editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A BRIEF NARRATIVE OF THE PROCEEDINGS OF THE GOVERNMENT OF NEW-YORK, RELATIVE TO THEIR OBTAINING THE JURISDICTION OF THAT LARGE DISTRICT OF LAND, TO THE WESTWARD FROM CONNECTICUT RIVER, Which, antecedent thereto, had been patented by his Maje≈øty's Governor and Council of the Government of NEW-HAMPSHIRE.
AND ALSO, Of the monopolizing Conduct of the Government of New-York, in their ≈øub≈øequently patenting Part of the ≈øame Land; and oppre≈ø≈øing the Grantees and Settlers under New-Hamp≈øhire.
TOGETHER WITH Arguments demon≈øtrating that the Property of tho≈øe LANDS was conveyed from the Crown to the New-Hamp≈øhire Grantees, by Virtue of their re≈øpective Charters.

WITH REMARKS on a Pamphlet entitled, "A State of the Right of the Colony of New-York," &c. and on the Narrative of the Proceedings ≈øub≈øequent to the royal Adjudecation, concerning the Lands to the We≈øtward of Connecticut River; lately u≈øurp'd by New-Hamp≈øhire. Intended as an Appendix to the General A≈ø≈øembly's State of the Right of the Colony of New-York, (with Re≈øpect to it's Ea≈øtern Boundary on Connecticut River, ≈øo far as concerns the late Encroachments under the Government of New-Hamp≈øhire) publi≈øhed at their Se≈ø≈øion, 1773.
By ETHAN ALLEN.
BENNINGTON, 23d September, 1774.
HARTFORD: Printed by E ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ N, WATSON, near the Great Bridge.

LIEUTENANT Governor Colden repre≈øented to his Maje≈øty and Privy Council, that it would be greatly to the Advantage of the Inhabitants of the Di≈øtrict of Land to the We≈øtward of Connecticut River, which had been granted by the Government of New-Hamp≈øhire, to be under the Juri≈ødiction of the Province of New-York, and that Connecticut River was a good and certain Boundary line to divide the re≈øpective Provinces; and furthermore, that Hud≈øon's River was navigable a great Way into the Country; and that the Situation of the New-Hamp≈øhire Grants was ≈øuch as would naturally con≈øtitute that River the Centre of Trade and Commerce, for the Inhabitants of tho≈øe Grants; by the Navigation of which they could ea≈øily ≈øend Exports to the City of New-York,
and receive and return ≈øuch Articles as they needed: And that it would therefore be much more convenient and happy for them to be under the Juri≈ødiction of New-York, &c.

WITH Re≈øpect to the Southwe≈øt Part of the Di≈øtrict of Land afore≈øaid it mu≈øt be confe≈ø≈øed that Hud≈øon's River mu≈øt con≈øtitute the Centre of Trade, &c. to the Inhabitants thereof. But Three Qurters or more of that Di≈øtrict of di≈øputed Lands, from the Contiguou≈øne≈øs thereof to Lake Champlain, and remote Situation from Hud≈øon's River, equally con≈øtitute Lake Champlain, Montreal, &c. the Centre of Trade for its Inhabitants.‚ÄîFurthermore, it is no Way incompatable, provided the Inhabitants of the Southwe≈øt Quarter of the Di≈øtrict afore≈øaid ≈øhould Trade at New-York, although they may be ≈øuppo≈øed to be under the Juri≈ødiction of New-Hamp≈øhire. The following Exhibitions, will undoubtedly convince the impartial Reader that the ≈øaid Inhabitants would be under va≈øtly greater Advantage, to trade at New-York, or any where el≈øe, on Provi≈øo they ≈øhould be re-annexed to the Government of New-Hamp≈øhire; for then they would peaceably enjoy the Right of ≈øoil of Lands they po≈ø≈øe≈øs, which, under the Juri≈ødiction of New-York they cannot. A Number of Families that have ≈øpent their Sub≈øtance in purcha≈øing Lands of the Government of New-Hamp≈øhire, and in removing from a great Di≈øtance to the Premi≈øes, and in making Improvements thereon; provided they ≈øhould be di≈øinherited, would make a very indifferent Figure trading at New-York.

HIS Maje≈øty, ever graciou≈øly di≈øpo≈øed to promote the Intere≈øt and Good of his Subjects, and viewing the E≈øtabli≈øhment of the juri≈ødictional Line between the re≈øpective Governments, as not interfering with the private Property of his Subjects, and in this View of the Ca≈øe, perceiving a manife≈øt Convenience, at lea≈øt for a Part of that Di≈øtrict, to be annexed to the Province of New-York; and the Government of New-Hamp≈øhire not being notified of Tryal (which is ≈øuppo≈øed to be owing to the Neglect of their Agent) by which Means his Maje≈øty and Council could have no Information but from the Repre≈øentations from New-York; came to a Determination of the juri≈ødictional Line Exparte; which is probably the Cau≈øe why it extended ≈øo far Ea≈øt as the we≈øt Banks of Connecticut River. This Event proved exceeding unfortunate to the New-Hamp≈øhire Settlers: From which they may compute the Date of their Oppre≈ø≈øion from the Government of New-York; this put it in the Power of that crafty, de≈øinging, & monopolizing Government, to exerci≈øe that U≈øurpation towards the Inhabitants afore≈øaid, exhibited in the following Sheets.

No ≈øooner had New-York obtained the Juri≈ødiction, than Governor Colden began to Patent, to certain celebrated Attornies and principal Gentleman in the Province, the very Lands on which the New-Hamp≈øhire Settlers dwelt; and it is a more inexcu≈øable and complicated Wickedne≈øs in Governor Colden; ina≈ømuch as but a little before he per≈øwaded his graciou≈øly di≈øpo≈øed Maje≈øty into an Opinion
that it would be for the Advantage and Happine≈øs of the Settlers aforesaid to be under the Juri≈ødiction of New-York. A complaint of the Conduct of the Government of New-York, relative to their laying Patent upon Patent, as afore≈øaid, being laid before his Maje≈øty, who with the Advice of his Privy Council was graciou≈øly plea≈øed to prohibit the Government of New-York from Patenting any of the ≈øaid Di≈øtrict of Land patented by the Governor of New-Hamp≈øhire as afore≈øaid, on Pain of his Maje≈øty's highe≈øt Di≈øplea≈øure. Notwith≈øtanding, the ≈øame Lieutenant Governor Colden, Governor Dunmore, and Governor Tryon, have, each and every of them, in their re≈øpective Turns in the Admini≈øtration, pre≈øumed to violate the ≈øaid Royal Command, by Patenting to certain of their own Favourites and Gentlemen of Influence, ≈øundry valuable Tracts of Land contained in, and belonging to the prohibited Premi≈øes; the mo≈øt of which Land being at the Time of patenting in actual Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion and Occupancy by People claiming the ≈øame Lands by Virtue of prior Patents from the Government of New-Hamp≈øhire.

NEXTLY, in the Cour≈øe of this Narrative it is nece≈ø≈øary to take a retro≈øpective View to July Term, in the Year 1769, at which the Claimants under New-York, being Non-re≈øidents, brought Actions of Ejectment in the Supreme Court again≈øt ≈øundry of the Claimants under New-Hamp≈øhire, who were in actual Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the conte≈øted Premi≈øes: but part if not all of the Judges and Attornies being intere≈øted in the ≈øaid ≈øub≈øequent Patents
from the Government of New-York, and ≈øome of the principal Attornies, Patentees of the identical Patents then on Tryal. And the Plaintiffs appearing in great Fa≈øhion and State, which, together with their Fraternity of Land-monopolizers, made a briliant Appearance. But the Defendants appearing in but ordinary Fa≈øhion, having been greatly fatigued by hard Labour, wrought on the di≈øputed Premi≈øes, made a very di≈øproportionable Figure at Court; and, in fine, Intere≈øt, Connection, and Grandeur, ea≈øily turned the Ca≈øe again≈øt the forlorn Defendants: The whole Di≈øtrict of Inhabitants were greatly alarm'd at the Event that had begun to take Place, were in great Con≈øternation, each Individual reading his own intolerable Di≈øtruction from that which had already began.

STILL there was more Actions of Ejectment commenced again≈øt ≈øundry of the Inhabitants, and the Sheriff of Albany County, by ≈øpecial Order from the Governor, was rai≈øing the Militia of the County to di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈øs the Defendants afore≈øaid, of their Tenements. This was a mo≈øt melancholy Scene‚ÄîWomen lamenting over their Children, and they crying; and Men pierced to the Heart with the mo≈øt pungent Grief and Affection for them, and bitter Indignation at the approaching Tyranny of New-York. And what renders the Reflection of the Conflict more doleful, is the Con≈øideration of the extreme Fatigue, Hunger, and infinite Hard≈øhips the Inhabitants had undergone in the Settlement and Cultivation of a Wilderne≈øs Country: It ≈øtill adds a twinge to the Smart to
take a retro≈øpect on the Interim; and view the Attornies and wealthy Gentlemen in the Province (and mo≈øt of them in the City) of New-York "which fared ≈øumptuou≈øly every Day" peru≈øing the old ob≈øolete and abdicated Charter from King Charles to the Duke of York, and in≈øpecting into the Cabots and Hud≈øon's exploring this Continent; and withal, in≈øpecting clo≈øely, whether in ancient Time ≈øome Dutchman had not Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of ≈øome part of the abdicated Premi≈øes; and by ≈øuch round-about and ≈øalacious Pretences of deducing a Title, planing the Ruin of the Inhabitants afore≈øaid.‚ÄîBut to return to the Sheriff and the Po≈ø≈øe of Albany County, who were in motion to di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈øs the Inhabitants, Defendants afore≈øaid, and deliver their Tenements to the Claimants under New-York. The Inhabitants being thus drove to the Extremity of either quiting their Country and Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, or make forceable Oppo≈øition to the Sheriff and Po≈ø≈øe. In this State of De≈øperacy they put on Fortitude, and cho≈øe the latter Expedient, and managed with that Oeconomy that they defeated the Sheriff in di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing them, without Blood≈øhed: Though it ≈øhould be confe≈ø≈øed that this Event was but partly owing to the Fortitude of the Inhabitants; the greate≈øt Rea≈øon was this, the People of the Government in general (but particularly tho≈øe that compo≈øe the Po≈ø≈øe of the ≈øaid County of Albany) were fully per≈øwaded and con≈øcious, that the Cau≈øe of the Inhabitants was ju≈øt; and that the New-York Patentees was Oppre≈ø≈øive and unju≈øt: And therefore they would not hazard their lives to defend
them in ≈øuch an U≈øurpation of the Rights of their fellow Men.

THERE had before this time been ≈øeveral le≈ø≈øer Combinations of the People of tho≈øe Grants to defend their Per≈øons and Properties from the Encroachments of New-York, which by them are called by the opprobrious Names of Riots, Mobs, Rebellion, Felony, &c‚ÄîAfter the ineffectual Mu≈øter of the Po≈ø≈øe, the Land-Monopolizers in the Colony of New-York, adopted different Mea≈øures to accompli≈øh their De≈øigns; perceiving they could not rai≈øe a Militia, that would Fight for the Title of their Sub≈øequent Patents, and they being a cringing, fawnig, deceitful Fraternity; not enured to the Horrors of War, or any thing Heroic, dur≈øt not Fight for their own Claims: Their accu≈øtomed Way, to carry Paints, being to deceive, cheat and over reach the Commonality of their Species, under a Pretence of Law, Ju≈øtice, good Government, and a great pretended Zeal of Loyalty, &c. They were therefore obliged to follow their old beaten Road of Politics, and by their Influence, cau≈øed to be indicted as Rioters, every of the mo≈øt bold, ≈øpirited and leading Men, who were active in defending either their Country or them≈øelves, again≈øt their mo≈øt egregious and intreiguing Wiles; hopeing to make ≈øuch an Example of them thereby as to frighten the Re≈øt into their de≈øpotic Mea≈øures.‚ÄîThe Inhabitants in general viewing this to be their Policy, guarded again≈øt it, and were active in defending them≈øelves, their Friends and Neighbours ≈øo indicted, being fully per≈øwaded that the
Fraternity of New-York Patentees were the Fomenters and Planers of tho≈øe Indictments; and that they eventually, by ≈øuch Stratagems, de≈øigned to avail them≈øelves of the Fee-≈øimple of the Lands which they, the afore≈øaid Inhabitants po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed. And as for the New-York Patentees, and ≈øuch part of the Authority and People as they could Influence, they were active, endeavouring by all and every Method to apprehend the Rioters (≈øo called) and puni≈øh them as Criminals: The Struggles that en≈øued between the Parties relative to taking and defending Rioters, terminated in Wrath, Strife, and Ill-Will: The Con≈øequences ari≈øing therefrom, (which are too prolix to be in≈øerted) are very ingeniou≈øly ≈øummed up in the≈øe Words, "Where Envying and Strife is, there is Confu≈øion and every Evil Work." Tho' it is common (and almo≈øt without Exception) for both Parties to be more or le≈øs blameable in ≈øo long and ≈øpirited a Controver≈øy; yet in the In≈øtances before us, it is beyond Di≈øpute certain, that the Yorkers act offen≈øively, and the New-Hamp≈øhire Settlers defen≈øively, which will more fully appear.

BUT to ≈øhorten this Narration, and yet make it intelligible, and exhibit to View, that tho≈øe Gentlemen intere≈øted in the Lands contained in the New-Hamp≈øhire Grants, by ≈øub≈øequent Patents from the Government of New-York, have extended their Influence into the General A≈ø≈øembly of the Government, and ≈øway that whole Legi≈ølative Body; the following Votes and Proceedings of that A≈ø≈øembly are here tran≈øcribed;
and al≈øo, the Votes and Proceedings of the General Committee for the Inhabitants of the New-Hamp≈øhire Grants in An≈øwer thereto: And likewi≈øe, the Acts pa≈ø≈øed by the Legi≈ølative Body afore≈øaid, the 9th of March Ultimo, and Remarks on the ≈øame; which here follow in their order, as they were publi≈øhed in ≈øundry public News-Papers in America.

div.head: FROM the New-Hamp≈øhire Gazette, No. 914.
div.p: "At a General Meeting of the Committee for the ≈øeveral Town≈øhips on the We≈øt Side of the Range of Green Mountains granted under the Great Seal of the Province of New-Hamp≈øhire, held at the Hou≈øe of Mr. Eliakim Wellers in Manche≈øter, on the 1≈øt Day of March, A. D. 1774; and afterwards, by Adjournment, at the Hou≈øe of Capt. Jehiel Hawley, in Arlington, on the third Wedne≈øday of the ≈øame Month; at which ≈øeveral Times, and Places, the New-York Mercury No. 1163, was produced; which contains an Extract from the Votes and Proceedings of the General A≈ø≈øembly of the Colony of New-York, which is as follows, viz.

"MR. Bru≈øh, (in behalf of Mr. Clinton, Chairman) from the Grand Committee, reported, that he was directed by the ≈øaid Committee, to make the following Report to the Hou≈øe, viz. That the ≈øaid Committee having taken into Con≈øideration, the Petition of Benjamin Hough, in behalf of him≈øelf,
and many of his Maje≈øty's Subjects, inhabiting the County of Charlotte, and the North-Ea≈øtern Di≈øtrict of the County of Albany; complaining of many Acts of Outrage, Cruelty, and Oppre≈ø≈øion, committed again≈øt their Per≈øons and Properties by the Bennington MOB, and the Dangers and Injuries to which they are Daily expo≈øed, and imploring that this Hou≈øe will take them under their Protection, and ≈øecure them again≈øt future Violence; and the ≈øaid Committee, having al≈øo duly con≈øidered the ≈øeveral Proofs and Depo≈øitions pre≈øented in ≈øupport of the Truth of the ≈øaid Petition, do therefore Re≈øolve,

"1, THAT it appears to this Committee, that there at pre≈øent prevails in part of the County of Charlotte, and in the North-Ea≈øtern Di≈øtrict of the County of Albany, a dangerous and de≈øtructive Spirit of Riot and Licentiou≈øne≈øs, ≈øubver≈øive of all Order and good Government; and that it is become an intolerable Grievance, which requires immediate Redre≈øs.‚Äî

"2, RESOLVED, That it appears to this Committee, that many Acts of Outrage, Cruelty, and Oppre≈ø≈øion have been there perpetrated by a Number of lawle≈øs Per≈øons, calling them≈øelves the Bennington MOB, who have ≈øeized, in≈øulted, and terrified ≈øeveral Magi≈øtrates and other civil Officers, ≈øo that they dare not exerci≈øe their re≈øpective Functions, ri≈øqued Pri≈øoners for Debt, a≈ø≈øumed to them≈øelves military Commands, and judicial Power, burned and demoli≈øhed the Hou≈øes
and Property, and beat and abu≈øed the Per≈øons of many of his Maje≈øty's Subjects, expelled them from their Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, and put a Period to the Admini≈øtration of Ju≈øtice, and ≈øpread Terror and De≈øtruction through that Part of the Country which is expo≈øed to their Oppre≈ø≈øion.

"3, RESOLVED, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, that the Complainants before this Hou≈øe and others, who inhabit Part of that Colony, and from Re≈øpect to Government, will not countenance or be concerned in the ≈øaid riotous Proceedings, are expo≈øed from the Violence of the Rioters to eminent Danger, both in Per≈øons, and Properties, and that they ≈øtand in Need of immediate Protection and Succour.

"4, RESOLVED, That it appears to this Committee, that Ethan Allen, Seth Warner, Remember Baker, Robert Cochran, Peleg Sunderland, Silvanus Brown, James Breakenridge, and John Smith, are principal Ring-Leaders of, and Actors in the Riots and Di≈øturbances afore≈øaid, and that it is therefore the Opinion of this Committee, that an humble Addre≈øs be pre≈øented to his Excellency, de≈øiring that He would be plea≈øed to i≈ø≈øue a Proclamation, offering a Reward of Fifty Pounds for apprehending and ≈øecuring any or either of the Per≈øons above named, in his Maje≈øty's Goal in Albany; and commanding the Magi≈øtrates, and other Civil Officers of the Counties of Albany and Charlotte, to be active and vigilent in ≈øuppre≈ø≈øing the ≈øaid Riots, and pre≈øerving the Public Peace
and good Order, as well as for bringing to Ju≈øtice the Perpetrators and Authors of ≈øaid Riots.

"5, RESOLVED, That it is the Opinion of this Committee, that a Bill be brought in, more effectually to ≈øuppre≈øs the ≈øaid riotous and di≈øorderly Proceedings, maintain the free Cour≈øe of Ju≈øtice, and for bringing the Offenders to condign Puni≈øhment; which Report he read in his Place, and afterward delivered it in at the Table, where the ≈øaid Re≈øolutions were ≈øeverally read a Second Time, Re≈øolved that this Hou≈øe doth agree with the Committee in their ≈øaid Re≈øolutions.

"ORDERED, That a Bill be brought in, pur≈øuant to the la≈øt Re≈øolution, and that Mr. Bru≈øh, and Col. Ten Broeck, prepare and bring in the ≈øame. Ordered, That Capt. Delancey and Mr. Walton, wait on his Excellency the Governor with the foregoing Addre≈øs and Re≈øolutions of the Hou≈øe."

Mr. Nathan Clark, Chairman of the Committee of the New-Hamp≈øhire Settlers afore≈øaid, ordered the Clerk to read the Re≈øolves and Votes afore≈øaid, to the general Committee, which was accordingly read ≈øundry Times, and the following Draught being pre≈øented in An≈øwer thereto, to the Publick Meeting; Seven Per≈øons were ≈øelected and cho≈øen out of the ≈øaid general Committee, to examine the ≈øame, and report their Opinion thereon, which here follows.

"WHEN we con≈øider the numberle≈øs Troubles,
and almo≈øt in≈øurmountable Difficulties which our infant Settlements have been forced to ≈øtruggle with, ≈øince its fir≈øt Beginning, which have been occa≈øioned by an unequal and bia≈ø≈øed Admini≈øtration of Law, ever ≈øince our unhappy Misfortune of being annexed to a Government in which the Intere≈øt of the greater Part of the leading Gentlemen thereof are in direct Oppo≈øition to our's. The tyrannical Mea≈øures they take to en≈ølave us, (we hope) will not fail to ju≈øtify us in the following Arguments and Re≈øolves thereon; for we think it an intolerable Hard≈øhip, and Piece of inhuman Cruelty, that we cannot be ≈øaid to give ≈øufficient Proof of our Loyalty and Obedience to Government but at the Re≈øignation of our whole Fortunes, in the Purcha≈øe and Improvement of which, we have ≈øuffered an Infinity of Hard≈øhips. Yet, at the ≈øame Time, impre≈ø≈øed with a Sen≈øe of Gratitude, we return our thankful Acknowledgment to the≈øe worthy Gentlemen, Governor Tryon, and ≈øundry of His Maje≈øty's honorable Council, for the Province of New-York, for their ≈øignal Favours to us in ≈øome Time pa≈øt; which has, in ≈øome Degree, alleviated and ≈øupported us, under our heavy Troubles and Oppre≈ø≈øions. But when we con≈øider that his Excellency is about to embark for Great-Britain, and while we view the Spirit of the General A≈ø≈øembly, in their Re≈øolves; we cannot but reflect with ≈øome Regret, on what may of Con≈øequence prove the Re≈øult (without an Alteration) of their pre≈øent Opinion; but there
are ≈øcarce any Circum≈øtances that entirely exclude Hope; therefore we are not yet in total Di≈øpair: For this Moment we happily call to Mind, that the General A≈ø≈øembly of the ≈øame Province, about two Years ago, did annex all that Part of the Bay Province, We≈øt of Connecticut River, to that UNLIMITED County of Albany; but their avaricious Grappling not being of a ≈øufficient Strength for ≈øuch an unrea≈øonable Burthen, it failed, by which they lo≈øt their ideal Booty.

"THE candid Reader will doubtle≈øs ob≈øerve, that in the Re≈øolves of the A≈ø≈øembly afore≈øaid, there is not a ≈øingle Word mentioned in Regard to the Title of the Land conte≈øted for, but that they level all their Spleen, and point all their Malice at notorious Rioters, as they call them, and make a pretended Shew and Figure, as though they were great Sticklers for good Order and Government; although at the ≈øame Time every Per≈øon of common Sen≈øe, who has had any Acquaintance and Knowledge of the Controver≈øy, ab≈øolutely knows, that our goodly Land, with the Labour thereon, is the only ≈øubject Matter, and grand Object of the whole Controver≈øy; and give the New-Yorkers but that, and the Matter would be accompli≈øhed to their eternal Satisfaction; and it is pre≈øumed the Words Riotous, Di≈øorderly, Licentious, &c. would not be printed again on account of the New-Hamp≈øhire Grantees and pre≈øent Occupants, for the whole Cour≈øe of the ≈øucceeding Century.

"FOR the Truth of the Ca≈øe is, the Executors of the Law, are mo≈øt (if not all) of them the pretended Claimants to the Lands whereon the New-Hamp≈øhire Grantees and Occupants dwell, and their Judgments on Writs of Ejectment, brought by the New-York Patentees, have not hitherto failed to corre≈øpond with their imaginary Intere≈øts; but were they hone≈øt Men they would not undertake to be Judges in their own Ca≈øe, or in any other wherein the Re≈øolution thereof would make a Pre≈øident, for their own, e≈øpecially in Title of Land wherein Judge and Plaintiff are connected in one common Intere≈øt: ≈øuch a Di≈øtribution of Law is contrary to the Law of Rea≈øon and Nations.‚Äî

"Therefore our Ca≈øe ≈øtands thus, if we ≈øubmit to their Execution of Law, and become obedient and ≈øubmi≈ø≈øive Subjects of their de≈øigning Government, we mu≈øt ≈øoon yield to be their Tenants and Slaves; and we cannot ≈øee Rea≈øon to conform to any Law, or ≈øuch Branches of it, as will apparently bring us and our Po≈øterity into Bondage, or manife≈øtly deprive us of our Property; but ina≈ømuch as we boldly adhere to the Maintenance of our Property, which to us is very precious, as it would be to the New-Yorkers, was it in their hands; we find it is immediately recommended to the Governor of the Province by the General A≈ø≈øembly, to i≈ø≈øue his Proclamation, Offering therein large Sums of Money to apprehend tho≈øe notorious
Rioters (as they are plea≈øed to ≈øtile them) but any one who has had Opportunity to read the Stipulation and particular Articles of the public Faith, pledged by the Government of New-York to the New-Hamp≈øhire Grantees and Settlers, dated in July Anno Domini 1772, will immediately find a ≈øufficient Rea≈øon for the Governor's not ≈øigning ≈øuch a Proclamation; for it mu≈øt indeed be ≈øhocking to common Sen≈øe when the Reader comes to ob≈øerve what notorious Complaints, and mo≈øt horrid Accu≈øations are ≈øet forth in the Re≈øolves of the General A≈ø≈øembly of New-York, mentioned in the fore Part of this Paper, again≈øt Thou≈øands of hard labouring, indu≈øtrious, hone≈øt Pea≈øants, who are in Truth loyal Subjects of the Crown of Great-Britain, for their Violations of Law and Government; when at the ≈øame Time the following expre≈øs Orders from his Mo≈øt Sacred Maje≈øty, to that litigious Government of New-York, will plainly ≈øhow that they do not make the lea≈øt He≈øitation, to rebel and act in direct Oppo≈øition to the Authority of the Crown, when (as in the pre≈øent Ca≈øe) they ≈øhow a Di≈øpo≈øition to take Advantage of the minor Part of tho≈øe under their Government; and throw them into Contention and Di≈øorder; and thereby build their Fortunes on the Ruin of the pretended Aggre≈ø≈øors; and all under the ≈øpecious Pretence of good Order and Government which is in Fact what they eventually aim at, as will appear by the following Order.

opener.dateline:
"At a Court at St. James's,
the 24th Day of July, 1767.

div.p: PRESENT,
"THE Petition and Report thereon by the Lords of Trade and Plantation Affairs, is too prolix to be in≈øerted in this Paper, the royal Order is therefore only tran≈øcribed which is as Follows.

"His Maje≈øty taking the ≈øaid Report into Con≈øideration, was plea≈øed, with the Advice of his Privy Council, to approve thereof, and doth hereby ≈øtrictly charge, require and command, that the Governor or Commander in Chief of his Maje≈øty's Province of New-York, for the Time being, do not upon Pain of his Maje≈øty's highe≈øt Di≈øplea≈øure, pre≈øume to make any Grant what≈øoever, of any Part of the Lands de≈øcribed in the ≈øaid Report, until his Maje≈øty's further Plea≈øure ≈øhall „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ concerning the ≈øame.

closer.signed: A true Copy, WILLIAM SHARPE,
Atte≈øt GEO. BANYAR, Dep. Sec'ry.

div.p: "NOTWITHSTANDING this Prohibition, and one or two more of the ≈øame general Import, and from the ≈øame Authority, the Government of New-York have lapped their Patents on the New-Hamp≈øhire Charters, and in Con≈øequence thereof demand at Common Law, the Lands on which the New-Hamp≈øhire Grantees and Occupants dwell; and from hence has ari≈øen the numerous Troubles and Di≈øturbances, between the Government of New-York, and its di≈øcontented Subjects, the Settlers under New-Hamp≈øhire. This has al≈øo been the Source of all Licentiou≈øne≈øs and Confu≈øion, Riotou≈øne≈øs, &c. complained of by that Government, again≈øt the Settlers afore≈øaid.

"AND whereas the true State of our Grants hath been already laid before the worthy Lords of the Board of Trade and Plantation, and they having con≈øidered, and wi≈øely deliberated upon its ≈øeveral Circum≈øtances, did on the Third Day of December, A. D. 1772, make their Report in Favour of the New-Hamp≈øhire Grantees, to his mo≈øt Gracious Maje≈øty, who≈øe Royal Confirmation we daily expect, and on the Credit and good Faith of this Report, many Hundreds of indu≈øtrious (and many of them wealthy) Families, have purcha≈øed and moved upon the New-Hamp≈øhire Grants, nothing doubting of that Title.

"We therefore humbly report to the ≈øaid General Committee of the New-Hamp≈øhire Grants, as our Opinion, 1. That as we ever have, ≈øo for the future we will remain loyal and dutiful Subjects,
to our mo≈øt rightful Sovereign GEORGE the Third, and demean Our≈øelves agreeable to the good and whole≈øome Laws of the Realm, and ≈øight for the Honour and Dignity of his Maje≈øty's Crown and Government, at all Times when there may be a Call for it, viewing him as our political Father, and relying on him to be protected in our Property.

"2, THAT as we purcha≈øed our Lands of One of his Maje≈øty's Governors, and on the good Faith of the Crown of Great-Britain, we are determined to maintain tho≈øe Grants, again≈øt all Oppo≈øition, until his Maje≈øty's Royal Plea≈øure ≈øhall be known on the Premi≈øes.

"AND whereas we have never made any further Re≈øi≈øtance to Government, than the Law of Self-Pre≈øervation, which the Law of GOD and Nature enjoyns on every intelligent, wi≈øe and under≈øtanding Being; we therefore are fully of the Opinion to re≈øolve,

3, THAT ≈øuch of the Magi≈øtrates, and governmental Authority of the Province of New-York, as have pur≈øued, and have been acce≈ø≈øary in the Scheme of indicting our Friends and Neighbours as Rioters; and have by Intrigue and Stratagem, of various Sorts, endeavoured to take them, and puni≈øh them as Criminals; thereby to di≈øhearten and terrify the New-Hamp≈øhire Settlers to that Degree, that they may tamely be di≈øinherited; have acted contrary to the Spirit and De≈øign of the good
and righteous Laws of Great-Britain, which, under a ju≈øt Admini≈øtration, never fail to ≈øecure the Liberty and Property of the Subject; are thereby guilty of great Inhumanity to its re≈øpective Subjects. We therefore re≈øolve, That as a Country, we will ≈øtand by, and defend our Friends and Neighbours, ≈øo indicted, at the Expence of our Lives and Fortunes. And we would recommend it to the General A≈ø≈øembly of the Province of New-York, to wait the Determination of his Maje≈øty, relative to the Title of tho≈øe Lands, and de≈øi≈øt from taking us as Rioters, to prevent the unhappy Con≈øequences that may re≈øult from ≈øuch an Attempt.

"AND Fourthly, and la≈øtly, Re≈øolved, That for the future, every nece≈ø≈øary Preparation be made, and that our Inhabitants hold them≈øelves in Readine≈øs, at a Minute's Warning, to aid and defend ≈øuch Friends of our's, who, for their Merit to the great and general Cau≈øe, are fal≈øely denominated Rioters; but that we will not act any Thing, more or le≈øs, but on the Defen≈øive, and always encourage due Execution of Law, in civil Ca≈øes, and al≈øo in criminal Pro≈øecutions, that are ≈øo indeed; and that we will a≈ø≈øi≈øt, to the utmo≈øt of our Power, the Officers appointed for that Purpo≈øe.

"THE foregoing Arguments, Narrations and Re≈øolves, being laid before the General Committee of the New-Ham≈øhire Grants, and was read ≈øundry Times, and carefully examined. And after mature Deliberation, Mr. Clark, Chairman, put
the Votes to Tryal, whether the foregoing was approved of, as an An≈øwer to the Re≈øolves of the General A≈ø≈øembly of the Province of New-York? And it was pa≈ø≈øed in the Affirmative. And it was furthermore the Advice of this Committee, that the foregoing be forthwith exhibited in the public Papers, to the Intent that all Officers, Magi≈øtrates and Per≈øons what≈øoever may know that if they pre≈øume to take the Rioters afore≈øaid, they do it on their Peril.

Certified per
NATHAN CLARK, Chairman.
JONAS FAY, Clerk.

div.head: The following LAW of the Colony of New-York, was pa≈ø≈øed the 9th Day of March, 1774.
div.p: "An ACT for preventing tumultuous and riotous A≈ø≈øemblies in the Places therein mentioned, and for the more ≈øpeedy and effectual puni≈øhing the Rioters.

"WHEREAS a Spirit of Riot and Licentiou≈øne≈øs has of late prevailed in ≈øome Parts of the Counties of Charlotte and Albany, and many Acts of Outrage and Cruelty have been perpetrated by a Number of turbulent Men, who, a≈ø≈øembling from Time to Time in Arms, have ≈øeized, in≈øulted and menaced ≈øeveral Magi≈øtrates, and other Civil Officers, ≈øo that they dare not execute their Functions‚Äîre≈øcued Pri≈øoners for Debt‚Äîa≈ø≈øumed to them≈øelves military Commands, and judicial Powers‚Äîburned and demoli≈øhed the Hou≈øes and Property, and
beat and abu≈øed the Per≈øons of many of His Maje≈øty's Subjects‚Äîexpelled others from their Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions‚Äîand finally, have put a Period to the Admini≈øtration of Ju≈øtice within, and ≈øpread Terror and De≈øtruction throughout that Part of the Country which is expo≈øed to their Oppre≈ø≈øion: Therefore, for the preventing and ≈øuppre≈ø≈øing ≈øuch Riots and Tumults, and for the more ≈øpeedy and effectual puni≈øhing the Offenders therein,

"1. Be it Enacted, by His Excellency the Governor, the Council, and the General A≈ø≈øembly, and it is hereby enacted, by the Authority of the ≈øame, That if any Per≈øons, to the Number of Three, or more, being unlawfully, riotou≈øly, and tumultuou≈øly a≈ø≈øembled, within either of the ≈øaid Counties, to the Di≈øturbance of the public Peace, at any Time after the pa≈øting of this Act, and being required or commanded, by any One or more Ju≈øtice or Ju≈øtices of the Peace, or by the High Sheriff, or his Under Sheriff, or by any One of the Coroners of the County where ≈øuch A≈ø≈øembly ≈øhall be, by Proclamation to be made in the King's Name, in the Form herein after directed, to di≈øper≈øe them≈øelves, and peaceably to depart to their Habitations, or to their lawful Bu≈øine≈øs, ≈øhall, to the Number of Three, or more, notwith≈øtanding ≈øuch Proclamation made, unlawfully, riotou≈øly, and tumultuou≈øly remain or continue together to the Number of Three, or more, after ≈øuch command, or Reque≈øt, made by Proclamation, ≈øhall, for every ≈øuch Offence, upon Conviction thereof, in due Form of Law, either in the Supreme Count of Judicature of this Colony, or at
the Courts of Oyer and Terminer, and General Goal Delivery, or at the General Se≈ø≈øions of the Peace, to be held re≈øpectively in and for the ≈øaid Counties of Albany and Charlotte, or either of them, ≈øuffer Twelve Months Impri≈øonment without Bail or Mainprize, and ≈øuch further corporal Puni≈øhment, as the re≈øpective Courts before which he, ≈øhe, or they ≈øhall be convicted, ≈øhall judge fit, not extending to Life or Limb; and before his or her Di≈øcharge, ≈øhall enter into Recognizance with two ≈øufficient Sureties, in ≈øuch Sums as the ≈øaid Court ≈øhall re≈øpectively direct, to be of good Behaviour, and keep the Peace towards his Maje≈øty, and all his Subjects, for the Term of Three Years, from ≈øuch his, her, or their Di≈øcharge out of Pri≈øon.

"2. And be it further enacted by the Authority afore≈øaid, That the Order and Form of the Proclamation which ≈øhall be made by the Authority of this Act, ≈øhall be as hereafter follows, that is to ≈øay, The Ju≈øtice, or other Per≈øon, authorized by this Act to make the ≈øaid Proclamation, ≈øhall, among the ≈øaid Rioters, or as near to them as he can ≈øafely come, with a loud Voice command, or cau≈øe to be commanded, Silence to be kept, while Proclamation is making; and ≈øhall then openly, with a loud Voice, make, or cau≈øe to be made, Proclamation in the≈øe Words, or to the like Effect: Our Sovereign Lord the King, chargeth and commandeth all Per≈øons, being a≈ø≈øembled, immediately to di≈øper≈øe them≈øelves, and peaceably to depart to their Habitations, or to their lawful Bu≈øine≈øs, upon the Pain contained in the Act made in the Fourteenth Year of the Reign of King GEORGE
the Third, to prevent tumultuous and riotous A≈ø≈øemblies. And every ≈øuch Ju≈øtice and Ju≈øtices of the Peace, Sheriff, Under Sheriff, or Coroner, within the Limits of the re≈øpective Counties where they re≈øide, are hereby authori≈øed, impowered, and required, on Notice or Knowledge of any ≈øuch unlawful, riotous and tumultuous A≈ø≈øembly, forthwith to repair to the Place where ≈øuch unlawful, riotous and tumultuous A≈ø≈øembly ≈øhall be, to the Number of Three, or more, and there to make, or cau≈øe to be made, Proclamation in Manner afore≈øaid.

"3. And be it further enacted, by the Authority afore≈øaid, That if any Per≈øon or Per≈øons do, or ≈øhall, with Force and Arms, wilfully and knowingly oppo≈øe, ob≈øtruct, or in any Manner wilfully and knowingly let, hinder or hurt and Per≈øon or Per≈øons, who ≈øhall begin to proclaim, or go to proclaim, according to the Proclamation hereby directed to be made, whereby ≈øuch Proclamation ≈øhall not be made; that then every ≈øuch oppo≈øing, letting, hindering, or hurting ≈øuch Per≈øon or Per≈øons ≈øo being „Äà‚óä„Äâ going to make ≈øuch Proclamation as afore≈øaid, ≈øhall be adjudged Felony without Benefit of Clergy; and that the Offenders therein, ≈øhall be adjudged Felons, and ≈øhall ≈øuffer Death, as in Ca≈øes of Felony without Benefit of Clergy: And that al≈øo every ≈øuch Per≈øon or Per≈øons, ≈øo being unlawfully, riotou≈øly and tumultuou≈øly a≈ø≈øembled to the Number of Three, as afore≈øaid, or more, to whom Proclamation ≈øhould, or ought to have been made, if the ≈øame had not been hindered as afore≈øaid, ≈øhall, in Ca≈øe they, or any of them, to
the Number of Three, or more, ≈øhall continue together, and not forthwith di≈øper≈øe them≈øelves, after ≈øuch Let or Hindrance, having Knowledge of ≈øuch Let or Hindrance, ≈øhall likewi≈øe for every ≈øuch Offence, upon Conviction thereof, in Manner afore≈øaid, ≈øuffer the ≈øame Pains and Penalties as are hereby inflicted on tho≈øe who ≈øhall continue together to the Number of Three, or more, after they ≈øhall be commanded to depart to their Habitations, or lawful Bu≈øine≈øs, by Proclamation as afore≈øaid.

"4. And be it Further Enacted, by the Authority afore≈øaid, That if ≈øuch Per≈øons ≈øo unlawfully, riotou≈øly and tumultuou≈øly a≈ø≈øembled, or any Three or more of them, after Proclamation made in Manner afore≈øaid, ≈øhall continue together, and not forthwith di≈øper≈øe them≈øelves, it ≈øhall and may be lawful to and for every ≈øuch Ju≈øtice of the Peace, Sheriff, Under Sheriff, Coroner, or Con≈øtable, of any County or Town≈øhip where ≈øuch A≈ø≈øembly ≈øhall be; and to and for ≈øuch Per≈øon or Per≈øons as ≈øhall be commanded to be a≈ø≈øi≈øting unto ≈øuch Ju≈øtice of the Peace, Sheriff, Under Sheriff, Coroner, or Con≈øtable, who are hereby authorized and impower'd to command all His Maje≈øty's Subjects of Age and Ability, to be aiding and a≈ø≈øi≈øting to them therein; to ≈øeize and apprehend, and they are hereby required to ≈øeize and apprehend ≈øuch Per≈øons ≈øo unlawfully, riotou≈øly, and tumultuou≈øly a≈ø≈øembled together, after Proclamation made as afore≈øaid, and forthwith to carry the Per≈øons ≈øo apprehended, before any one or more of his Maje≈øty's Ju≈øtices of the Peace of the ≈øaid Counties of Charlotte, or Albany; in order
to their being proceeded again≈øt for ≈øuch their Offences, according to Law.

"AND that if the Per≈øons ≈øo unlawfully, riotou≈øly, and tumultuou≈øly a≈ø≈øembled, or any of them, ≈øhall happen to be killed, maimed, or hurt in the di≈øper≈øing, ≈øeizing, or apprehending them, by rea≈øon of their re≈øi≈øting the Per≈øons ≈øo di≈øper≈øing, ≈øeizing, or apprehending, or endeavouring to di≈øper≈øe, ≈øeize, or apprehend them, that then every ≈øuch Ju≈øtice of the Peace, Sheriff, Under-Sheriff, Coroner or Con≈øtable, and all and ≈øingular Per≈øons aiding and a≈ø≈øi≈øting to them, or any of them, ≈øhall be freed, di≈øcharged, and indemnified, as well again≈øt the King's Maje≈øty, his Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors, as again≈øt all and every other Per≈øon and Per≈øons, of, for, or concerning the killing, maiming, or hurting of any ≈øuch Per≈øon or Per≈øons, ≈øo unlawfully, riotou≈øly, and tumultuou≈øly a≈ø≈øembled, that ≈øhall happen to be ≈øo killed, maimed, or hurt as afore≈øaid.

"5. And be it further enacted, by the Authority afore≈øaid, that if any Per≈øon or Per≈øons within the ≈øaid Counties, or either of them, not being lawfully authorized a Judge, Ju≈øtice, or Magi≈øtrate, ≈øhall a≈ø≈øume judicial Power, or ≈øhall try, fine, ≈øentence, or condemn any Per≈øon, who ≈øhall either be ab≈øent, or ≈øhall unlawfully or forcibly be ≈øeized, taken, or brought before Him or Them for Tryal, or Puni≈øhment; or if any Per≈øon or Per≈øons ≈øhall aid or a≈ø≈øi≈øt in ≈øuch illegal Proceedings, or ≈øhall inforce, execute, or carry
the ≈øame into Effect; or if any Per≈øon or Per≈øons ≈øhall unlawfully ≈øeize, detain, or confine, or a≈ø≈øault and beat any Magi≈øtrate, or civil Officer, for, or in the Re≈øpect of any Act or Proceeding in the due exerci≈øe of his Function, or in order to compel him to re≈øign, renounce, or ≈øurcea≈øe his Commi≈ø≈øion or Authority, or to terrify, hinder, or prevent him from performing and di≈øcharging the Duties thereof; or if any Per≈øon, or Per≈øons, either ≈øecretly, or openly, ≈øhall unlawfully, wilfully, and malliciou≈øly burn or de≈øtroy the Grain, Corn, or Hay, of any other Per≈øon, being in any Inclo≈øure, or if any Per≈øons unlawfully, riotou≈øly, and tumultuou≈øly a≈ø≈øembled together, to the Di≈øturbance of the public Peace, ≈øhall unlawfully, and with Force demoli≈øh, or pull down, or begin to demoli≈øh or pull down any Dwelling-Hou≈øe, Barn, Stable, Gri≈øt-Mill, Saw-Mill, or Out-Hou≈øe, within either of the ≈øaid Counties, that then, each of the ≈øaid Offences, re≈øpectively, ≈øhall be adjudged Felony, without Benefit of Clergy; and the Offenders therein, ≈øhall be adjudged Felons, and ≈øhall ≈øuffer Death, as in ca≈øes of Felony without Benefit of Clergy.

"6. AND WHEREAS Complaint and Proofs have been made, as well before his Excellency the Governor in Council, as before the General A≈ø≈øembly, That Ethan Allen, ≈øome Time of Sali≈øbury, in the Colony of Connecticut, but late of Bennington, in the County of Albany, Yeoman; Seth Warner, late of Bennington in the ≈øaid County,
Yeoman; Remember Baker, late of Arlington in the ≈øaid County, Yeoman; Robert Cochran, late of Ruporte, in the County of Charlotte, Yeoman; Peleg Sunderland, and Silvanus Brown, late of Socialborough in the ≈øame County, Yeomen; James Brackenridge, late of Wallum≈øchack, in the County of Albany, Yeoman; and John Smith, late of Socialborough, Yeoman; have been principal Ringleaders of, and Actors in the Riots and Di≈øturbances afore≈øaid; and the General A≈ø≈øembly have thereupon addre≈ø≈øed his Excellency the Governor, to i≈ø≈øue a Proclamation offering certain Rewards for apprehending and ≈øecuring the ≈øaid Offenders, and for bringing them, and the other Perpetrators and Authors of the Riots to Ju≈øtice: And fora≈ømuch as ≈øuch di≈øorderly Practices are highly criminal, and de≈øtructive to the Peace and Settlement of the Country, and it is indi≈øpen≈øably nece≈ø≈øary for Want of Proce≈øs to Outlawry (which is not u≈øed in this Colony) that ≈øpecial Provi≈øion be made for bringing ≈øuch Offenders in future to Tryal and Puni≈øhment, without expo≈øing the Colony to the Expence of extraordinary Rewards and Bounties for apprehending ≈øuch Offenders.‚Äî

"Be it therefore enacted, by the Authority afore≈øaid, That it ≈øhall and may be lawful to and for his Excellency the Governor, or the Governor and Commander in Chief, for the Time being, by and with the Advice of the Council, as often as either of the above named Per≈øons, or any other Per≈øon, ≈øhall be indicted in either of the Counties afore≈øaid, for any Offence perpetrated after the
pa≈ø≈øing of this Act, made Capital by this or any other Law, or where any Per≈øon may ≈øtand indicted for any of the Offences above mentioned, not made Felony by this Act, to make his Order in Council, thereby requiring and commanding ≈øuch Offender or Offenders to ≈øurrender them≈øelves re≈øpectively, within the Space of Seventy Days next, after the fir≈øt Publication thereof, in the New-York Gazette, and weekly Mercury; to one of his Maje≈øty's Ju≈øtices of the Peace, for either of the ≈øaid Counties re≈øpectively, who are hereby required thereupon to commit him or them, without Bail or Mainprize, to the Goal of the City of New-York, or of the City and County of Albany, to the End that He or They may be forthcoming to an≈øwer the Offence or Offences, wherewith He or They ≈øhall ≈øtand charged according to the ordinary Cour≈øe of the Law; which Order the Clerk of his Maje≈øty's Council, or his Deputy, ≈øhall cau≈øe forthwith to be printed and publi≈øhed, in eight ≈øucce≈ø≈øive Papers, of the New-York Gazette, and weekly Mercury; the two fir≈øt of which to be forthwith tran≈ømitted to the Sheriffs of the Counties of Albany and Charlotte; and the ≈øaid Sheriffs re≈øpectively, ≈øhall, within ≈øix Days after the Receipt thereof, cau≈øe the ≈øame printed Orders to be affixed upon the Door of the Court-Hou≈øe of the County of Albany, and upon the Door of the Dwelling-Hou≈øe of Patrick Smith, E≈øq where the Courts are now u≈øually held for the ≈øaid County of Charlotte, and upon the Doors of two other Publick-Hou≈øes, in each of their re≈øpective Counties. And in ca≈øe the ≈øaid Offenders
≈øhall not re≈øpectively ≈øurrender them≈øelves, pur≈øuant to ≈øuch Orders of his Excellency the Governor, or of the Governor and Commander in Chief for the Time being, to be made in Council as afore≈øaid; He or They ≈øo neglecting or refu≈øing to ≈øurrender Him≈øelf, or Them≈øelves as afore≈øaid, ≈øhall, from the Day to be appointed for his or their Surrendery as afore≈øaid be adjudged, deemed, and (if indicted for a capital Offence hereafter to be perpetrated) to be convicted and attainted of Felony, and ≈øhall ≈øuffer Death, as in Ca≈øes of Per≈øons convicted & attainted of Felony by Verdict and Judgment, without Benefit of Clergy; and that it ≈øhall and may be lawful to, and for the Supreme Court of Judicature of this Colony, or the Courts of Oyer and Terminer, or General Goal delivery, for the re≈øpective Counties afore≈øaid, to award Execution again≈øt ≈øuch Offender or Offenders, ≈øo indicted for a capital Offence, perpetrated after the pa≈ø≈øing of this Act, in ≈øuch Manner as if He or They had been convicted or attainted in the ≈øaid Supreme Courts of Judicature, or before ≈øuch Courts of Oyer and Terminer, or General Goal Delivery re≈øpectively: And if any Offender, being indicted for a le≈ø≈øer Offence, under the Degree of Felony, ≈øhall not ≈øurrender him≈øelf within the Time fixed by ≈øuch Order, and after ≈øuch Notice as afore≈øaid, he ≈øhall thence forth be deemed guilty of the Offence for which he may be charged by ≈øuch Indictment; and it ≈øhall be lawful for the Court wherein ≈øuch Indictment is found, to proceed to pronounce ≈øuch Judgment again≈øt the Offender as might lawfully be done if he was pre≈øent in Court, and convicted in the ordinary Cour≈øe of
the Law, of the Crime wherewith he ≈øhall ≈øo ≈øtand charged as afore≈øaid. Provided always,

"7. And be it further enacted, by the ≈øame Authority afore≈øaid, That if any Per≈øon ≈øo neglecting to ≈øurrender him≈øelf as afore≈øaid, within the ≈øaid Seventy Days, ≈øhall, at any Time after, ≈øurrender him≈øelf to the Sheriff of the Cities of New-York or Albany, or of the Counties of Dutche≈øs or We≈øt-Che≈øter, (who are to receive, and ≈øafely keep ≈øuch Offenders) and being actually in Cu≈øtody, exhibited rea≈øonable Proof, to the Satisfaction of the Judges of the Supreme Court of this Colony, or either of them, that he was not within either of the ≈øaid Counties of Albany or Charlotte, or within either of the Counties of Cumberland or Glouce≈øter, at any Time after the Publication and Notices above directed, and before ≈øuch Surrender of him≈øelf as afore≈øaid; then ≈øuch Judge before whom ≈øuch Proof is made, ≈øhall forthwith notify the ≈øame in Writing, to the Sheriff to whom any Warrant of Execution for the Executing ≈øuch Offender, or any other Proce≈øs for any le≈ø≈øer Puni≈øhment, hath been, or may be i≈ø≈øued; and thenceforth ≈øuch Pri≈øoner or Offender ≈øhall not be liable to ≈øuffer Death, or any other Puni≈øhment for not ≈øurrendering him≈øelf.‚ÄîProvided al≈øo, that nothing in this Act contained, ≈øhall be con≈øtrued to exempt any Offender, ≈øo ≈øurrendering him≈øelf, after the Seventy Days, as afore≈øaid, from any Puni≈øhment to which he may be liable for any other Crime than for not ≈øurrendering him≈øelf within the Seventy Days, as afore≈øaid, nor to deprive any Per≈øon who
≈øhall ≈øo ≈øurrender him≈øelf within the Seventy Days, from being bailed, in Ca≈øes where he ≈øhall be bailable by Law; any Thing herein contained to the Contrary thereof, in any Wi≈øe notwith≈øtanding.

"8. And be it further enacted, by the ≈øame Authority afore≈øaid, That all and every Per≈øon and Per≈øons who ≈øhall, after the Expiration of the Time to be appointed as afore≈øaid, for the Surrender of the re≈øpective Offenders herein before named, harbour, receive, conceal, abet, or ≈øuccour ≈øuch Offender, or Offenders, knowing him or them to have been required to ≈øurrender him or them≈øelves, by ≈øuch Order or Orders as afore≈øaid, and not to have ≈øurrendered pur≈øuant thereto, ≈øhall upon Conviction thereof in due Form of Law, ≈øuffer the ≈øame Pains and Penalties as are by this Act inflicted on tho≈øe who ≈øhall continue together to the Number of Three or more, after they ≈øhall be commanded to depart to their Habitation, or lawful Bu≈øine≈øs by Proclamation as afore≈øaid.

"9. AND WHEREAS the ≈øaid County of Charlotte, hath but lately been ≈øet off from the ≈øaid County of Albany, and there is yet no Goal or Court-Hou≈øe erected within the ≈øame; and a great Part of the ≈øaid County being involved in a State of Anarchy & Confu≈øion by Rea≈øon of the violent Proceedings of the afore≈øaid riotous and di≈øorderly People, from whence it mu≈øt at pre≈øent be extremely difficult if not impracticable, to bring Offenders to Ju≈øtice within the ≈øaid County:

Be it therefore further Enacted by the Authority
afore≈øaid, That all Trea≈øons, Felonies, Crimes, Mi≈ødemeanors & Offences what≈øoever, at any Time heretofore committed or perpetrated, or hereafter to be committed or perpetrated within the ≈øaid County of Charlotte, ≈øhall and may be proceeded again≈øt and pre≈øented by any Grand Jury for the County of Albany from Time to Time to be impanelled and ≈øworn at any Court or criminal Juri≈ødiction to be held in and for the ≈øaid County of Albany, who ≈øhall and may charge any of the ≈øaid Offences to have been committed in any Part of the ≈øaid County of Charlotte, and all Indictments ≈øo found by them ≈øhall be adjudged to be good and valid, notwith≈øtanding that the Place of perpetrating any of the ≈øaid Offences be in the ≈øaid Indictments alledged to be out of the ≈øaid County of Albany; and all ≈øuch Offences & Offenders, which ≈øhall be pre≈øented or indicted as afore≈øaid, ≈øhall and may be tried within the County of Albany, and by a Jury thereof, and there heard, determined, and puni≈øhed in the ≈øame Manner and Form as if ≈øuch Trea≈øon, Felony, Crime, Mi≈ødemeanor, or Offence, had ari≈øen and been perpetrated within the ≈øaid County of Albany.

"10. Provided always, And be it further Enacted, That if at any Time hereafter the Ju≈øtices to be appointed for holding Courts of Oyer and Terminer, and General Goal Delivery, for the ≈øaid County of Charlotte, in Ca≈øes cognizable before them; or the Ju≈øtices of the General Se≈ø≈øion of the Peace for the ≈øaid County of Charlotte, in Ca≈øes cognizable before them, ≈øhall conceive that any Pri≈øoner or Offender may be ≈øafely brought to
Ju≈øtice within, and by a Jury of the ≈øaid County of Charlotte, that then it ≈øhall and may be lawful to and for each of the ≈øaid Courts re≈øpectively, to proceed again≈øt, and try ≈øuch Pri≈øoner or Offender, having lawful Cognizance of his Cau≈øe within and by a Jury of the ≈øaid County of Charlotte, and him there to acquit or to Sentence, condemn, and puni≈øh as the Law directs; any thing in this Act to the contrary thereof notwith≈øtanding.

"11. AND be it further Enacted, by the Authority afore≈øaid, That this Act ≈øhall be publickly read in every Court of General Se≈ø≈øions of the Peace, to be held in each of the ≈øaid Counties of Albany, and Charlotte, re≈øpectively.

"12. AND be it further Enacted, by the Authority afore≈øaid; That this Act ≈øhall remain and continue in full Force and Effect, from the pa≈ø≈øing thereof, until the fir≈øt Day of January, which will be in the Year of Our Lord, One Thou≈øand, Seven Hundred, and Seventy Six."

div.head: From the New-Hamp≈øhire Gazette, No. 915. REMARKS, &c. on ≈øome late Laws, pa≈ø≈øed in New-York.
div.p:
HIS Excellency Governor Tryon in Conformity to the Addre≈ø≈øes of the General A≈ø≈øembly of the Colony of New-York, having on the 9th Day of March 1774, with the Advice of his Council, i≈ø≈øued his Proclamation, offering therein large Sums of Money, for the Purpo≈øe of apprehending and
impri≈øoning the following Per≈øons, viz. Ethan Alten, Seth Warner, Remember Baker, Robert Cochran, Peleg Sunderland, Silvanus Brown, James Breakenridge, and John Smith.

AND whereas, his Excellency the Governor, by the ≈øame Proclamation, hath ≈øtrictly enjoined and commanded all Magi≈øtrates, Ju≈øtices of the Peace, Sheriffs, and other civil Officers of the Counties of Albany and Charlotte, to be active and vigilant in apprehending, and impri≈øoning the Per≈øons above named; and we the afore≈øaid Per≈øons, who have hereunto ≈øub≈øcribed, being con≈øcious that our Cau≈øe is good and equitable, in the Sight of GOD, and all unprejudiced and hone≈øt Men, are determined at all Events, to maintain, and defend the ≈øame, 'till his Maje≈øty's Plea≈øure ≈øhall be known, concerning the Validity of the New-Hamp≈øhire Grants.‚ÄîAnd we now proclaim to the Public, not only for Our≈øelves, but for the New-Hamp≈øhire Grantees, and Occupants in general; that the Spring and moving Cau≈øe of our Oppo≈øition to the Government of New-York, was Self-Pre≈øervation, viz. Fir≈øtly, the Pre≈øervation and maintaining of our Property: And Secondly, ≈øince that Government is ≈øo incen≈øed again≈øt us, therefore it ≈øtands us in Hand to defend our Lives; for it appears, by a late Set of Laws pa≈ø≈øed by the Legi≈ølature thereof, that the Lives, and Property of the New-Hamp≈øhire Settlers are manife≈øtly ≈øtruck at; but, that the Public may rightly under≈øtand the E≈ø≈øence of the Controver≈øy, we now proclaim to tho≈øe Law-Givers, and to the World,
that if the New-York Patentees will remove their Patents that have been ≈øub≈øequently lapped and laid on the New-Hamp≈øhire Charters, and quiet us in our Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, agreeable to his Maje≈øty's directions, and ≈øu≈øpend tho≈øe criminal Pro≈øecutions again≈øt us, for being Rioters (as we are unju≈øtly denominated) then will our Settlers be orderly and ≈øubmi≈ø≈øive Subjects to Government; but be it known to that de≈øpotic Fraternity of Law-Makers, and Law-Breakers, that we will not be fooled or frighted out of our Property; they have broke over his Maje≈øty's expre≈øs Prohibitions, in patenting tho≈øe Lands, and when they act in Conformity to the regal Authority of Great-Britain, it will be ≈øoon enough for us to obey them. It is well known by all wi≈øe and ≈øen≈øible Per≈øons in the neighbouring Governments, (that have animadverted on the Controver≈øy) that their pretended Zeal for good Order and Government, is fallacious, and that they aim at the Lands and Labours of the Grantees and Settlers afore≈øaid: and that they ≈øubvert the good and whole≈øome Laws of the Realm, to corroborate with, and bring about their vile and mercenary Purpo≈øes.

AND, ina≈ømuch as the Malignity of their Di≈øpo≈øition towards us, hath flamed to an immea≈øurable and murtherous Degree, they have in their new-fangled Laws, calculated for the meridian of the New-Hamp≈øhire Grants, pa≈ø≈øed the 9th of March, 1774; ≈øo calculated them, as to corre≈øpond with the depravedne≈øs of their Minds and Morals; in them Laws, they have exhibited their
genuine Pictures. The Emblems of their in≈øatiable, avaricious, overbearing, inhuman, barbarous, and blood-guiltine≈øs of Di≈øpo≈øition and Intention is therein portraited in that tran≈øparent Image of them≈øelves, which cannot fail to be a Blot, and an infamous Reproach to them, to Po≈øterity.‚ÄîWe cannot ≈øuppo≈øe that every of his Maje≈øty's Council, or that all the Members of the General A≈ø≈øembly were active in pa≈ø≈øing ≈øo bloody and uncon≈øtitutional a Set of Laws; undoubtedly, ≈øome of them di≈øapproved thereof; and it is altogether po≈ø≈øible, that many that were active in making the Law, were impo≈øed upon by fal≈øe Repre≈øentations, and acted under mi≈øtaken Views of doing Honour to Government; but be this as it will, it appears that there was a Majority. And it has been too much the Ca≈øe with that Government, for a Number of de≈øigning Schemers, and Land-Jockeys, to rule the ≈øame. Let us take a View of their former narrow and circum≈øcribed Boundaries, and how, by Legerdemain, Bribery and Deceptions of one Sort or other, they have extended their Domain far and wide; they have wrangled with, and encroached on all their neighbouring Governments, and have u≈øed all Manner of Deceit and Fraud to accompli≈øh their De≈øigns: Their Tenants groan under their U≈øury and Oppre≈ø≈øion; and they have gained, as well as merited the Di≈øapprobation and Abhorrence of their Neighbours, and the innocent Blood they have already ≈øhed, calls for Heaven's Vengeance on their guilty Heads; and if they ≈øhould come forth in arms again≈øt us, thou≈øands of their injured
and di≈ø≈øatisfied Neighbours in the ≈øeveral Governments, will join with us, to cut off, and extirpate ≈øuch an execrable Race from the Face of the Earth!

THIS Piece is not ≈øuppo≈øed to contain a full An≈øwer to the new con≈øtructed Set of Laws afore≈øaid; for ≈øuch a large TWO-YEAR OLD, hath never before been ≈øeen in America, it being of an enormous and mon≈øtrous Birth; nor is it ≈øuppo≈øed to give the Legi≈ølators their full Characters: But ≈øo much, and a little more may ≈øuffice for the pre≈øent. To quote the Laws, and make Remarks thereon, would be Matter ≈øufficient for a Volume: However, we will yet make ≈øome few ≈øhort Ob≈øervations.
1≈øt, NEGATIVELY, it is not a Law for the Province of New-York in general, but,

2d, POSITIVELY, it is a Law but for Part of the Counties of Charlotte, and Albany; viz. Such Parts thereof, as are covered with the New-Hamp≈øhire CHARTERS, and it is well known tho≈øe Grants compo≈øe but a minor Part of the Inhabitants of the ≈øaid Province; and we have no Repre≈øentative in that A≈ø≈øembly: The fir≈øt Knowledge we had of ≈øaid Laws, was the Completion of them; which informed us, that if we a≈ø≈øembled, Three or more of us together, to oppo≈øe (that which they call legal) Authority, we ≈øhall be adjudged Felons, and ≈øuffer the Pains of Death; and that ≈øame Fraternity of Plotters knew, as well as we, and the generality of the People in the adjacent Colonies, that they have for a Number
of Years la≈øt pa≈øt, endeavoured to exerci≈øe ≈øuch a Cour≈øe of what they call Law, that had they not been oppo≈øed by the People of the≈øe Grants (called the MOB) in the executing the ≈øame, they would before this Time, have been in Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of that Territory, for which the Laws afore≈øaid are calculated. Therefore the Ca≈øe ≈øtands thus: If we oppo≈øe civil Officers, in taking Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of our Farms, we are, by the≈øe Laws, denominated Felons; or if we defend our Neighbours, who have been indicted Rioters, only for defending our Property; we are likewi≈øe adjudged Felons. In fine, every Oppo≈øition to their monarchial Government is deemed Felony, and at the End of every ≈øuch Sentence there is the Word DEATH! And the ≈øame Laws further impower the re≈øpective Judges, provided any Per≈øons, to the Number of Three, or more, that ≈øhall oppo≈øe any Magi≈øtrate, or other civil Officer, and be not taken, that after a legal Warning of Seventy Days, if they do not come and yield them≈øelves up to certain Officers appointed for the Purpo≈øe of ≈øecuring them; then it ≈øhall be lawful for the Judges afore≈øaid, to award Execution of DEATH, the ≈øame as tho' he or they had been convicted or attainted before a proper Court of Judicature, &c. The candid Reader will doubtle≈øs ob≈øerve, that the diabolical De≈øign of this Law, is to obtain Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the New-Hamp≈øhire Grants, or to make the People that defend them Out-Laws, and ≈øo kill them whenever they can catch them.

THOSE bloody Law-Givers know we are nece≈ø≈øitated
to oppo≈øe their Execution of Law, where it points directly at our Property, or give up the ≈øame: But there is one Thing is Matter of Con≈øolation to us, viz. that printed Sentences of Death will not kill us when we are at a Di≈øtance; and if the Executioners approach us, they will be as likely to fall Victims to Death as we: And that Per≈øon, or Country of Per≈øons, are Cowards indeed, if they cannot as manfully fight for their Liberty, Property and Life, as Villains can to deprive them thereof.

THE New-York Schemers accu≈øe us with many Things, Part of which are true, and Part not.‚ÄîWith Re≈øpect to re≈øcuing Pri≈øoners for Debt, it is fal≈øe. As to a≈ø≈øuming judicial Powers, we have not, except a well-regulated Combination of the People to defend their ju≈øt Rights, may be called ≈øo. As to forming our≈øelves into Military Order, and a≈ø≈øuming Military Commands, the New-York Po≈ø≈øies, and Military Preparations, Oppre≈ø≈øions, &c. obliged us to it. Probably Me≈ø≈ø. Duane, Kemp, and Banyer, of New-York, will not di≈øcommend us for ≈øo expedient a Preparation; more e≈øpecially ≈øince the Decrees of the 9th of March, are yet to be put in Execution: And we flatter our≈øelves, upon Occa≈øion, we can mu≈øter as good a Regiment of Mark's-men and Scalpers, as America can afford; and we now give the Gentlemen above-named, together with Mr. Bru≈øh, and Col. Ten Broeck, and, in fine, all the Land-Jobbers of New-York, an Invitation to come and view the Dexterity of our Regiment; and we cannot think of a better Time
for that Purpo≈øe, than when the Executioners come to kill ≈øome or all of us, by Virtue of the Authority their Judges have lately received to award and Sentence us to Death in our Ab≈øence. There is ≈øtill one more notable Complaint again≈øt us, viz. That we have in≈øulted and menaced ≈øeveral Magi≈øtrates, and other civil Officers, ≈øo that they dare not execute their re≈øpective Functions: This is true, ≈øo far as it relates to the Magi≈øtrates. But the Public ≈øhould be informed, what the Functions of tho≈øe Magi≈øtrates are: They are commi≈ø≈øioned for the ≈øole Purpo≈øe of doing us all the Harm and Mi≈øchief they po≈ø≈øibly can, through their Admini≈øtration and Influence; and that they might be ≈øub≈øervient to the wicked De≈øigns of the New-York Schemers. The≈øe are their Functions; and the Public need no further Proof than the Con≈øideration that they are the Tools of tho≈øe extravagant Law-Makers; and it mu≈øt be owned, they acted with great Judgment, in chu≈øing the mo≈øt infernal In≈øtruments for their Purpo≈øe.

DRACO, the Athenian Lawgiver, cau≈øed a Number of Laws (in many Re≈øpects analogous to tho≈øe we have been ≈øpeaking of) to be written in Blood. But our modern Draco's determine to have their's verified in Blood. They well know we ≈øhall more than Three, nay, more than Three Times Three Hundred, a≈ø≈øemble together, if Need be, to maintain our common Cau≈øe, till his Maje≈øty determines who ≈øhall be and remain the Owners of the Land in Conte≈øt. "Wilt not thou po≈ø≈øe≈øs that which Chemoth, thy God giveth thee to po≈ø≈øe≈øs?" So will we
po≈ø≈øe≈øs that which the Lord our God (and King) giveth us to po≈ø≈øe≈øs.
AND la≈øtly, we addre≈øs our≈øelves to the People of the Counties of Albany and Charlotte, which inhabit to the We≈øtward of, and are ≈øituated contiguous to the New-Hamp≈øhire Grants.

GENTLEMEN, FRIENDS AND NEIGHBOURS, PROVIDENCE having allotted and fixed the Bounds of our Habitations in the ≈øame Vicinity, which, together with the Intercour≈øe of Trade and Commerce, hath formed an almo≈øt univer≈øal Acquaintance and Tie of Friend≈øhip between us, and hath laid ≈øuch a Foundation of Knowledge, that your People in general cannot but be ≈øen≈øible that the Title of our Land is in Reality the Bone of Contention, and that as a People, we behave our≈øelves orderly; and are indu≈øtrious, and hone≈øtly di≈øpo≈øed; and pay ju≈øt Deference to Order and good Government; and that we mean no more by that which is called the MOB, but to defend our ju≈øt Rights and Properties. We appeal to the Gentlemen Merchants, to inform whether our People in general, do not exert them≈øelves to pay their ju≈øt Debts; and whether ever they have been hindered by the Country's MOB, in the Collection of their Dues. But as the Magi≈øtrates, Sheriffs, Under-Sheriffs, Coroners, and Con≈øtables of the re≈øpective Counties that hold their Po≈øts of Honor and Profit under our bitter Enemies, we have a Jealou≈øy, that ≈øome of them may be induced (to
recommend them≈øelves to tho≈øe on whom they are dependant, and for the Wages of unrighteou≈øne≈øs, offered by Proclamation) to pre≈øume to apprehend ≈øome of us, or our Friends: We therefore adverti≈øe ≈øuch Officers, and all Per≈øons what≈øoever, that we are re≈øolved to inflict immediate Death on whom≈øoever may attempt the ≈øame: And provided any of us or our Party ≈øhall be taken, and we have not Notice ≈øufficient to relieve them, or whether we relieve them or not, we are re≈øolved to ≈øurround ≈øuch Per≈øon or Per≈øons, whether at his or their own Hou≈øe or Hou≈øes, or any where that we can find him or them, and ≈øhoot ≈øuch Per≈øon or Per≈øons dead. And further more, that we will kill and de≈øtroy any Per≈øon or Per≈øons whom≈øoever, that ≈øhall pre≈øume to be acce≈ø≈øary, aiding or a≈ø≈øi≈øting in taking any of us as afore≈øaid; for by the≈øe Pre≈øents we give any ≈øuch di≈øpo≈øed Per≈øon or Per≈øons to under≈øtand, that, altho' they have a Licence by the Law afore≈øaid, to kill us; and an "Indemnification" for ≈øuch Murther from the ≈øame Authority; yet they have no Indemnification for ≈øo doing, from the GREEN MOUNTAIN BOYS; for our Lives, Liberties and Properties are as verily precious to us, as to any of the King's Subjects; and we are as loyal to his Maje≈øty or his Government, as any Subjects in the Province: But if the Governmental Authority of New-York will Judge in their own Ca≈øe, and act in Oppo≈øition to that of Great-Britain, and in≈øi≈øt upon killing us to take po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of our "Vineyards" come on, we are ready for a Game of Scalping with them; for our mar≈øhal Spirits glow with Bitter
Indignation, and con≈øumate Fury to Bla≈øt their Infernal Projections.

"IT may be the Reader, not having ≈øeen the Law referred to in this Piece, and not being thoroughly acquainted with the long and ≈øpirited Conflict that hath ≈øub≈øi≈øted between the Claimants under New-Hamp≈øhire and New-York, nor of the Progre≈ø≈øive, Arbitrary and Monopolizing di≈øpo≈øition of the Court Party of the latter of tho≈øe Provinces; may be apt to imagine that the Spirit of this Writing is too ≈øevere, ina≈ømuch as it De≈øtines whoever pre≈øumes to take us as Felons or Rioters, to immediate Death; but let the Wi≈øe con≈øider the State of the Cau≈øe.

1. PROVIDED we on our Part be taken, we have by them Laws the Sentence of Death already pronounced again≈øt us, on Provi≈øo more than Three of us a≈ø≈øemble together to maintain and defend our Property, till his Maje≈øty determines the Controver≈øy. And,

2. MAY it be con≈øidered, that the Legi≈ølative Authority of the Province of New-York had no con≈øtitutional Right or Power to make ≈øuch Laws, and con≈øequently that they are Null and Void, from the Nature and Energy of the Engli≈øh Con≈øtitution; therefore as they merit no Place among the Laws of the Realm of Great-Britain, but are the arbitrary League and Combination of our bitter and mercile≈øs Enemies, who, to obtain our Property, have inhumanly, barbarou≈øly, and maliciou≈øly,
under the ≈øpecious and hypocritical Pretence of legal Authority, and Veneration for Order and Government, have laid a Snare for our Lives. Can the Public cen≈øure us for exerting Our≈øelves nervou≈øly to pre≈øerve our Lives in ≈øo critical a Situation? For by the Laws of the Province, into which we are unfortunately fallen, we cannot be protected in either Property or Life, except we give up the Former to ≈øecure the Latter; ≈øo we are re≈øolved to maintain both, or to hazard or loo≈øe both.

FROM hence follows a nece≈ø≈øary Inference, That ina≈ømuch as our Property, nay our Lives, cannot be protected (but manife≈øtly ≈øtruck at) by the highe≈øt Authority in the Province to which we at pre≈øent belong; therefore in the Interim, while his Maje≈øty is determining the Controver≈øy, and till he ≈øhall interpo≈øe his Royal Authory, and ≈øubject the Authority above≈øaid to their Duty, or re-annex the Di≈øtrict of di≈øputed Lands to the Province of New-Hamp≈øhire, or ≈øome Way in his great Wi≈ødom and Fatherly Clemency, put the di≈øtre≈ø≈øed Settlers under New-Hamp≈øhire, on an equal Footing with our Brother Subjects in his Realm; we are under Nece≈ø≈øity of re≈øi≈øting, even unto Blood, every Per≈øon who may attempt to take us as Felons or Rioters as afore≈øaid; for in this Ca≈øe it is not re≈øi≈øting Law, but only oppo≈øing Force by Force; therefore ina≈ømuch as by the Oppre≈ø≈øions afore≈øaid, the New-Hamp≈øhire Settlers are reduced to the di≈øagreeable State of Anarchy and Confu≈øion; in which State we hope for Wi≈ødom, Patience and Fortitude, till
the happy Hour his Maje≈øty ≈øhall graciou≈øly be plea≈øed to re≈øtore us to the Privileges of Engli≈øhmen.

closer.signed:
Signed per
ETHAN ALLEN,
SETH WARNER,
REMEMBER BAKER,
ROBERT COCKRAN,
PELEG SUNDERLAND,
JOHN SMITH,
SILVANUS BROWN.

postscript.p: N. B. WHEREAS Mr. James Breakenridge, hath the Honour to be enroled a Rioter with us, we can a≈ø≈øure the Public that this worthy Gentleman hath never been concerned with us in any Mob what≈øoever; but that he hath always relied on a good Providence, and the regal Authority of Great-Britain for the Confirmation of the New-Hamp≈øhire Charter; exclu≈øive of all forcible Mea≈øures what≈øoever.

lg.l: St. Paul was ≈øent to hear his Doom;
But Roman Laws in a criminal Ca≈øe,
Mu≈øt have the Accu≈øer Face to Face;
Or Cae≈øar gives a flat Denial.‚Äî
But here's a Law made now of late;
Which de≈øtines Men to awful Fate,
And Hangs and Damns without a Trial.
Which made me view all Nature through,
To find a Law where Men were ti'd,
By legal Act which doth exact
Then down I took the ≈øacred Book,
But could not find one of this kind,

closer.signed: T. R.

div.p: IN order to exhibit a more full Narrative of the real State of the Controver≈øy afore≈øaid, it is thought Nece≈ø≈øary here to In≈øert ≈øundry Letters from Governor Tryon to the Inhabitants of Bennington and the adjacent Country, and their An≈øwers thereto, as they were publi≈øhed in ≈øundry public News-Papers; which will ≈øerve to open to View the antecedent State, and Progre≈ø≈øion of the Controver≈øy, as far back as the Year 1772, and Reflect Light on ≈øo important a Cau≈øe.

div.head: From the CONNECTICUT COURANT, No. 394.
div.opener:
New-York,
19th May, 1772.
ON HIS MAJESTY'S SERVICE, To the Rev. Mr. Dewey, and the Inhabitants of Bennington, and the adjacent Country, on the Ea≈øt Side of Hud≈øon's River.
div.p:
THE many violent and illegal Acts you have lately committed again≈øt the Peace and good Order of this Province, of which I have had frequent Proofs and Informations, at the ≈øame Time that they are not only a Reproach to your≈øelves, but dangerous and injurous to your Families and Intere≈øts, cannot fail of being highly offen≈øive to your Sovereign. You may depend a Per≈øeverance in your Di≈øobediance to, and Violations of the Laws
of your Country mu≈øt ≈øoon draw forth again≈øt you the Exertions of the Powers of Government. However, being ≈øincerely di≈øirous on my Part, to avoid compul≈øive Mea≈øures, while lenient Methods may prove ≈øucce≈øsful; I e≈øteem it my Duty to invite you to lay before this Government the Cau≈øes of your illegal Proceedings; and it is with the Concurrence and Advice of his Maje≈øty's Council that I ≈øend you this Invitation, who, with „Äà‚óä„Äâ are di≈øpo≈øed to examine into the Grounds of your Behaviour and Di≈øcontent with Deliberation and Candor, and as far as in us lies, to give ≈øuch Relief as the Nature of your Situation and Circum≈øtances will ju≈øtify. That there may be no Ob≈øtruction to your laying before me in Council, as ≈øoon as po≈ø≈øible, a fair Repre≈øentation of your Conduct, I do hereby engage full Security and Protection to any Per≈øons whom you ≈øhall choo≈øe to ≈øend on this Bu≈øine≈øs to New-York, from the Time they leave their Homes to the Time of their Return, except Robert Cockran, as al≈øo Allen, Baker, and Sevil, mentioned in my Proclamation of the 9th of December la≈øt, and Seth Warner, who≈øe audacious Behaviour to a Civil Magi≈øtrate, has ≈øubjected him to the Penalties of the Laws of his Country. 'I am told Mr. William Dewey, a Mini≈øter of the Go≈øpel, James Breakenridge, and Mr. Fay, are Per≈øons in who≈øe Judgment you have much Confidence; I ≈øhould therefore think they would be your proper Me≈ø≈øengers on a Bu≈øine≈øs in which you are ≈øo deeply concerned, e≈øpecially Mr. Dewey, who has been favourably repre≈øented here ≈øince my Appointment to this Government. His Maje≈øty's Secretary of State has ≈øignified to me that the King
has finally fixed Connecticut River to be the e≈øtabli≈øhed Juri≈ødiction between the Government of New-York and New-Hamp≈øhire.

"This Circum≈øtance I mention that you may not be mi≈øled or deceived by a Per≈øwa≈øion, that that Part of the Country you inhabit, will ever be annexed to the Government of New-Hamp≈øhire. I have this farther Motivefor mentioning the King's final Deci≈øion, that by your receiving this Authority of your being in the Government of New-York, I am hopeful your future Conduct will ju≈øtify me in a≈ø≈øuring his Maje≈øty of your dutiful Obedience to his royal Determination. I flatter my≈øelf you will chearfully improve this final Offer of reconciling your≈øelves to this Government. I am your Friend,

closer.signed: W. TRYON.

div.opener:
Bennington,
5th June, 1772.
To his Excellency, WILLIAM TRYON, ESQUIRE, &c.
div.p: WE his Maje≈øty's leige and loyal Subjects of the Province of New-York, having received your particular Favour of the 19th Day of May la≈øt, reque≈øting the Inhabitants of Bennington, and the adjacent Country on the Ea≈øt Side of Hud≈øon's River, to lay before your Excellency and Council, the Cau≈øe of our Di≈øcontent and Behaviour, do now expre≈øs our Satisfaction in having this very Opportunity to acquaint your Excellency,

"FIRST, That we hold the Fee and Property of the Lands we are ≈øettled on, and in Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of, by Virtue of Grants from their Maje≈øties George the Second and Third, &c. which Lands at the Time of thus being granted, was reputed to be within the Juri≈ødiction of the Province of New-Hamp≈øhire, until the Year 1764, when ≈øome of your Excellency's now Subjects had by ≈øome Mea≈øures obtained his Maje≈øty's Plea≈øure for Alteration of Juri≈ødiction-line between the Provinces of New-Hamp≈øhire and New-York; ≈øince this, ≈øundry Grants have been made by tho≈øe in the Admini≈øtration of Government in the ≈øaid Province of New-York, on the very Land before granted by their Maje≈øties to us, as though the Fee of the Land and Property was altered with Juri≈ødiction, which we ≈øuppo≈øe was not. The Mea≈øures taken to di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈øs us of tho≈øe Lands by repeated Writs of Ejectments, Suits at Law, Rejectment of Proof from authentic Records, refu≈øing a ≈øuitable Time and Opportunity for Collection of Evidence to ≈øupport and vindicate our Cau≈øe, contrary, (as we ≈øuppo≈øe) to the u≈øual Cu≈øtoms of the Law of the Province, ≈øeem to be the Grounds of our Di≈øcontent, and that illegal and uncon≈øtitutional Method of Proceeding in Indicting ≈øundry per≈øons who are bound by the Law of Self and Family Pre≈øervation to maintain their Liberty and Properties; the U≈øage of tho≈øe intreaguers that would Monopolize our Intere≈øts to them≈øelves by ≈øuch irregular Steps.‚Äî

"Their Methods of breaking by Violence, Hou≈øes for Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and to obtain tho≈øe whom they are plea≈øed to denominate riotous, tumultuous
and di≈øorderly, their firing on tho≈øe People, and wounding innocent Women and Children, to compa≈øs their De≈øigns, may have occa≈øioned ≈øome very di≈øagreeable and unhappy Di≈øturbances among the Friends of Mr. Remember Baker, re≈øiding on the New-Hamp≈øhire Grants, which we ≈øuppo≈øe your Excellency has been plea≈øed to mention illegal. The foregoing is an exact Account of our hitherto Ideas of the State of the pre≈øent Ca≈øe, and on this Footing we mu≈øt clo≈øely adhere to the maintaining our Property, with a due Submi≈ø≈øion to your Excellency's Juri≈ødiction, and if we ≈øhould, through Ignorance or Inadvertency, have hitherto mi≈øunder≈øtoood either your Excellency, or the Occa≈øion of your Excellency's Reque≈øt, we beg the Favour to be undeceived. The Per≈øons cho≈øen to pre≈øent the≈øe Lines we hope may give your Excellency ≈øome further Satisfaction.

"WE flatter Our≈øelves from the Candor of your Excellency's favourable Letter, that you will be friendly di≈øpo≈øed toward us; and we mo≈øt earne≈øtly pray and be≈øeech your Excellency would a≈ø≈øi≈øt to quiet us in our Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, till his Maje≈øty in his royal Wi≈ødom ≈øhall be graciou≈øly plea≈øed to ≈øettle the Controver≈øy. Should your Excellency Grant this our humble Reque≈øt, our Satisfaction would be inexpre≈ø≈øible.
