"THEREFORE, confidently tru≈øting in your Excellency's Wi≈ødom and Clemency, as Members of your Province, as loyal and ≈øubmi≈ø≈øive Subjects
to his Maje≈øty, we beg Leave to Sub≈øcribe our≈øelves

closer.signed: your Excellency's faithful, obedient, and very humble Servants.

div.trailer: A true Copy of the An≈øwer to Excellency's Letter of the 19th of May la≈øt.

div.opener:
Bennington, 5th June, 1774.
To His EXCELLENCY, WILLIAM TRYON, ESQUIRE, &c. May it plea≈øe your Excellency,
div.p:
WE, His Maje≈øty's loyal Subjects, who≈øe Names are to this Piece affixed, Inhabitants on that Tract of Land, your Excellency di≈øcribes by the Name of Bennington, and the adjacent Country, &c. and who was by your Excellency's Letter of the 19th of May la≈øt, prohibited the Privilege of going to New-York, and per≈øonally vindicate either our≈øelves or Country, before your Excellency, and being put to the Extremity of informing your Excellency by Writing, the Rea≈øon of our Di≈øcontent, and al≈øo of our Behaviour, which we ≈øhall more largely ≈øet forth, than is in the foregoing general An≈øwer to your Excellency's Letter; and al≈øo exhibit more Arguments deduced from Rea≈øon and the Nature of Things, we hope your Excellency will be graciou≈øly plea≈øed to view this our Defence with that Tenderne≈øs and Candor a Gentleman in ≈øo elevated a Station ≈øhould do, and therefore beg Leave to ob≈øerve, that as on the one Hand, no Con≈øideration whatever, ≈øhall induce us to remit in the lea≈øt, of our Loyalty and Gratitude to our mo≈øt gracious Sovereign, nor of a rea≈øonable Submi≈ø≈øion to your
Excellency; ≈øo on the other Hand, no tyrannical Exertions of the Powers of Government, can deter us from a≈ø≈øerting and vindicating our undoubted Rights and Privileges as Engli≈øhmen. We expected an An≈øwer from your Excellency, to our humble Petition to you delivered ≈øoon after your Excellency's Acce≈ø≈øion to the Admini≈øtration of the Government, but for Rea≈øons to us unknown, your Excellency pa≈ø≈øed it by in Silence. However, we chearfully embrace this Opportunity of laying before your Excellency in Council the true State of our Controver≈øy, which we can no otherways do, but by ab≈øorbing our per≈øonal Di≈øtinction into the Community, and general Cau≈øe, to which we have obtained the Character of faithful. We a≈ø≈øure your Excellency that we a≈ø≈øent to your Authority of Juri≈ødiction ina≈ømuch as his Maje≈øty's Proclamation a≈ø≈øures us it is his Will and Plea≈øure we be under the Juri≈ødiction of New-York, and not only now A≈ø≈øent to it, but have ever done the ≈øame, except in In≈øtances where ≈øuch perver≈øe U≈øe has been made thereof, as would di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈øs us of our Property and Country, we are truly de≈øirous, and petitioning his Maje≈øty to re-annex us to the Province of New-Hamp≈øhire. But this is not the Ground of our Di≈øcontent, or at lea≈øt is far from being the principle Ground of it, though it was done ex parte, and we apprehend there were more or le≈øs wrong Repre≈øentations made to his Maje≈øty, to obtain the Juri≈ødiction: However, it is the unrea≈øonable and uncon≈øtitutional Exerci≈øe of it that is the pre≈øent Bone of Contention‚Äîour Properties are all at Stake; this we contend for, as the following known
Facts will demon≈øtrate. A certain number of de≈øigning Men in New-York (and el≈øewhere) procured Patents under the Great Seal of that Province, and tho≈øe Grantees being non-re≈øidents, brought ≈øundry Writs of Ejectment again≈øt the New-Hamp≈øhire Settlers on the ≈øame Land, covered by both Patents as afore≈øaid, and obtained Judgment again≈øt them, and proceeded further and took out Writs of Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and actually di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed ≈øeveral of them by Order of Law, of their Hou≈øes and Farms, leaving them to ≈øuffer the Inclemency of the Weather, bereaved of all the Nece≈ø≈øaries of Life, their new Ma≈øters having monopolized their earthly ALL, to them≈øelves. The≈øe indigent Families having in the fir≈øt Place expended their ≈øeveral Fortunes, in bringing their Farms out of a wilderne≈øs State, into that of fruitful Feilds, Gardens and Orchards; the whole Country con≈øi≈øting of more than Fifteen Hundred Families, was greatly alarm'd at the Event which had already began to take Place, was in the greate≈øt Con≈øternation, each Individual, from the≈øe In≈øtances, reading their own intolerable and univer≈øal De≈øtruction.‚ÄîStill the Writs of Ejectment came thicker and fa≈øter, and univer≈øal Slavery, Poverty and Horror, emblematically appeared in every Countenance.

"THUS, things having come to this Pa≈øs, the Oppre≈ø≈øion was too great for human Nature, under Engli≈øh Con≈øtitution, to grope under, for tho≈øe unparrallelled In≈øtances ≈øtruck an infinitely more terrible Idea, than that of the Exertion of the Powers of Government.

"LAWS and Society-compacts, were made to protect and ≈øecure the Subjects in their peaceable Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions and Properties, and not to ≈øubvert them. No Per≈øon or Community of Per≈øons can be ≈øuppo≈øed to be under any particular Compact or Law, except it pre-≈øuppo≈øeth, that that Law will protect ≈øuch Per≈øon or Community of Per≈øons in his or their Properties, for otherways the Subject would by Law be bound to be acce≈ø≈øary to his own Ruin and De≈øtruction, which is incon≈øi≈øtant with the Law of Self-pre≈øervation; but this Law being natural as well as eternal, can never be abrogated by the Law of Men.

"WE would acquaint your Excellency, that ≈øince our Misfortune of being annexed to the Province of New-York, Law has been rather u≈øed as a Tool (than a Rule of Equity) to cheat us out of the Country, we have made va≈øtly valuable by Labour and Expence of our Fortunes.‚ÄîWe conclude the≈øe Things are yet unknown, or in a great Mea≈øure ≈øo to your Excellency, as your Excellency's Commencement to the Admini≈øtration, hath not been long, and a Set of artful, wicked Men, concealing the Truth from your Excellency, purpo≈øing to make a Booty of us, characterizing us, (≈øpeaking of our Inhabitants in general) as ≈øo many Rioters if not Rebels; and we being a poor People at a great Di≈øtance from your Excellency's Place of Re≈øidence, fatigued in ≈øettling a Wilderne≈øs Country, have little or no Opportunity of acquainting your Excellency of our Greivances, except by one ≈øhort Petition delivered to your Excellency
≈øoon after your fir≈øt taking Admini≈øration‚Äîand as our Cau≈øe is repre≈øented before his Maje≈øty and Council, we did not expect your Excellency to determine the Controver≈øy, nor do we yet expect it. We are ≈øen≈øible tho≈øe Men that ≈øeek our Ruin, thereby to enrich them≈øelves, do by Stratagems of every Kind, repre≈øent us to your Excellency as Breakers of the Peace, and Enemies to the Government; and under this Pretence they hope to catch a Number of the bolde≈øt of our Inhabitants, and puni≈øh them in the New-York Inqui≈øition, with that Severity that the Re≈øidue may be frightened out of both Liberty and Property; for otherways they would ≈øoon be indicted Rioters, and thus under Colour of puni≈øhing Rioters, and a Zeal of Loyalty and Veneration for good Government, rob the Inhabitants of their Country. If we do not oppo≈øe the Sheriff and his Po≈ø≈øy, he takes immediate Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of our Hou≈øes and Farms, if we do, we are immediately indicted Rioters; and when others oppo≈øe Officers in taking ≈øuch their Friends ≈øo indicted, they are al≈øo indicted and ≈øo on, there being no End of Indictment again≈øt us ≈øo long as we Act the bold and manly Part, and ≈øtand by our Liberty.‚Äî

"This is a ≈øhort Sketch of the di≈øingenuous Cunning of Me≈ø≈øieurs Duane, and Kemp, and their A≈ø≈øociates; and it comes to this at la≈øt, that we mu≈øt tamely be di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, or oppo≈øe Officers in taking Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and as a next nece≈ø≈øary Step, oppo≈øe taking of Rioters ≈øo called, or run away like ≈øo many Cowards, and quit our Country to a Number
of cringing, polite Gentlemen who have ideally po≈ø≈øe≈øs'd them≈øelves of it already.

"As to ≈øundry Men who have eloped lately from our Grants, and ≈øled to New-York for Protection, Self-pre≈øervation nece≈ø≈øitated us to treat ≈øome of them roughly; and others, viz. Ebenezer Cowle, and Jonathan Wheat, of Shaft≈øbury, fled to New-York, on Account of their own Guilt, not being hurt or threatened. Would Time permit we could give a rational Account for mo≈øt, or all of our late Conduct towards the≈øe Men. The general Rea≈øon is this, namely, they were a Set of Men that loved them≈øelves, and not their Country, they bu≈øied them≈øelves in planning and a≈ø≈øi≈øting to take Rioters ≈øo called. In fine, they were the Emi≈ø≈øaries of that mercenary Core of Yorkers, and did more in Oppre≈ø≈øing the People, than their prepo≈øterous Benefactors.

"The A≈ø≈øault made upon Mr. Baker at Day break, of the Night of the 22d of March la≈øt, by a Number of Ruffians under the Command of the infamous John Munro, E≈øq was a notorious Riot, and gave Energy and Motion, to the ≈øub≈øequent Acts, your Excellency denominates illegal. This Munro and his bloody Party, by cuting, wounding and maiming, Mr. Baker, his Wife and Children, in ≈øuch an inhuman and Savage Manner, was no le≈øs than proclaiming him≈øelf in a mo≈øt public Manner to be a malicious and bloody Enemy, not only to Mr. Baker, but al≈øo to all tho≈øe Men on our Grants, who manfully adhere to maintaining Liberty
and Property, and ina≈ømuch as the murtherous Villian is alive, he has no Cau≈øe of Complaint‚Äîfor after his A≈ø≈øault upon Mr. Baker, he made another A≈ø≈øault upon Mr. Seth Warner, but not having ≈øo ≈øtrong a Party of Ruffians with him as in his other Expedition, it was not attended with the like Con≈øequences, for Mr. Warner, ≈øtruck his Head with a dull Cutla≈øs, and levelled him to the Ground, but the Blow proved not Mortal, and after this, for his Satisfaction for the Wound, threatened the Lives of a Number of the New-Hamp≈øhire Settlers.‚ÄîYour Excellency will undoubtedly con≈øider as our Opponents have had the Manufactory of the Civil Laws ≈øo much under their Power, that this mercile≈øs Man could not be brought to Ju≈øtice, nor could others among us be ≈øafe any other Way, but by u≈øing him in his own Play, he ≈øet the Example, and enraged the People to mimick him from that natural Principle of ju≈øtice in every Man's own Brea≈øt.

"As to the Perfidious and treacherous Bli≈øs Willoggby, he always pretended to be a Friend of the ≈øaid Baker's, and Baker had ever been truly a Friend of his‚Äîthis Hypocrite, two Days before Baker was taken, made a frivilous Excu≈øe of Bu≈øine≈øs, went to ≈øaid Baker's Hou≈øe, viewed the Strength of it, perceived Baker was ≈øomewhat carele≈øs and ≈øecure, and made Report to the ≈øaid Munro. In fine, Willoggby was the Planner and In≈øtigator of that ≈øavage Cruelty exerci≈øed to ≈øaid Baker, which was perpetrated and brought into Action by the dete≈øtible ≈øaid Munro. But to de≈øi≈øt, as to the
Hi≈øtory of our late tran≈øaction, whether they be all Right or not, we on our Part have a few Arguments & Con≈øiderations more to lay before your Excellency, as to the Cau≈øe of our Di≈øcontent, as well as to the Cau≈øe of our late Actions your Excellency denominates illegal.

"The Alteration of Juri≈ødiction in 1764 could not effect private Property: Surely his Maje≈øty by this Alteration, did not purpo≈øe to take away the per≈øonal Property of a large Number of his loyal Subjects, and transfer it to other Subjects; the Engli≈øh Con≈øtitution will by no Means admit of this, for the transferring or alienation of Property is a ≈øacred Prerogative of the true Owner.‚ÄîKings and Governors cannot intermeddle therewith. Furthermore Your Excellency & Council mu≈øt needs be acquainted that we have a Petition lying before his Maje≈øty and Council, for Redre≈øs of our Grievances. That is an impartial Board; pray why may it not be determined there? For the very indentical Matters in Di≈øpute, are now and for ≈øeveral Years pa≈øt, have been lying before that Court, except the Accu≈øations of Riotou≈øne≈øs, Di≈øorderly, &c. which is improved as a Handle to ≈øubvert Property, and that only.

"FURTHERMORE, in the Time of Sir Henry Moor's Admini≈øtration, his Maje≈øty was plea≈øed to lay the Government of New-York, under ab≈øoluto Prohibition not to grant or patent any of the Lands antecedently granted under the Great Seal of the Province of New-Hamp≈øhire, and Furthermore
forbid the Government to di≈øturb or mole≈øt the Settlers. This rightly under≈øtood, amounts to a Supercedies over the Authority of Common Law, and ab≈øolutely controuls the Cognizance thereof. As to the particular Matters in the Prohibition ≈øet forth, or Matters lying before his Maje≈øty by Petition, the Import of the Prohibition mu≈øt needs be thus, Namely, that his Maje≈øty, by it informs the Government of New-York that he has taken the Controver≈øy to him made known by Petition, under his Royal Con≈øideration, and that, after due Information and Evidence of the State of the Ca≈øe, determines to ≈øettle the Controver≈øy; con≈øequently forbids the Government taking Cognizance thereof; and Common Sen≈øe teaches us that under ≈øuch Prohibition, if a Judgment at Common Law be ≈øuppo≈øed to be valid, it would invalidate the Authority of the Crown, and ≈øubvert and overthrow the Authority of the Kingdom, as it would render the Prohibitions of the Crown perfectly impertinent. Therefore Common Law, in the Ca≈øe before us, is not cloathed with Cognizance of this Ca≈øe, much le≈øs with Authority to di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈øs us; con≈øequently every Party of Men that have with Officers or otherwi≈øe, come into the≈øe Parts to di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈øs us, came in open Defiance and direct Oppo≈øition to his Maje≈øty's Orders and Authority: And tho' they ≈øtile us Rioters, for oppo≈øing them, and ≈øeek to catch and puni≈øh us as ≈øuch, yet in Reality, them≈øelves are the Rioters, the tumultuous, di≈øorderly, ≈øtimulating Faction, or, in fine, the Land-robbers; and every violent Act they have done to compa≈øs their De≈øigns, tho' ever
≈øo much under Pretence of Law, is in Reality a Violation of Law, and an In≈øult on the Con≈øtitution, and Authority of the Crown, as well as to many of us in Per≈øon, who have been great Sufferance by ≈øuch inhuman Exertions of pretended legality of Law.‚ÄîRight, and Wrong, are eternally the ≈øame to all Periods of Time, Places and Nations, and colouring a Crime with a ≈øpecious Pretence of Law, only adds to the Criminality of it; for it ≈øubverts the very De≈øign of Law, pro≈øtituting it to the vile≈øt Purpo≈øes. Can any Man, in the Exerci≈øe of Rea≈øon make him≈øelf believe that a Number of Attornies and other Gentlemen, with all their Tackle of Ornaments, and Compliments, and French Fine≈ø≈øe, together with their boa≈øted Legality of Law, that the≈øe Gentlemen have ju≈øt Right to the Lands Labours and Fortunes of the New-Hamp≈øhire Settlers? Certainly they cannot. Yet this is the Object in View by that mercenary Fraternity.

"WE do not ≈øuppo≈øe, may it plea≈øe your Excellency, we are making Oppo≈øition to a Government, as ≈øuch; it is nothing more than a Party, chiefly carried on by a Number of Gentlemen Attornies (if it be not an Abu≈øe to Gentlemen of Merit to call them ≈øo) who manife≈øt a ≈øurprizing and interprizing Thir≈øt of Avarice after our Country, but for a Collection of ≈øuch Intreaguers, to plan Matters of Influence of a Party, ≈øo as eventually to become Judges in their own Ca≈øe, & thereby cheat us out of our Country, appears to us ≈øo audaciou≈øly unrea≈øonable and tyrannical that we view it with the utmo≈øt Dete≈øtation and Indignation,
and our Brea≈øts glow with a martial Fury to defend our Per≈øons and Fortunes from the Ravages of tho≈øe that would De≈øtroy us; but not again≈øt your Excellency's Per≈øon or Government.

"WE are fully per≈øwaded your Excellency's Ears have been much abu≈øed by ≈øubtle and de≈øigning Men, for we are informed from credible Authority, your Excellency has lately made Application to your A≈ø≈øembly to rai≈øe an armed Force to ≈øubdue us, but that the Motion was negatived: We apprehend your Excellency views us as oppo≈øing your Excellency's Juri≈ødiction, and that the violent Acts, by us done, was in Rebellion to his Maje≈øty's Authority, or your Excellency had never propo≈øed the ≈øubduing of us; We are morally Certain we can convince your Excellency, that it is not ≈øo; but that on the other Hand Me≈ø≈øieurs Duane, Kemp, and their A≈ø≈øociates are the Aggre≈ø≈øors.

"WE have cho≈øen two Men from among us, viz. Capt. Stephen Fay, and Mr. Jonas Fay, to treat with your Excellency in Per≈øon, who we hope will An≈øwer ≈øuch Queries, and give your Excellency the Satisfaction you hope for.

"We view your Excellency as our Governor and political Father, and hope and expect, from the Sincerity and Candor of your Excellency's Letter, you will be friendly and favourably di≈øpo≈øed towards us, when your Excellency by the≈øe Lines perceive the Grounds of our Di≈øcontent:
For we are Con≈øcious that our Cau≈øe is good, and that it was Oppre≈ø≈øion which has been the Ground of our Di≈øcontent, and that Self-pre≈øervation hath hitherto urged us to the Mea≈øures lately taken. And we now earne≈øtly intreat your Excellency's Aid and A≈ø≈øi≈øtance to quiet us in our Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions and Properties, till his Maje≈øty in his royal Wi≈ødom Settle the Controver≈øy: If your Excellency ≈øhould do this, there would be an End of Riots, ≈øo called, and our Tongues unable to expre≈øs our Gratitude to your Excellency for ≈øuch Protection.
"THEREFORE, relying on your Excellency's great Wi≈ødom and Goodne≈øs, as Members of your Government, his Maje≈øty's loyal and liege Subjects, we ≈øub≈øcribe Our≈øelves

closer.signed:
your Excellency's ever faithful and humble Servants,
ETHAN ALLEN,
SETH WARNER,
REMEMBER BAKER,
ROBERT COCHRAN.

div.head: An Encomium on his Excellency Governor Tryon, and his Maje≈øty's Honourable Council of the Province of New-York.
Copied from the CONNECTICUT COURANT.
div.p:
WHEREAS the Inhabitants of the Lands We≈øt of Connecticut River, who purcha≈øed their Lands of his Maje≈øty's Government of New-Hamp≈øhire, who on the Faith of Government, and full Reliance on the Veracity of Charters under the Great Seal of that Province, have ≈øettled, cultivated, and made great Improvements thereon;
which Tract of Land, in the Year Seventeen Hundred and Sixty-Four, his Maje≈øty was plea≈øed to annex, the Province of New-York. And whereas, ≈øub≈øequent thereto, a Number of mercenary & litigious Gentlemen of the Province (and principally of the City) of New-York, procured Patents under the Great Seal of that Province, & covered ≈øundry Town≈øhips the ≈øame identical Land, antecedently granted under the Great Seal of the Province of New-Hamp≈øhire. And whereas many vexatious Law≈øuits, and clande≈øtine and oppre≈ø≈øive crown Pro≈øecutions, have been craftily, ≈øubtilly, and with a De≈øign to over-awe, abu≈øe, terrify, and impoveri≈øh the ≈øaid Inhabitants, hath been militated, devi≈øed and pro≈øecuted again≈øt them, by the Influence of the Gentlemen afore≈øaid, purpo≈øing by ≈øuch ba≈øe and oppre≈ø≈øive Mea≈øures of Policy, to defraud and wrong the ≈øaid Inhabitants, out of the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion and Property of their Country. And in order to clude & defeat ≈øuch their di≈øingenuous and vicious Policy, the ≈øaid Inhabitants mutually agreed to oppo≈øe New-York Officers, in their Attempts to take Rioters, ≈øo characterized, and take every other requi≈øite, lawful and effectual Method to defend their Property.

"And Matters having come to this, that Ho≈øtility, Revenge and Hatred, had began to put on their bloody, murtherous, and vengful Emblems‚ÄîIn which propitious Hour, his Excellency WILLIAM TRYON, E≈øq Governor of the Province of New-York, ≈øent the ≈øaid Inhabitants a kind, lenient and generous Letter, which breathed forth
rather the Affections of a Father, than a hard-hearted Judge; reque≈øting the ≈øaid Inhabitants to exhibit to him in Council, the Grounds of their Di≈øcontent and Unea≈øine≈øs, and the Cau≈øe of their violent and illegal Proceedings; a≈ø≈øuring them, that they ≈øhould be heard with Candor in the Premi≈øes, and have ≈øuch Relief as the Nature and Circum≈øtances of their Ca≈øe ≈øhould ju≈øtify.

"UPON which the Town of Bennington, and the adjacent Towns, by their Committees, met at Bennington, and ≈øent a written An≈øwer to his Excellency's Letter, informing him of the State of the Controver≈øy, and withal of the Ground of their Unea≈øine≈øs and Di≈øcontent, and the Cau≈øe of their Proceedings; and al≈øo made Choice of Captain Stephen Fay, and Doctor Jonas Fay, of Bennington, to go to New-York, and deliver the written An≈øwer to his Excellency, and further inform him as to the State of Facts, and negotiate the Matter of our Petition; (though not with Power to compleat a Settlement on our Part.) His Excellency received the Agents with Expre≈ø≈øions of Kindne≈øs‚Äîlaid the State of Grievances before His Maje≈øty's honourable Council, who after mature Con≈øideration, determined in the following Words: "The Committee are de≈øirous your Excellency ≈øhould afford the Inhabitants of tho≈øe Town≈øhips, all the Relief in your Power, by ≈øu≈øpending, till his Maje≈øty's Plea≈øure ≈øhall be known, all Pro≈øecutions in behalf of the Crown, on Account of the Crimes with which they ≈øtand charged, by Depo≈øitions before us, and to recommend it to the Owners of the conte≈øted
Lands under Grants from this Province, to put a Stop, during the ≈øame Period, to all civil Suits concerning the Lands in Que≈øtion."

AFTER our Agents received Copies of the Minutes of Council, and al≈øo a Letter from his Excellency, purporting his Approbation and Compliance therewith, they retired to Bennington with great Joy‚Äîwarned a Meeting of that Town and the adjacent Country, which was held on the 15th of July Ultimo; and before a large Auditory of People, the Copy of the Minutes of Council was read, and al≈øo his Excellency's Letter of Compliance to the ≈øame, which defu≈øed univer≈øal Joy through the Country of the New-Hamp≈øhire Grants, and the People were at Strife in doing the mo≈øt exalted Honour to Governor Tryon. And having at Bennington a Cannon, it was di≈øcharged ≈øundry Times in Honour to his Excellency and his Maje≈øty's honourable Council, and after the Report of the Cannon, each ≈øeveral Time, the whole Audience gave a Huzza! in Acclamation, Good-will, Gratitude and vocal Honour to Governor TRYON, and Capt. Warner's Company of GREEN MOUNTAIN-BOYS under Arms, fired three Vollies of ≈ømall Arms, in Concert and Aid of the Glory.

"HIS Maje≈øty's Health, al≈øo a Health to his Excellency, and his Maje≈øty's honourable Council was drank, with full flowing Bowls, and Confu≈øion to all the New-York Land-jobbers, hoping Peace, Liberty and Plenty may abound.

div.head: From the CONNECTICUT COURANT.
His Excellency Governor TRYON'S Letter to the Inhabitants of Bennington, &c.
div.p:
"AT the ≈øame Time I expre≈øs to you my Satisfaction by the Opportunity of Mr. Fay, on the grateful Manner in which you received and accepted the lenient Mea≈øures pre≈øcribed by this Government, for your peaceable Conduct until his Maje≈øty's Plea≈øure ≈øhould be known, re≈øpecting the di≈øputed Claim to Lands within this Government. I cannot conceal from you my high Di≈øplea≈øure at the Breach of Faith and Honor, made by a Body of your People, in di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing ≈øeveral Settlers on Otter Creek, and its Neighbourhood, of their Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, during the very Time the Commi≈ø≈øioners you appointed to attend on me at New-York, were waiting the Determination of Government on your Petition, that you might remain unmole≈øted in your Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, until the King's Plea≈øure be obtained. Such di≈øingenuous and di≈øhonourable Proceedings, I view with great Concern, con≈øidering them as daring In≈øults to Government, a Violation of public Faith, and the Conditions granted to you on Petition. To prevent therefore the fatal Con≈øequence that mu≈øt follow ≈øo manife≈øt a Breach of public Confidence, I am to require your A≈ø≈øi≈øtance, in putting forthwith tho≈øe Families who have been thus di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, into Re-po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of their Lands and Tenements,
in the ≈øame Manner in which they were at the Time Mr. Fay and his Son, waited on me at New-York. Such a Conduct on your Part, will not fail of recommending your Situation to his Maje≈øty, and in≈øure a continuance of my friendly Intentions towards you.

closer.signed: WM. TRYNN.

div.trailer: To the Inhabitants of Bennington, and the adjacent Country.

opener.salute: To His EXCELLENCY. WILLIAM TRYON, ESQUIRE, &c.

div.p:
WE his Maje≈øty's leige and loyal Subjects, Inhabitants of Bennington, and the adjacent Country, have received your Excellency's Letter, of the 11th of Augu≈øt In≈øtant, by which we are inform'd of your Excellency's high Di≈øplea≈øure towards us, by Rea≈øon of a Body of our People's di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing ≈øeveral Settlers on Otter-Creek, and its Neighbourhood, of their Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, during the very Time our Me≈ø≈øengers attended on your Excellency at New-York, and were waiting the Determination of Government, on our Petition, that we might remain unmole≈øted in our Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, till the King's Plea≈øure could be obtained. Your Excellency further informs us, that you Look on our late Proceedings with great Concern, viewing them as daring In≈øults to Government, a Violation
of public Faith, and the Conditions granted to our Petition. We would with proper Submi≈ø≈øion, give your Excellency and Council, a ≈øhort Narrative of Facts, with a few Reflections and Rea≈øons thereon. And,

"FIRST, we would ob≈øerve, That our Me≈ø≈øengers your Excellency ≈øtiles Commi≈ø≈øioners, was not authorized to e≈øtabli≈øh, and compleat Articles of public Faith for their Con≈øtituents. The Bu≈øine≈øs a≈ø≈øign'd them, was to deliver the written Petition, and inform your Excellency and Council of the Facts of the Controver≈øy ≈øub≈øi≈øting, and further negociate and forward the Matter of our Petition, and return to us the Determination of Government, re≈øerving to Our≈øelves the Power of a≈ø≈øenting to, or di≈ø≈øenting therefrom, tho' true it is, when the Articles of amicable Settlement, or Order of Government was read at a public Meeting held at Bennington, on the 15th Day of July Ultimo, the ≈øaid Order and Propo≈øals were univer≈øally complied with by tho≈øe pre≈øent: From which Time we rea≈øonably Compute the Date of public Faith, and ≈øacred Bond of Friend≈øhip, but in the Interim, the Conditions of Faith was forming, and before a Ratification thereof, Mr. Kockburn, a noted Surveyor, unknown (as we ≈øuppo≈øe) to your Excellency, and Council, who, by the Contrivance, Aid and Employ of certain monopolizing Adver≈øaries of our's, took a Tour to the northerly Parts of the New-Hamp≈øhire Grants, to ≈øurvey, and make Locations on our Land. Such Locating we view as a manife≈øt Plan, and Intention
of invading our Property‚Äîthe ≈øame as intrenching round the City, portraits a Siege thereof.

OUR People having Notice of Mr. Kockburn's Intru≈øion on our Borders, rallied a ≈ømall Party, and pur≈øued, and overtook him and his Party, and in their Pur≈øuit, pa≈ø≈øed the Towns of Panton and New-Haven, near the Mouth of Otter Creek; di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed Col. Reed of a Saw-Mill in ≈øaid Panton, which by Force, and without Colour, or even Pretence of Recour≈øe to Law, he had taken from the original Owners and Builders, more than three Years before, and did at that ≈øame Time extend his Force, Terrors and Threats into the Town of New-Haven; who, by the vicious and haughty Aid of Mr. Benzell, the fam'd Engineer, with a Number of A≈ø≈øi≈øtants, under their Command, ≈øo terrified the Inhabitants (which were about twelve in Number) that they left their Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions and Farms to the Conquerers, and e≈øcaped with the Skin of their Teeth, although they had expended large Sums of Money in cutting Roads to, and ≈øettling in that new Country, as well as fatigued and laboured hard in cultivating their Farms: Col. Reed at the ≈øame Time, and with the ≈øame Force, did take Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of one Hundred and Thirty Saw-Logs, and fourteen Thou≈øand Feet of Pine Boards, which Boards were made in the ≈øame Mill, & all lying thereby, all which he converted to his own U≈øe. Not long after, the original Proprietors of the ≈øaid Mill, did re-enter, and take Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion thereof, but was a ≈øecond Time attacked by Col. Reed's Stewart, with a Number of armed Men, under his
(≈øuppo≈øed). In≈øtructions, and by their ≈øuperior Force and Threats, obliged to quit the Premi≈øes again‚Äîall which Tenements, ≈øaid Reed occupied and enjoyed until di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, as your Excellency's Letter complains of.

BUT to return to Kockburn again. Cur Party having taken him as afore≈øaid, brought him to the Town of Ca≈øtleton, near South Bay, where being fir≈øt informed of your Excellency's Clemency as well as that of the honourable Council, in granting the Prayer of our Petition; and in Conformity to the Articles of Settlement agreed on, di≈ømi≈ø≈øed him on honourable Terms.
THIS is a ≈øhort Narrative of Facts, for the Proof of which, ≈øufficient Affidavits can be educed,

WE are apprehen≈øive your Excellency has been hitherto unacquainted with the≈øe Facts, and have therefore exhibited them in this Letter; although it appears ≈øtrange to us, according as your Excellency's own Letter ≈øtates the Matter, that we ≈øhould be ≈øu≈øpected or taxed with violation of public Faith, and that our di≈øingenuous and di≈øhonourable Violation thereof, hath nullified and made void the late amicable Settlement; for at the ≈øame Time your Excellency charges us with breach of Faith, and Settlement, the very Preliminaries of this Faith was not known on our Part, and con≈øequently could not have been complied with, the very Stipulation and Faith ≈øpoken of, did not then exi≈øt, for it mu≈øt be the Meeting of
the Minds of the contracting Parties, which con≈øtitutes ≈øuch Faith and Agreement, and of Cour≈øe cannot be broken before its exi≈øtence.

MR. Kockburn's locating our Lands in the mean Time the Preliminaries of Public Faith were forming, was at lea≈øt as much a Breach of that Faith, as what we are charged with. Nay, according to our Conception of the Matter, more ≈øo; as he made the fir≈øt Movement towards the Inva≈øion of our Property.

SOON after, our Me≈ø≈øengers returned from New-York, and read the Minutes of Council, and your Excellency's Letter of Compliance therewith, to a large Auditory convened at Bennington for that purpo≈øe, compo≈øed of the Inhabitants of that Place, the adjacent Country, and ≈øundry re≈øpectable Gentlemen from the neighbouring Provinces; your Excellency's gracious, wi≈øe, and benevolent Propo≈øals for ≈øettling Unity and Concord, in our Part of the Province, were by tho≈øe pre≈øent, unanimou≈øly applauded, and conceded to; and all po≈ø≈øible public Te≈øtimonies of Honour and Re≈øpect, paid to your Excellency and Council, by ≈øundry Di≈øcharges of Cannon and ≈ømall Arms; your Excellency's Health, long Life, and Pro≈øperity, as well as that of the honourable Council's, was the Toa≈øt; your Name commanded Reverence and E≈øteem, and your Excellency's Per≈øon in particular, became precious in our Eyes.

AND, we do humbly a≈ø≈øure your Excellency we have no Di≈øpo≈øition of Alienation of Affections,
towards you, or knowingly break any Article of Publick Faith.
THERE are two Propo≈øitions, which are the Objects of our Attention.
"FIRSTLY; The Protection and maintaining our Property.
AND, SECONDLY; to u≈øe the greate≈øt Care and Prudence, not to break the Articles of Publick Faith, or in≈øult Governmental Authority.

THESE two Propo≈øitions, we mean ≈øtrictly and religiou≈øly to adhere to. And for the more explicit Knowledge of the Preliminaries and Conditions of Publick Faith and Tru≈øt, we would inform your Excellency and Council, that our Acceptation of tho≈øe Conditions on the Part of New-York, is, that they make no further ≈øettlements or Locations on our Lands, granted under the Great Seal of the Province of New-Hamp≈øhire, until his Maje≈øty's Plea≈øure be obtained, as to the validity of the Grants; although this was not ≈øo fully expre≈ø≈øed, yet we ≈øuppo≈øe it was implied in the Ab≈øtract of the Minutes of Council; if it was not, we pray, your Excellency and Council would undeceive us in that Particular, for if we are deceived in this, then, on this Hypothe≈øis, your Excellency and Council's lenient and friendly Di≈øpo≈øition towards Us, will not for the future, (by us) be viewed as ≈øuch; for ≈øuch Locations and Settlements on our Lands, would be incompatible with Friend≈øhip, and a manife≈øt Infringement
on our Property, which has all along been the Bone of Contention.

THE la≈øt part of your Excellency's Letter to Us, contains a Requirement of our immediate A≈ø≈øi≈øtance in repo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing Col. Reed's Tenants of ≈øaid Tenements. As to this Particular, had your Excellency have known by what Means Col. Reed obtained Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of them Lands and Tenements, undoubtedly your Excellency would not have required our A≈ø≈øi≈øtance in repo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing him; or have viewed with Concern, our di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing him, as a daring In≈øult to Government: For the Ca≈øe rightly under≈øtood, it appears, that his Conduct was a daring In≈øult to Government, and continued Violation for more than three Years, of the Laws, Re≈øtrictions, Regulations, and OEconomy, both of God, and Man; a notorious Breach of the Tenth Command of the Decalogue, which ≈øays, "Thou ≈øhalt not covet, &c." He coveting, did take the Saw-Mill-Logs, Boards, and al≈øo, the Lands, Labours, Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, Farms, Tenements, &c. &c. from the rightful Owners, Proprietors, and fir≈øt Occupants thereof, without a proce≈øs at Law, as afore≈øaid, to their Exclu≈øion from the Premi≈øes more than three Years, all which Time He has been enriching Him≈øelf, by the improvement of their E≈øtates; and, ≈øhould we repo≈ø≈øe≈øs him of the Premi≈øes again, We ≈øhould become Co-Partners with Him, in his Wickedne≈øs. Such an Act we could not reconcile to our own Con≈øciences; it being a parently immoral, and mo≈øt flagrantly Cruel and Unju≈øt.

WHEN your Excellency and Council views the≈øe Facts, and Arguments, we humbly conceive we ≈øhall not be required to repo≈ø≈øe≈øs Colonel Reed of the Premi≈øes: Nor do we expect your Excellency and Council will adjudge us to be Violators of the late Articles of Public Faith: All which with due Submi≈ø≈øion, we refer to your Excellency and Council.

AND, we do now, with due Reverence, a≈øk the Favour of a few Lines, which may certify to us, the Determination of Government, relative to the Particulars litigated in this Paper, and remain your ever faithful and mo≈øt obedient humble Servants.

AT a General Meeting held at Manche≈øter, on the 27th Day of Augu≈øt 1772, by the Committee of the Towns of Bennington, Sunderland, Manche≈øter, Do≈ø≈øeth, Ruport, Pollet, Wells, Poultney, Ca≈øtleton, Pitsford and Rutland; the foregoing An≈øwer to his Excellency's Letter of the 11th In≈øtant, was read to the ≈øaid Committees, and the Vote was called by Mr. Nathan Clark Chairman, whether the ≈øaid An≈øwer be approved of, by the ≈øaid Committees? and it was voted in the Affirmative.

closer.signed: Te≈øt. ETHAN ALLEN, Clerk for ≈øaid Committees.

div.head: ARGUMENTS, Demon≈øtrating that the Property of the Di≈øtrict of LAND afore≈øaid, was conveyed from the CROWN, to the NEW-HAMPSHIRE GRANTEES, by Virtue of their re≈øpective CHARTERS.
SECTION I.
div.p:
AS the Claimants under New-Hamp≈øhire rely on their Charters from that Government as the predicate and ground of their Title to the Property of the Land in Conte≈øt; ≈øo, on the other Hand, the Claimants under New-York, predicate and ground their Title to the ≈øame Land on the Validity of their Patents from New-York: This brings the Point in I≈ø≈øue between the re≈øpective Claimants to this ≈øingle Que≈øtion, namely, Which of the ≈øaid Governments conveyed the Fee of the Land in Conte≈øt? For it is ≈øelf-evident both could not. And upon exploring the Controver≈øy, and animadverting on the Merits of the different Claims, be it which it will that may be allowed to ≈øtand the Te≈øt, and adjudged Valid, it will of Nece≈ø≈øity invalidate the other. In the Di≈øcu≈ø≈øion of this Subject, and ≈øearching into the Merit of the re≈øpective Claims, it is nece≈ø≈øary to in≈øpect into the Validity of the Grant from King CHARLES to the Duke of York, from which Foundation only, the Government
of New-York deduce their Right of patenting the Lands in conte≈øt; yet the Matter of Fact is, that neither the Government of New-York as ≈øuch, or any Individual therein, has ever had any Conveyance of any Land from the Duke of York, nor doth any Landlord or Per≈øon whatever, in the Government hold the Fee or Property of their Land, by Virtue of any Conveyance from the Duke of York; but they hold the Fee of their Lands on a very different Footing, viz. by Conveyance from the Crown; yet, if it be conceded to, that King CHARLES gave to his Brother James Duke of York, the Fee of the Lands We≈øt of Connecticut River, to the Head of Delaware Bay; and allowing the Fee to be ≈øtill ve≈øted in him, his Heirs or A≈ø≈øigns, upon this Hypothe≈øis no Per≈øon in the Province of New-York hath the Fee or Property of the Land they po≈ø≈øe≈øs, the Fee remaining the Property of the Duke of York, his Heirs or A≈ø≈øigns. And further, upon the ≈øame Principle, tho≈øe identical Patents under the Seal of New-York, which were laid on the New-Hamp≈øhire Grants, are in their own Nature, equally null and void, with all other Conveyances of Land in the ≈øaid Province which have been given by the Crown, the Fee thereof being ve≈øted in the Duke of York, &c. So that the Grantees under New-York and New-Hamp≈øhire, are both, upon this Stating of the Ca≈øe, equally de≈øtitute of the Fee of the Land conte≈øted for: But, upon this Stating, the Grantees under New-Hamp≈øhire, have the Argument of Settlement, and Ocoupation, and Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, on their Side; which is abundantly ≈øufficient to give the Priority, and Preference of Title to them, ≈øo that neither the Government of New-York or
their Patentees, gain any Thing by building their Title on the ≈øaid Grant to the Duke of York‚Äîfor if there be any Thing in it, it defeats their own Title as well as that of New-Hamp≈øhire, proving too much for their Purpo≈øe, or nothing at all: But, if the Lands contained in the Duke of York's Grant reverted back to the Crown, then the Duke of York's Patent became extinct, null, and ab≈øolutely void, and is as though it never had been; whether the ≈øaid Rever≈øion happened in Con≈øequence of the ≈øaid Duke's abdicating the Throne‚Äîturning Papi≈øt, or by any formal Surrendery, or by any Means whatever, provided the Fee became reve≈øted in the Crown, then the ≈øaid Charter became extinct, as afore≈øaid: ≈øo that whether the Fee of the Land in Di≈øpute ≈øtill remains in the ≈øaid Duke of York, his Heirs or A≈ø≈øigns, or reverted, or was ≈øurrendered to the Crown, none of all this will in the lea≈øt ju≈øtify the Government of New-York or its Patentees, in founding their Preten≈øions of Title to the Lands afore≈øaid, by Virtue of the afore≈øaid Grant from King Charles to the Duke of York. For, take the Argument one Way, and it overturns both the Title of New-York and New-Hamp≈øhire al≈øo, leaving the latter in Occupation and Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the di≈øputed Premi≈øes, and that only, being intirely de≈øtitute of the Fee; and the New-York Claimants de≈øtitute of the lea≈øt Colour of Title what≈øoever. But, take the Argument the other Way, viz. Provided the Fee of the Lands afore≈øaid reverted and been reve≈øted in the Crown, then the ≈øaid Lands at the Time of fir≈øt granting were crown Lands the ≈øame as though the Duke of York had never exi≈øted: But the Truth of the matter undoubtedly
is this, the under Proprietors all except William Penn, who had the ≈øeveral Countries parcelled out to them by the Duke of York, which was contained in his Grant; ≈øurrendered their Charters to the Crown, whereby New-York and New-Jer≈øey, became royal Governments: This then being the State of the Ca≈øe, the Lands in Di≈øpute became Crown Lands, and the Governor of New-Hamp≈øhire, as well as New-York Crown Officers, or King's Agents, and it is of no Con≈øequence to the King which of his Governors, grants his Land, if ≈øo be they be granted to, and ≈øettled by loyal and indu≈øtrious Subjects, thereby adding to the Revenue of the Crown and enlarging and ≈øtrengthening the Kingdom: This being pre≈øuppo≈øed, and admit for ≈øuppo≈øition only, that the Governor New-Hamp≈øhire exceeded his proper Limits in crown Lands, mu≈øt the Grantees who have ≈øettled tho≈øe Lands, paid one of the crown Officers for granting the ≈øame, and expended their ALL, in ≈øettling and cultivating his Maje≈øty's Wilderne≈øs Land, and who are truly loyal Subjects, be turn'd off the ≈øaid Land by Thou≈øands, and reduced to ≈øtarving Poverty, together with their numerous Families, becau≈øe one of the crown Officers either ignorantly or de≈øignedly impo≈øed upon the People by granting Crown Lands over his Bounds? This would be extreme wrong, the more ≈øo as it cannot be ≈øuppo≈øed that the Subjects are capable Judges of the Juri≈ødiction of Governments and con≈øequently there ≈øhould be the greate≈øt care taken to guard the Subject from injury in all Ca≈øes of this Nature, the Truth of which will more fully appear by the following Con≈øiderations, viz. That notwith≈øtanding
the ≈øuppo≈øed Error in granting the ≈øaid Lands, yet the great End of the Crown in granting of it is compleatly an≈øwered, and provided the Subjects i. e. the Settlers are quieted in the Fee and Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øaid Lands, they will not be injured, ≈øo that upon this Hypothe≈øis, neither King nor Subject would ≈øu≈øtain Damage: Indeed no Per≈øon in the Realm could have ju≈øt Cau≈øe of Complaint. True, the re≈øpective Governors of New-York may in≈øinuate, that upon this ≈øtate of the Ca≈øe, the Governor of New-Hamp≈øhire has cheated them out of their Fees for granting the ≈øaid Land‚Äîthough it is evident, if Crown Officers are faithful to the King and Subjects, they could take no more Money for granting Crown Lands, than a rea≈øonable Compen≈øation for their Trouble, and the other Governor's being ≈øuppo≈øed to grant the Lands, ≈øaves the ≈øaid Governor of New-York the trouble; ≈øo that the Argument is brought to this ≈øingle Point only at la≈øt, that upon Suppo≈øition the Governor of New-Hamp≈øhire exceeded his proper Limits in granting tho≈øe Lands, yet neither King nor Subjects are injured, (provided the Claimants under New-Hamp≈øhire hold the Fee of the ≈øaid Land as above) except the Governors of New-York, and if they be ≈øuppo≈øed to be hone≈øt Men, the Trouble of granting the Land would be equal to their Fees had they granted it; ≈øo that they have not been injured a Whit more in this Ca≈øe, than they may be ≈øuppo≈øed to have injured the Subjects by taking exorbitant Fees for granting the ≈øame Lands; which to them is no Injury at all, but a providential Check to the Excerci≈øe of their Avarice. So that the re≈øpective Governors of New-York, in an equitable Sen≈øe, are no Loo≈øers in
this Affair; or at mo≈øt the Privileges would be ≈øo very incon≈øiderable as to make it meer trifling to mention it, e≈øpecially when ≈øet in Competition with the ≈øhocking and univer≈øal De≈øtruction that would over≈øpread a large Country of his Maje≈øty's good Subjects, provided they be di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the Lands afore≈øaid. This ≈øeems to be the genuine Sequel of the Argument, even upon the Yorker's own Stating it.

div.head: SECTION, II.
div.p:
IT is not conceeded to on the Part of the Claimants under New-Hamp≈øhire, that the Governor did in Fact exceed his proper Limits in granting tho≈øe Lands, the contrary will abundatly appear from the following Con≈øiderations, viz. Before and at the Time the ≈øaid Governor of New-Hamp≈øhire granted tho≈øe Lands they were reputed to be within his Juri≈ødiction, this was the Opinion of both Learned and Unlearned, the Wi≈øe as well as Simple, thus it was univer≈øally planed in all ancient and modern Maps down to the Year 1764, when, by royal Determination, the Juri≈ødiction of New-York, was extended over this di≈øputed Di≈øtrict of Land: But the general Opinion before this royal Adjudication was that the Province of New-York extended its Juri≈ødiction but Twenty Miles to the Ea≈øtward from Hud≈øon's River, ≈øo general was this Opinion that the be≈øt Maps of the two re≈øpective Provinces, and the Hi≈øtory of New-Hamp≈øhire adopted it as ≈øettled; it is of very great weight in the Que≈øtion to ≈øhew how unive≈øal this Maxim was, and that the unprejudiced and accurate Geographer Mr. Mitchel, in his Map compo≈øed ≈øo
late as the Year 1755, which with great Propriety and Certainty a≈øcertains the ≈øame Limits, this Map has the more Authority as it was according to the Certificate of Mr. Pownal, Secretary to the Board of Trade, and was undertaken with the Approbation and at the Reque≈øt of the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners for Trade and Plantation, and is chiefly compo≈øed from Draughts, Charts, and actual Serveys of different Parts of His Maje≈øty's Colonies and Plantations in America, great Part of which have been ≈øince taken by their Lord≈øhips Orders and tran≈ømitted to the Office of the Governors of ≈øaid Colonies: This Twenty Mile Line was ≈øo far from being deemed unfavourable to New-York, that we find the Commi≈ø≈øioners from that Province ≈øo late as the Year 1767, made an Offer to tho≈øe of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts-Bay to let a Line at Twenty Miles di≈øtance Ea≈øt of Hud≈øon's River be the Divi≈øion between their re≈øpective Provinces, which the latter Commi≈ø≈øioners would not then agree to it, being Thought by them too much in Favour of New-York, ≈øo little it ≈øeems did New-York Commi≈ø≈øioners conceive their Claim as far as Connecticut River could be ≈øupported.

THOUGH it is true in the Year 1771 the Province of New-York by a publick Act of their General A≈ø≈øembly, did annex all that Part of the Province of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts-Bay, to the We≈øtward from Connecticut River, to their County of Albany; and it is likewi≈øe true that in the Year 1773 the Governor's of the re≈øpective Provinces met at Hart≈øord in Connecticut and came to a mutual Agreement to ≈øettle that Line at Twenty Miles di≈øtance
Ea≈øtward from Hud≈øon's River, which was the Hypothe≈øis of that Settlement, which hath ≈øince been ratified by His Maje≈øty.

THE Report of the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners for Plantation Affairs in 1753, States the following Facts, from which is nece≈ø≈øarily inferred that New-Hamp≈øhire extended its Juri≈ødiction to the We≈øtward of Connecticut River.‚Äî"There are, ≈øays their Lord≈øhips, about 60,000 Acres of Land ≈øituate on the We≈øt ≈øide of Connecticut River, which was purcha≈øed by private Per≈øons from Connecticut, to whom the Land had been laid out, by the Government of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts-Bay as an equivalent for two or three Town≈øhips which the Latter purcha≈øed from the Former, this Tract of Land by the determination of the Boundary Line between the Provinces of New-Hamp≈øhire and the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts-Bay in 1739 is become a Part of New-Hamp≈øhire."‚ÄîThus we have their Lord≈øhips Sentiments that the Juri≈ødiction of New-Hamp≈øhire extended over Part of the very Lands in Conte≈øt, We≈øtward of Connecticut River, as long ago as the Year 1739, at which Time New-York never dreamed of extending their Claim to Connecticut River.‚ÄîThere is another glaring and indi≈øputable evidence of the former We≈øtern extent of New-Hamp≈øhire, viz. Relative to Fort Dummer which was Built by the Bay Province in 1724, and garri≈øoned at their Expence a great Number of Years; but upon its being excluded from their Juri≈ødiction by the Settlement of the juri≈ødictional Line, between them and New-Hamp≈øhire in 1739, the Bay Province repre≈øented to the Government at Home, that the ≈øaid
Di≈øtrict of Land and Fort Dummer, having been determined to be the Property of New-Hamp≈øhire, they were no longer obliged to Garri≈øon and maintain it, and praying, That as it was nece≈ø≈øary to the Defence of the Country, that New-Hamp≈øhire might be directed to ≈øupport it. In Con≈øequence of which, an Order pa≈ø≈øed the King and Council in 1744, that the Governor and Commander in Chief of New-Hamp≈øhire, ≈øhould forthwith move the A≈ø≈øembly, in His Maje≈øty's Name, to make a proper Provi≈øion for that Service; and at the ≈øame Time informing them that in Ca≈øe they refu≈øed to comply with ≈øo rea≈øonable and nece≈ø≈øary a Propo≈øal, his Maje≈øty would find him≈øelf under a Nece≈ø≈øity of re≈øtoring that Fort, with a proper Di≈øtrict of Land contiguous thereto, to the Province of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øett's-Bay, who cannot with Ju≈øtice be required to maintain a Fort no longer within their Boundary. In con≈øequence of this, New-Hamp≈øhire did maintain this Fort, and paid a Demand of Arrears for its Maintainance, to the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øett's-Bay. In the mean Time New-York was never a Competitor for the Burthen, willing as ≈øhe is to enjoy the Advantage of granting and engro≈ø≈øing the ≈øaid Lands.

THIS being the Ca≈øe, the Government of New-Hamp≈øhire by the Royal Decree, was obliged to maintain Fort Dummer, and it being on the We≈øt Side of Connecticnt River, and on this very identical Di≈øtrict of Land now in Di≈øpute, can that Government be ju≈øtly charged with granting Lands in the Province of New-York, when but a little before his Maje≈øty in Council had adjudged the ≈øame Lands to
be in the ≈øaid Government of New-Hamp≈øhire and ordered them to defend it, as by maintaining Fort Dummer, &c. Surely at that Time New-Hamp≈øhire, did extend its Juri≈ødiction We≈øtward of Connecticut River; otherwi≈øe the King had ordered the Government of New-York to have maintained Fort Dummer. Nothing can be more flagrantly evident, than, that the Government of New-Hamp≈øhire had a Right to Grant Crown Lands where the Crown compelled them to Defend. From Hence it appears, that the Government of New-Hamp≈øhire had a legal Right to grant the Lands now in Di≈øpute, and that, that Government and his Maje≈øty's good Subjects, the Grantees of, and Settlers on the ≈øaid Lands, acted upon hone≈øt and honourable Principles, in granting purcha≈øing, and ≈øettling the ≈øame, and on the other Hand, it appears, that the Government of New-York in re-granting the ≈øame Land, acted quite the rever≈øe; and the more unpardonably ≈øo, as they granted great Part of it, in open Defiance to His Maje≈øty's Authority manife≈øted unto them by his expre≈øs Prohibition, dated the 24th Day of July 1767.

FROM what has been already elucidated it appears, that the Line of Juri≈ødiction between the re≈øpective Provinces was not exactly a≈øcertained till the 20th of July 1764; but neverthele≈øs that the Admini≈øtration of Great-Britain had adjudged in 1739 and confirmed in 1755, that the Government of New-Hamp≈øhire extended We≈øtward of Connecticut River, and that this was the general Sen≈øe of the Nation (till a≈øcertained as afore≈øaid) is real Matter of Fact.‚ÄîTrue no Determination of
His Maje≈øty or Reports of the Lords of Trade had before particularized how far the Government of New-Hamp≈øhire ≈øhould extend We≈øt of Connecticut River: but ≈øuch Determinations of their's mightily ≈øtrengthened the common Opinion, nay, fully confirmed it, that that Government extended We≈øtward to a twenty Miles Di≈øtance, Ea≈øt from Hud≈øon's River; inter≈øecting a parrallel Line with the Colony of Connecticut, and the Province of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øett's Bay, between them and ≈øaid Province of New-York. This was the Opinion both of King and Subjects at the Time the Government of New-Hamp≈øhire granted tho≈øe Lands; and Americans could not conceive of any intermediate Boundary in one Place more than another, between Connecticut River and the twenty-mile Limit afore≈øaid; nor had they any Apprehen≈øion that the Government of New Hamp≈øhire would extend to the We≈øtward of that Limit. This parrallel Line took univer≈øal and deep Impre≈ø≈øion on the Minds of Geographers, and was the Under≈øtanding of the Briti≈øh Empire, and was thus portrayed in all former Maps.‚ÄîThe Certainty of this general Opinion may be further illu≈øtrated from the Con≈øideration that none of the Briti≈øh Subjects applied to the Government of New-York for Grants of tho≈øe Lands, till after the Alteration of Juri≈ødiction in 1764, except it be, as is pretended by the New-York Scriblers, that their Government extended Patents from within the ≈øaid twenty mile Line acro≈øs the ≈øame, and on ≈øome Part of the Premi≈øes in Di≈øpute, many Years before the Government of New-Hamp≈øhire granted tho≈øe Lands‚Äîwhich will
be hereafter con≈øidered: But, would further add, it is Matter of Di≈øpute whether the Admini≈øtration at Home would recognize tho≈øe Patents granted by the Government of New-York, on the Premi≈øes afore≈øaid; though antecedent to tho≈øe granted by New-Hamp≈øhire, ina≈ømuch as the Royal Adjudication in 1764, could not antecedently impower the Government of New-York to grant them Lands, which by Royal Adjudication of the Line of Juri≈ødiction between New-Hamp≈øhire and Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts Bay, fell within the Government of New-Hamp≈øhire in 1739, as afore≈øaid. However, for Argument only, we will ≈øuppo≈øe the Governments of New-Hamp≈øhire and New-York had each of them equal Authority to grant tho≈øe Lands‚Äîthen on this Stating the Ca≈øe, prior granting would of Con≈øequence be Priority of Title. The fir≈øt Conveyance, upon this Hypothe≈øis, being good and valid both in Law and Equity, mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily defeat any ≈øub≈øequent Grant from the Crown or its Repre≈øentatives, being as authentic, to all Intents and Purpo≈øes, as any Conveyance of the Fee of Land from the Crown can po≈ø≈øibly be.‚ÄîThus it appears upon this mo≈øt favourable Conce≈ø≈øion to tho≈øe on the Part of New-York, that the Argument preponderates in Favour of the Claimants under New-Hamp≈øhire, as their Grants are prior to tho≈øe of New-York, (except in the In≈øtances of the old Patents, yet to be con≈øidered.)

FURTHERMORE, it appears by the expre≈øs Words of the New-Hamp≈øhire Grants, that the Grantees were not only intitled to the Fee of the Lands
therein di≈øcribed, but al≈øo to all the Enfranchi≈øements, and each and every of the Privileges and Immunities that by Law his Maje≈øty's Subjects in the Province of New Hamp≈øhire enjoy; ≈øo that at the ≈øame Time that the Grantees were ve≈øted with the Fee of the Land, they were enfranchi≈øed with, and entitled to, all the Privileges and Immunities contained in their Charters; as the holding of Fairs, choo≈øing Town Officers, and making and mending their own Roads, &c. It is therefore humbly conceived, that provided it ≈øhould be the future Plea≈øure of his Maje≈øty, to continue the ≈øaid Lands in the Juri≈ødiction of New-York, (which by the Settlers afore≈øaid is hoped will not be the Ca≈øe) that the Claimants and Settlers under the ≈øaid Grants, will neverthele≈øs have his Maje≈øty's gracious Approbation to enjoy without Let or Mole≈øtation, the Privileges of Incorporation therein contained; the Grantees having ever con≈øidered tho≈øe Privileges as in≈øeperably connected with the Grant of the Fee-Simple.

div.head: SECTION III.
div.p: FROM the Facts and Rea≈øons that have been advanced in the foregoing Sections, it manife≈øtly appears, that the Title of the Claimants under New-Hamp≈øhire to the Lands in Que≈øtion is indefea≈øible; yet ≈øtill there are ≈øundry Con≈øiderations that may ≈øerve more abundantly to confirm and e≈øtabli≈øh this Title beyond He≈øitation. As,

FIRSTLY, The far greate≈øt Part of the Extent
of Juri≈ødiction of the Province of New-York, and great Part of New-Hamp≈øhire, depended entirely on his Maje≈øty's Plea≈øure, being wholly in the Arbitration of the Crown, to be either curtailed or extended. The real Grant on which the original Circumference of the Government of New-Hamp≈øhire was founded, extended but Sixty Miles from the Sea into the Country, to the We≈øtward, terminating about Twenty Miles Ea≈øt of Connecticut River. This Government was afterwards enlarged by his Maje≈øty's Commi≈ø≈øion to Benning Wentworth, E≈øq Governor of that Province, directing it to extend to the We≈øtward until it ≈øhould meet with his Maje≈øty's other Governments. Which Clau≈øe of We≈øtern Extention, in the ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øion, as well as the Royal Adjudication of the boundary Line between this Government and the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts-Bay in 1739, and Report of the Lords of Trade in 1755, and many Arguments mentioned in this and the foregoing Sections, all, on the Part of New-Hamp≈øhire, amount to ≈øufficient Evidence, that their Government extended ≈øo far We≈øt as to inter≈øect the parrallel Line of the Colony of Connecticut and Province of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts Bay, as argued above. And with re≈øpect to the Province of New-York, it's original Northen Circumference terminated South of the City of Albany, and afterwards, as Plantations were extended Northerly, either on Patents procured immediately from the Crown, or Government, or meer Settlements on Extra-provincial Lands, Commi≈ø≈øions from the King, to the re≈øpective Governors were enlarged, as in the Example following, viz. A. M. E≈øq.
Captain General, Governor and Commander in Chief in and over the Province of New-York, (then follows the Enlargement,) and the Territories depending thereon in America.‚ÄîThe≈øe Territories are that Exten≈øion of Juri≈ødiction beyond their fir≈øt circum≈øcribed Limits, terminating South of Albany, called the Province. This territorial Exten≈øion of Juri≈ødiction is altogether in the Arbitration of the Crown to curtail or extend as before repre≈øented. This being the Ca≈øe, the re≈øpective Governors can no other Way be Judges of the Extent of their Juri≈ødiction, but by Directions given them in their Commi≈ø≈øions, together with his Maje≈øty's expre≈øs Proclamations, and public Determinations relative thereto, as in the In≈øtance of the Royal Adjudication in 1764; a Publication of which, by his Maje≈øty's Order, gave his Subjects to under≈øtand, that it was his Plea≈øure that the Territorial Juri≈ødiction of New-York, ≈øhould extend to the We≈øt Banks of Connecticut River, which includes the di≈øputed Premi≈øes within that Government; before this it was impo≈ø≈øible for the Subjects to know it; if they could have under≈øtood it without his Maje≈øty's Proclamation certifying the ≈øame, ≈øuch Proclamation would have been needle≈øs and impertinent. The Truth of the Matter is, his Maje≈øty in 1739, determined New-Hamp≈øhire Government ≈øhould cover the pre≈øent di≈øputed Premi≈øes; he altered his Determination in 1764, whereby New-York extended it's Territories over the ≈øame Land. And the King has an undoubted Right to alter and regulate the Juri≈ødiction of Royal Governments as may ≈øeem to Him mete;
and for the New-Yorkers to pretend to amu≈øe People of common Sen≈øe, pretending that it is the ancient and indi≈øputable Right of the Colony of New-York to extend to the We≈øt Banks of Connecticut River, as it's ea≈øtern Boundary, is the very Height of Folly: It was in the Nature of Things ab≈øolutely impo≈ø≈øible his Maje≈øty him≈øelf ≈øhould have known that to have been the Ca≈øe the Moment before he determined it, and equally incon≈øi≈øtent that the Subjects ≈øhould know it before his Maje≈øty proclaimed it.

FURTHERMORE, it appears by the Repre≈øentation which was laid before his Maje≈øty by Lieutenant Governor Colden, as an Inducement to prefix the We≈øt Banks of Connecticut River, the ea≈øtern Boundary of the Province of New-York‚ÄîThat they were Arguments of Conveniency, holding up to View that it would be greatly to the Advantage of the Inhabitants on the New-Hamp≈øhire Grants, to be under the Juri≈ødiction of New-York; which Arguments are incompatible with the Idea of antecedent Right of Juri≈ødiction. Likewi≈øe, from hence we may ≈øee the Incon≈øi≈øtency of that Government or it's Patentees, in founding their Right in Fee to All or any Part of the Lands in Conte≈øt, by Virtue of the ≈øaid Royal Adjudication of the Boundary Line on the We≈øt Banks of Connecticut River; ina≈ømuch as it cannot operate to their Advantage antecedent to the Date of that Adjudication, and afterward cannot be con≈øidered any Thing more than a mere Line of Juri≈ødiction between the re≈øpective Governments.

IT ≈øhould be furthermore con≈øidered, that neither Governments were ve≈øted with the Fee of tho≈øe Lands; their Ca≈øe in this Re≈øpect, is quite the Rever≈øe to that of Proprietary Governments, who have a Right to appropriate the Soil. In Royal Governments, it is true, the Governors have a delegated Authority from his Maje≈øty to grant Crown Lands; and in ≈øuch Governments it is a Prerogative of the Crown to alter the Limits of Juri≈ødiction; His Maje≈øty hath a Right to re-annex the di≈øputed Premi≈øes to his Province of New-Hamp≈øhire, (in which it formerly was, and on the Faith of which the Claimants under that Government purcha≈øed and ≈øettled the ≈øame Lands) or incorporate it into a new Government, or continue it under the pre≈øent Juri≈ødiction, as his Royal Wi≈ødom may di≈øcern to be be≈øt for the governed: But, upon ≈øuch Alterations of Juri≈ødiction, private Property is never changed or ≈øubverted. For, if the Property of the Subject be in the Arbitration of the Crown, and liable to the ≈øame Vici≈ø≈øitudes and Changes with Juri≈ødiction, this would de≈øtroy the very Nature of Property, and would render a King ab≈øolute, and de≈øpotic, which is perfectly incon≈øi≈øtent with the Con≈øtitution of the Kingdom.‚ÄîTherefore, to convey or alienate Property, is the ≈øacred Prerogative of the rightful OWNER.‚ÄîKings and Governors (in the Kingdom of Great-Britain) cannot intermeddle therewith. There is indeed as much Difference between the Change of Juri≈ødiction, and transfering of the Property of the Subject, as there is between Light and Darkne≈øs; although ≈øince the ≈øaid Royal Adjudication in
1764, the New-Yorkers have endeavoured to blend them together to an≈øwer ≈øini≈øter and lucrative Purpo≈øes.‚ÄîThey were ≈øen≈øible, undoubtedly, that ≈øuch the afore≈øaid Arguments were conclu≈øive again≈øt their monopolizing the Fee-≈øimple of ≈øaid Lands; and as it is very common for People, who are upon a De≈øign of engro≈ø≈øing the Property of their Neighbour, to ≈øet up ≈øome ≈øpecious Pretence of Right to vindicate them≈øelves from the Imputation of Di≈øhonor and Reproach; ≈øo in the pre≈øent Ca≈øe, the New-Yorkers endeavour to draw the Curtain of the Duke of York over their Knavery, and under the feigned Character of Heirs to that apo≈øtate Duke, claim the Lands afore≈øaid, and fancy them≈øelves the Owners of Towns, (Fields) and Hou≈øes that they builded not.

div.head: Some REMARKS on a Pamphlet intitled, "A State of the Right of the Colony of New-York," &c.
div.p:
HAVING fini≈øhed the general Narrative of the Controver≈øy ≈øub≈øi≈øting between the Claimants, under New-Hamp≈øhire and New-York, to Lands to the We≈øtward of Connecticut River; which were fir≈øtly granted by the Former, and which, by the Determination of the Boundary-Line, between the re≈øpective Provinces in 1764, fell within the Juri≈ødiction of the Latter. And, having given the Reader to under≈øtand the Oppre≈ø≈øions which the Government of New-York have exerci≈øed towards the Grantees and Settlers under New-Hamp≈øhire, which could not have been ≈øo effectually done any other Way, as by tran≈øcribing the Letters from Governor Tryon to the Inhabitants of Bennington, and the adjacent Country, and their An≈øwers to him, on the State of the afore≈øaid Controver≈øy; which were publi≈øhed in the public News Papers, directly after they were wrote. And having al≈øo fini≈øhed three Sections of Arguments, which demon≈øtrate that the Fee of tho≈øe Lands was conveyed from the Crown to the New-Hamp≈øhire Grantees, by Virtue of their re≈øpective Charters; the la≈øt Thing propo≈øed, is to
make ≈øome Remarks on a Pamphlet intitled, A State of the Right of the Colony of New-York, &c. and on the Narrative of the Proceedings ≈øub≈øequent to the Royal Adjudication concerning the Lands to the We≈øtward of Connecticut River; lately u≈øurped by New-Hamp≈øhire.‚ÄîIntended as an Appendix to the General A≈ø≈øembly's State of the Right of the Colony of New-York, (with Re≈øpect to its ea≈øtern Boundary on Connecticut River, ≈øo far as concerns their late Encroachments under the Government of New-Hamp≈øhire,) publi≈øhed at their Se≈ø≈øion, 1773.

div.head: SECTION IV.
div.p:
ALTHOUGH the Arguments contained in the foregoing Sections are full and conclu≈øive, relative to the Nullity and Nothingne≈øs of the Duke of York's Grant, at lea≈øt, ≈øuch Part thereof as concerns the pre≈øent Di≈øpute; and that neither the Government of New-York or its Patentees gain any Manner of Title to the Land in Conte≈øt, by predicating it on the Validity of that Grant, yet the General A≈ø≈øembly of the ≈øaid Province in their State of the Rights, &c. venture the Stre≈øs of their whole Cau≈øe thereon, and deduce all their Arguments of Title to tho≈øe di≈øputed Premi≈øes therefrom: It is therefore partly out of Compliment to ≈øo learned a Body of Doctors, as well as more fully to invalidate, and apparently demon≈øtrate, to every capable Judge, the utter In≈øufficiency and Defect of Title to tho≈øe Lands, by Conveyance
from the Government of New-York, that the Grant of the Duke of York is here brought under Con≈øideration: And in Order thereto, it is Nece≈ø≈øary that the ≈øecond Grant be here in≈øerted, which is tran≈øcribed from the New-York Pamphlet Verbatim.

div.head: EXTRACT of King CHARLES the Second's Grant of the Province of New-York, to his Brother JAMES, Duke of York.

opener.signed: CHARLES the Second, by the Grace of God, King of England, Scotland, France and Ireland, Defender of the Faith, &c.
opener.salute: To all to whom the≈øe Pre≈øents ≈øhall come, Greeting:

div.p:
Know Ye, that We, for divers Good Cau≈øes and Con≈øiderations, have, of our e≈øpecial Grace, certain Knowledge and mere Motion, given and granted, and by the≈øe Pre≈øents, for us, our Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors, do give and grant unto our deare≈øt Brother, James, Duke of York, his Heirs and A≈ø≈øigns, all that Part of the Main Land of New-England, beginning at a certain Place, called or known by the Name of St. Croix, next adjoining to New Scotland, in America; and from thence extending along the Sea Coa≈øt, unto a certain Place called Petuaguine or Pemaquid, and ≈øo up the River thereof to the furthere≈øt Head of the ≈øame, as it tendeth Northwards; and extending from the River of Kinebeque, and ≈øo upwards, by the ≈øhorte≈øt Cour≈øe of the River
Canada Northwards: And all that I≈øland or I≈ølands, commonly called by the ≈øeveral Name or Names of Matowacks or Long-I≈øland, ≈øituate, and being towards the We≈øt of Cape Cod; and the Narrow Highgan≈øetts, abutting upon the Main Land; between the two Rivers there, called or known by the ≈øeveral Names of Connecticut and Hud≈øon's River, together al≈øo with the ≈øaid River called Hud≈øon's, and all the Lands from the We≈øt Side of Connecticut River, to the Ea≈øt Side of Delaware Bay: and al≈øo, all tho≈øe ≈øeveral I≈ølands, called or known by the Names of Martin's Vineyard, and Nantuckes, otherways Nantucket; together with all, &c.

closer.dateline: Dated the Twenty Ninth Day of June, in the Twenty Sixth Year of the Reign of King Charles the Second.

div.p:
It appears from the Sequel of the Repre≈øentations, Narratives and Arguments contained in the New-York Pamphlet, that the Government of New-York do not pretend to any Conveyance of the Fee of the Lands in Conte≈øt from the Duke of York. But their Grand Hypothe≈øis is, that the Juri≈ødiction of their Government from the fir≈øt E≈øtabli≈øhment, was predicated on, and bounded by the de≈øcriptive Limits of the ≈øaid Grant; and con≈øequently, that the di≈øputed Premi≈øes was never in the Government of New-Hamp≈øhire; and, that that Government never was ve≈øted with Authority to grant tho≈øe Lands, and al≈øo con≈øequently, that the Grants by them made, are in their own Nature void. This is the Sum of the
New-York Arguments relative to their Title to tho≈øe Lands. Here,

FIRST, it is nece≈ø≈øary the de≈øcriptive Limits of the above rehear≈øed Charter be brought under Con≈øideration; which includes the Countries of St. Croix, adjoining New Scotland, Pemaquid, the River Kenebeque, and the I≈ølands known by the Names of Martin's Vineyard, Nantucket, &c. All the≈øe Countries lying far Ea≈øt of Connecticut River, and within the actual Juri≈ødiction of the Provinces of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts Bay, New-Hamp≈øhire, &c. and at pre≈øent, not contended for on the Part of New-York. Their General A≈ø≈øembly, in the State of the Right. &c. had done well to have informed the Publick; whether their "ancient and indi≈øputable Right" of Juri≈ødiction extended to every Part of the di≈øcriptive Limits of the Grants afore≈øaid, and if not, to which Part it was circum≈øcribed; and when done, and by what Authority; whether their Governors Commi≈ø≈øions, at any Time, particularized and determined to what Part of the Limits of the ≈øaid Duke's Grant their Juri≈ødiction ≈øhould extend, more than another, or to the whole; or, whether any Royal Edict or Proclamation, had ever thus given them ≈øuch predicated Limits of Juri≈ødiction: this is ab≈øolutely nece≈ø≈øary for them to do, in Support of their Title to the Lands in Que≈øtion. And furthermore, it is requi≈øite for them to demon≈øtrate that tho≈øe Lands were actually contained in ≈øuch their former Limits of Juri≈ødiction: but, if the Government of New-York from Royal Determination, cannot extend Juri≈ødiction to any
one Part of the de≈øcriptive Limits of the Grant afore≈øaid, more than to another; then, on this Hypothe≈øis, their Juri≈ødiction includes the whole Limits contained in the Grant, or none at all; that it includes the Whole, will not be pretended, and that any Part, as predicated on them Limits, cannot be made to appear: But on the contrary, it appears His Maje≈øty and Council had no Reference to any Part of the Limits of this Grant, in determining the Boundaries of the Juri≈ødiction of New-York in 1764, as may appear from the Royal Order it≈øelf, an Extract of which is as follows: His Maje≈øty with the Advice of his Privy Council, doth Order and Declare, That the We≈øt Banks of the River Connecticut, from where it enters the Province of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts Bay, as far North, as the Forty-fifth Degree of Northern Latitude, to be the Boundary between the ≈øaid two Provinces‚Äîthat Parrallel of Latitude is al≈øo e≈øtabli≈øhed it's North Boundary, &c. The Source of Connecticut River is ≈øuppo≈øed to be ≈øomething to the Northward of Latitude Forty-Five, and comes much from the North-Ea≈øt, a con≈øiderable Di≈øtance after it pa≈ø≈øes that Latitude; but it is notorious, that the Source of Hud≈øon's River is far South of it; ≈øo that by comparing the de≈øcriptive Limits of the Duke of York's Grant, with tho≈øe expre≈ø≈øed in the Royal Order, they will be found to be materially different. The Limit of that Part of the Duke's Grant, which re≈øpects the pre≈øent Arguments, is in the Words following: Together al≈øo with the ≈øaid River called Hud≈øon's River, and all the Lands from the We≈øt Side of Connecticut River
to the Ea≈øt Side of Delaware Bay; which Limit in any po≈ø≈øible Con≈øtruction of it, can include but Part of the di≈øputed Premi≈øes, (which ≈øaid Premi≈øes extend and are bounded on the Forty-fifth Degree of North Latitude,) as will more fully appear in a further Di≈øcu≈ø≈øion of that Line. But,

FIRST, it is manife≈øt that the King and Privy Council, in determining the Extent of the Juri≈ødiction of the Province of New-York, did not proceed upon the Idea of that Government's having any antecedent Right of Juri≈ødiction to tho≈øe Lands. Had that been the Ca≈øe, the Royal Order had been predicated on the Boundary Lines of the Duke's Grant afore≈øaid, and could not have comprehended any more Land than from the We≈øt Side of Connecticut River to the Ea≈øt Side of Delaware Bay; and the≈øe Bounds are ≈øo loo≈øe, vague, and indeterminate, that it is altogether impo≈ø≈øible to found a Line of Juri≈ødiction thereon, as will more abundantly appear by the following Ob≈øervations on the di≈øcriptive Limits thereof, which may be ≈øeen at Large in the fore Part of this Section. Therefore, ≈øuch Part only, as is nece≈ø≈øary for the Con≈øideration of the indeterminate Bounds, before ≈øpoken of, is here quoted; which, after de≈øcribing the Situation of Long-I≈øland, and that it abuts upon the Main Land between the two Rivers there called or known by the ≈øeveral Names of Connecticut and Hud≈øon's River, begins the Di≈øcription under Con≈øideration, together with the ≈øaid River called Hud≈øon's River. Ob≈øerve, that as the De≈øcription
of this River is not immediately connected with any foregoing or following Di≈øcriptions in ≈øaid Grant; nothing more can po≈ø≈øibly be included in it, but a Di≈øcription of the River only, exclu≈øive of one Foot of Land on either Side. The ≈øecond Di≈øcription and all the Land from the We≈øt Side of Connecticut River to the Ea≈øt Side of Delaware Bay. The be≈øt Mathematician on Earth cannot a≈øcertain the≈øe Limits, except upon arbitrary Principles, as there can be no prefixed Place on Connecticut River where to erect the fir≈øt Bounds; and as to any particular Place on the Ea≈øt Side of Delaware Bay, where to erect a Second, is altogether undetermined in this Di≈øcription: But, ina≈ømuch as it includes all the Land from the We≈øt Side of Connecticut River, &c. there is a little better Foundation to e≈øtabli≈øh the fir≈øt Bounds than the Second. It ≈øeems in order to include All as afore≈øaid, it would be nece≈ø≈øary to extend either to the Head of the River, or to the mo≈øt Northerly Extention of the whole Stream, to make the fir≈øt Bounds; and provided this imaginary Bounds ≈øhould extend North of the Forty-fifth Degree of Northern Latitude, it would ≈øo far exceed the Settlement of the Line in 1764. Be this as it will, the mo≈øt Northerly Part of the River, which would mo≈øt likely be the Head, would be the mo≈øt favourable on the Part of New-York, for to e≈øtabli≈øh a fir≈øt Bounds, and from thence to extend a ≈øtrait Line to ≈øome Place on the Ea≈øt Side of Delaware Bay; this is ≈øomething of a natural Con≈øtruction, on the indeterminate de≈øcriptive Limits afore≈øaid, without exploring Connecticut River, which in this
Ca≈øe is nece≈ø≈øary. And, Fir≈øt, in tracing ≈øaid River to its Source, it is found towards it's Extremity, to come much out of the North-Ea≈øt. This being the Ca≈øe, a ≈øtrait Line from it's Head to Delaware Bay, would cro≈øs ≈øaid River and include a large Tract of Land on the Ea≈øt Side, and perhaps cro≈øs the River ≈øundry Times; the Con≈øequences may be drawn thus, that where the Line may be ≈øuppo≈øed to cro≈øs the la≈øt Time, ought to be the fir≈øt real North Boundary, of the ancient and indi≈øputable Limit of Juri≈ødiction of New-York. For, if the Bounds at the Head of the River before ≈øpoken of, be ≈øo e≈øtabli≈øhed, it would include con≈øiderable Land on the Ea≈øt Side of the River, within the old Boundary of New-York, which is contrary to any Idea to be gained from the di≈øcriptive Limit afore≈øaid, viz. and all the Land from the We≈øt Side of Connecticut River, &c. Still it may be queried whether there may not be another propo≈øed fir≈øt Boundary better purporting with the Di≈øcription of And all the Land from the We≈øt Side of Connecticut River to the Ea≈øt Side of Delaware Bay, between the Head of the River, and the Place where the imaginary Line was ≈øuppo≈øed to pa≈øs? To this it may be an≈øwered, that a Place between the≈øe two, ≈øo far up the River as in tracing a ≈øtrait Line from thence, to Delaware Bay, would not cro≈øs the River, may better agree with the above Di≈øcription: Still, from none of the≈øe imagined Lines, from the different imagined Bounds, or from any other projected, po≈ø≈øible, fir≈øt Bounds, can ≈øuch a ≈øtrait Line be a≈øcertained, till the Place for the South-We≈øtern Boundary on the
"Ea≈øt Side of Delaware Bay" be e≈øtabli≈øhed? And the Vaguene≈øs of the di≈øcriptive Limit is ≈øo great, that it cannot be determined whether that Bounds ≈øhall be at the Northern Extremity of the Ea≈øt Side of Delaware Bay, or at the Southern, where it communicates with the main Ocean, or at any other intermediate Place between the≈øe two: ≈øo, that from the uncertainty of the ≈øecond Bounds, it is impo≈ø≈øible to e≈øtabli≈øh the fir≈øt, ≈øo as exactly to include "all the Land from the We≈øt Side of the ≈øaid River to the Ea≈øt Side of ≈øaid Bay," and no more. And,

THUS it is demon≈øtrated from the Vaguene≈øs, Uncertainty and Ob≈øoletene≈øs of the di≈øcriptive Limits of the Grant to the Duke of York, before quoted at large; that it is in the Nature of Things ab≈øolutely impo≈ø≈øible to a≈øcertain it. From hence follows a Second nece≈ø≈øary inference, viz. That it is equally impo≈ø≈øible and contradictory, that governmental Juri≈ødiction ≈øhould be predicated thereon; for an ideal uncertain Juri≈ødiction, in its own Nature incapable to be determined, is in reality none at all. And from hence follows a Third Inference which determines the Sequel of the Argument, on the Subject of Property, concerning the Lands in Que≈øtion, to be in Favour of the Claimants under New-Hamp≈øhire: For, it is in the la≈øt Place, equally contradictory and impo≈ø≈øible, as in the Ca≈øe of the Ab≈øurdity of a≈øcertaining the Limits of the pretended "ancient" Juri≈ødiction of New-York, predicating it on vague and undeterminate Boundaries, that, that Government ≈øhould predicate
their Right to the Fee of Lands, by them thus una≈øcertainable; for as Uncertainty, and natural Impo≈ø≈øibility of a Juri≈ødiction's being rendered determinate makes it in Reality to be none at all; ≈øo the Idea of Property, predicated thereon is equally impertinent.‚ÄîTrue it is, by the royal Determination in 1764, the Ea≈øt Line of New-York extended to the We≈øt Banks of Connecticut River. Which may be Foundation for Conjecture, that, that Limit might have Reference to a Di≈øcription in the Duke's Grant afore≈øaid, "and all the Lands from the We≈øt Side of Connecticut River," &c. Yet when the Repre≈øentation made by Lieut. Governor Colden, to his Maje≈øty in Council, as mentioned in this Pamphlet, under the Head of the Narrative, &c. comes to be con≈øidered it will reflect Light on this Point. The Arguments made U≈øe of in the ≈øaid Repre≈øentation were tho≈øe of Conveniency and Advantage to the Settlers on tho≈øe Lands to be in the Government of New-York: And, that the We≈øt Banks of Connecticut River was a good and certain Boundary," &c. The≈øe were undoubtedly the preponderating Motives of determining the We≈øt Banks of Connecticut River to be the Ea≈øt Boundary of New-York, and ≈øuch Arguments are utterly incon≈øi≈øtant with the Notion of an "Ancient indi≈øputable Right" of Juri≈ødiction.

THERE is ≈øtill another Con≈øideration which may be of Moment in the Ob≈øervation of this, ≈øo Trumpt-up, "ANCIENT RIGHT OF JURISDICTION" of the Province of New-York, to the Lands in Conte≈øt: If it be admitted a Line ≈øhould be drawn from the mo≈øt northerly Part of Connecticut River
