to the mo≈øt northern Extremity of Delaware-Bay; ≈øtill, it is by no means probable ≈øuch Line would include more than one half (if ≈øo much) of the Lands in Di≈øpute ≈øo far as may be judged from the Latitude and Longitude of the re≈øpective Objects: For con≈øidering the Cour≈øe of Connecticut River, which is nearly from North to South, except towards its Extremity; and the Sea coa≈øt, from the River's Mouth, together with Delaware Bay, forming al≈øo an indened Line, to the South of We≈øt; the Land included in the≈øe Limits, by a Line drawn from Connecticut River to Delaware Bay as afore≈øaid, would (excepting the ≈ømall Promontory formed by the Mouth of the Bay and the Ocean) lye in the Figure of an obtu≈øe angled Triangle; and the Cour≈øe of the ≈øaid Line from the River to the Bay, according to occular Survey, would be from the Northea≈øt a Southwe≈øterly Direction: Which very badly comports with the pre≈øent North and We≈øterly Exerci≈øe of Juri≈ødiction of the Government of New-York, at Crownpoint, Detroit, &c.‚ÄîIt may here well be ob≈øerved, the Settlers under New-Hamp≈øhire ≈øeem to be in a critical Situation; every arbitrary Mea≈øure under the pre≈øent Admini≈øtration of the Government of New-York, is excerci≈øed again≈øt them; and provided they flee to the Ea≈øtward to procure Inheritances, there they are fore-clo≈øed, the di≈øcriptive Limits of the ≈øaid ancient Juri≈ødiction covers them (to wit) the Countries of St. Croix, Pemaquid, Kenebeque, Nantucket, Martin's Vineyard, &c.‚ÄîYet there is another large unknown Country to the We≈øt and Northwe≈øt, which has been but partly
explored; and provided, the≈øe People, in≈øtead of fleeing to the Ea≈øtward, ≈øhould turn their Cour≈øe, to tho≈øe Countries; there, it is indi≈øputable but that, New-York would encircle them with another odd Di≈øcription of Domain contained in their Governor's Commi≈ø≈øions, i. e. A. B. Captain General Governor and Commander in Chief in and over the Province of New-York, next follows the Di≈øcription hinted and the Territories depending thereon, in America.

FROM the foregoing Di≈øcriptions of the Government of New-York, it appears they lay Claim to ≈øo exten≈øive a Domain three different Ways, or have three different Modes or Modifications in comprehending and engro≈ø≈øing their progre≈ø≈øive Limits. As,
1≈øtly. THE Province of New-York, which falls ≈øhort of, and terminates con≈øiderably South of the City of Albany.

2dly. "THE Territories depending thereon in America." The≈øe Territories comprehending ≈øuch Plantations, on extra-provincial Land, as are and have been carried on adjoining to the Province till its Territories, are at pre≈øent extended to Detroit and the Neighbourhood thereof, &c.

3dly. The Limits of the Duke of York's Grant, and ina≈ømuch as the Grantees and Settlers on the Lands in Di≈øpute, hold their Title under New-Hamp≈øhire, and that Government had for ≈øeveral Years exerci≈øed their Juri≈ødiction over tho≈øe Lands,
even till 1764.‚ÄîTherefore, in this Ca≈øe the Government of New-York could not extend their Territorial Sort of Juri≈ødiction over the Premi≈øes; for ≈øuch Sort of Juri≈ødiction might be challenged on the Part of New-Hamp≈øhire (if it ≈øhould be admited at that Time, ≈øaid Premi≈øes was extra-provincial Lands) and that with far the mo≈øt Propriety. Ina≈ømuch as that Government had granted the Land and began Settlements thereon. Add to this the following Clau≈øe in Governor Wentworth's Commi≈ø≈øion, which they viewed to be of great Weight in this Ca≈øe, which, after di≈øcribing the former Limits of New-Hamp≈øhire, and from thence extending We≈øt till it meets with his Maje≈øty's other Governments. Add to this al≈øo, the Rea≈øons held forth in the Chain of Arguments, contained in the three fir≈øt Sections; all which were too potent for the New-York territorial Sort of Dominion to fru≈øtrate. At that Juncture, Therefore, the Lawyers, Land-jobbers, Politicians, &c. planed out the afore≈øaid third Modes of Juri≈ødiction predicating it on the di≈øcriptive Limits of the Grant to the Duke of York. And on this new modled Plan breathed an air of ANCIENT AND INDISPUTABLE RIGHT of Juri≈ødiction, and con≈øequently to the Fee of the Lands in Conte≈øt.

THE fir≈øt Intimation that ever ≈øaluted the Ears of the Publick, a≈ø≈øerting it to be the ancient Right of the Colony of New-York, to extend to Connecticut River as its ea≈øtern Boundary, was di≈øcoverd from a Proclamation, given under the Hand of William Tryon, E≈øq Governor of the
Province of New-York, &c. and dated the 11th Day of December, 1771. His Proclamation begins after the following Manner. Whereas it is the ancient and inconte≈øtible Right of this Colony to extend to Connecticut River, as its Ea≈øtern Boundary.

THIS was drawing a po≈øitive Conclu≈øion from fictitious, and till that Time, unheard of Premi≈øes: and rather influenced People, in the ≈øeveral Governments, to purcha≈øe and ≈øettle under New-Hamp≈øhire, than di≈øwade them therefrom, for common Fame, and common Sen≈øe were a Barrier again≈øt the Belief of this New-York Doctrine, which from the Time of the royal Adjudication in 1764, was by the Proclamation afore≈øaid, antidated to "Ancient." That this Doctrine till then, was inconte≈øted, is thought to be true; for it had but peept to public Con≈øideration, and has ever ≈øince been conte≈øted.

SHOULD this, their new Hypothe≈øis be admitted; yet, as hath been before ob≈øerved, the≈øe Limits could include but Part of ≈øaid Lands, according to the be≈øt Judgment that can be formed without an actual, and accurate Survey of the di≈øcriptive Limits of ≈øaid Grant; which if the New-Yorkers can do and fairly Demon≈øtrate, to any able Mathematicians, and competant and impartial Judges, that they have rightly a≈øcertaned tho≈øe Limits, it is engaged on the Part of the Claimants under New-Hamp≈øhire that they ≈øhall yield up, to the Land-jobbers of New-York, their Lands and Labours:
an Object which undoubtedly would be grateful and plea≈øing to them; and which they have many Years been in Pur≈øuit of, and have hitherto had the Mortification to be baffled. It is verily Incumbant on the Government of New-York, in order to found Tittle to tho≈øe Land on this new Scheme,

FIRSTLY, to a≈øcertain the Limits of their imaginary Bounds: This, the Claimants under New-Hamp≈øhire, will expect compleated, or hear no more of tho≈øe "ANCIENT AND INCONTESTIBLE" Boundaries of New-York.

div.head: SECTION, V.
div.p:
THE General A≈ø≈øembly of the Colony of New-York, in their State of the Right of that Colony, &c. Page 3d. wave the Right of the Engli≈øh by fir≈øt Di≈øcovery, as being foreign to their Purpo≈øe, & that the Dutch Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions are only material to be ≈øupported; and Claim no further Right by Pay of the Dutch, but priority of Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion. Yet in the ≈øame Page inform, when the fir≈øt War between England and Holland became inevitable, King Charles the Second, by Letters Patent dated the 12th Day of March 1663-4, granted to his Brother the Duke of York the Tracts of Country, which comprehend New-York. To render this Gift effectual, before the War was proclaimed, a Fleet and Land Forces were ≈øent out to remove the Dutch and put the Duke in Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion.‚Äî The Circum≈øtancies that attended the making this Grant, and ≈øending the Armament
to render it effectual, are a ≈øufficient Rea≈øon to Determine that the Government at Home, at that Time, viewed the Dutch Settlement as an Intru≈øion, and Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion (which is all they rely on) gained by tre≈øpa≈øs, in legal Con≈øtruction, is no Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion at all. That the Engli≈øh had prior Right to all the Countries from Forty to Forty-eight Degrees of North Latitude, by Virtue not only of Di≈øcovery by Seba≈øtian Cabot and others, but by being in actual Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of ≈øeveral Parts of the Premi≈øes, is Matters too well known to be di≈øputed.

WHETHER there was real Sei≈øin in the Crown, or not, or the Time of granting the≈øe Countries, is not truly in Que≈øtion; ≈øince every Grant ≈øo made is inconte≈øtibly valid again≈øt the King, his Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors; and the Colony of New-York being entirely Dependant on the Crown of Great-Britain for their Title; Priority of Charter is therefore nece≈ø≈øary to be determined.

THE Grant of King James the Fir≈øt to the Council of Plymouth bearing Date at We≈øtmin≈øter, the 13th Day of November, in the Eighteenth Year or his Reign: comprehends all the Lands, I≈ølands, &c. from forty to forty-eight Degrees of North Latitude, through the Main Land from Sea to Sea. On the 19th Day of March 1628, the Council of Plymouth under their common Seal, did grant to Sir Henry Ro≈øwell, Sir John Young, and Others, their Heirs and A≈ø≈øociates for ever, all that Part of America, lying between the Great River
there, commonly called Monomack, alias Merimack and Charles River, within the Space of three Miles to the Northward of the ≈øame River, called Monomack, alias Merimack, or to the Northward of any or every Part thereof, and in Length and Longitude of and within all the Breadth afore≈øaid, thro'out the Main Lands there, from the Atlantic or We≈øtern Sea or Ocean on the Ea≈øt Part, to the South Sea on the We≈øt Part.

THIS Deed of Sale at the Suit of the Grantees, with a Charter of Incorporation, was granted and confirmed by King CHARLES the Fir≈øt, the 4th Day of March 1629, wherein the Limits are exactly the ≈øame with tho≈øe in the Plymouth Conveyance; and the Provi≈øo of CHARLES, that the actual Settlement of the Subjects of other Chri≈øtian States to determine the Extent, the ≈øame as was the Provi≈øo in JAMES'S Grant to the Plymouth Company.

THIS ≈øame Charter of Incorporation was adjudged void in the High Court of Chancery of England in 1684; from which the A≈ø≈øembly of New-York in their State, &c. Page 5th, take Occa≈øion to ≈øay the Title of that Colony now ≈øolely depends on their new Charter of 1691. Neverthele≈øs, the Right of Soil to All and every Part of the Deed of Sale afore≈øaid, remained indefea≈øible; for, only animadvert back to the Plymouth Conveyance, and ob≈øerve, that the Right in Fee, was by them conveyed to the Grantees; and trace it to King CHARLES'S Charter of Incorporation, which only ve≈øted the Grantees with Powers of Government.
Though it is true, this Charter contains all the Formality nece≈ø≈øary in the Conveyance of the Fee; yet is, ≈øo far as re≈øpects the Fee, is no more than a Duplicate of what was before granted, which neither adds nor demini≈øheth; and it is ea≈øy to ≈øee, that the Court of Chancery could not vacate or make Void, at mo≈øt, any Thing more than tho≈øe incorporate Privileges; and likewi≈øe as ea≈øily di≈øcernable that nothing more was attempted. Thus the Colony of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts ≈øtill hold their Right in Fee, by Conveyance from King JAMES to the Council of Plymouth, who were their Grantors.

IN the next Place it may be ob≈øerved, that in 1691 the Privileges of Incorporation were re≈øtored; though our Authors, in their State, &c. endeavour to curtail the Colony of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts, by con≈øtruing their la≈øt Charter to extend no further We≈øt than the Ea≈øt Limit of the Colony of Connecticut. Their Words are the≈øe, "The≈øe Words (as far as) being in the Ca≈øe of the Grant of the Crown on the Suit of the Party, in legal Con≈øtruction, carry the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts Bay Colony no farther We≈øtward than till it meets the Colony of Connecticut, and not to Connecticut River, and much le≈øs to the We≈øtward of it." Be the≈øe bold A≈ø≈øertions as they will, and provided it be here admitted, for Argument ≈øake, that the Powers of Juri≈ødiction of the Province of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts Bay be ever ≈øo much curtailed, yet one Propo≈øition we can verily be a≈ø≈øured of, viz. That it is not in the Power of King or Chancery to curtail or deprive them of their Property.

IT is to be further ob≈øerved, that however our Authors may Critici≈øe upon the gramatical or legal Con≈øtruction of ≈øelected Words or Phra≈øes; yet, a little Attention to the following real Facts, will clearly point out the Incon≈øi≈øtency of ≈øuch Sophi≈øms.

FIRSTLY, Connecticut Charter, granted by King CHARLES the Second, the 23d Day of April 1662, was bounded and extended in Length, by and with the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts fir≈øt Charter, granted by King CHARLES the Fir≈øt, the 4th Day of March 1629, which inconte≈øtibly extended agreeable with the afore≈øaid di≈øcriptive Limits of the Deed of Sale from the Council of Plymouth, to Sir Henry Ro≈øwell, Sir John Young, &c. and extended through the Main Land in Longitude to the South Sea on the We≈øt Part.

THIS Charter, as above, being nullified in the High Court of Chancery of England in 1684, and re≈øtored again in 1691, wherein the We≈øt Extent of Limit is predicated by that of Connecticut, and this We≈øt Limit of Connecticut being predicated by the old Charter of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts Bay, and expre≈øly extending in Longitude to the South Sea on the We≈øt Part, exactly extends the pre≈øent Charter of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts Bay, with it's Powers of Juri≈ødiction to All, and every Part of the Limits of the old nulled Charter. This is the natural and legal Sen≈øe of the pre≈øent Charter of the Colony of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts Bay, predicated on undeniable Facts,

IN the next Place 'tis nece≈ø≈øary to con≈øider the Charter of Connecticut, which our Authors inform ≈øhould not extend We≈øt of Connecticut River, in the Words following: This being a Crown Grant on the Suit and Petition of the Grantees, is to be taken mo≈øt beneficially for the King. The di≈øcriptive Words, and the Intention of the Grant, will in legal Con≈øtruction be ≈øatisfied by giving the Colony the ≈øame Length as the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts Bay; and it is plain, both from the Recital and the ≈øaving Clau≈øe in the Plymouth Patent, on which the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øett's Title was founded, that the Latter cou'd not in any Sen≈øe, extend to the We≈øtward of Connecticut River. As this their A≈ø≈øertion is founded on the Hypothe≈øis of Connecticut Charter's being predicated on that of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øett's, and therefore the Arguments before exhibited on that Head, are equally Conclu≈øive for the e≈øtabli≈øhing the We≈øtern Extent of Connecticut, nothing more is nece≈ø≈øary for that Purpo≈øe, but a Recital of the di≈øcriptive Words of their Charter, granted ≈øub≈øequent to their Purcha≈øe from the Council of Plymouth by King CHARLES the Second, the 23d Day of April, 1662, Bounded on the Ea≈øt by Narragan≈øet River, commonly called Narragan≈øet Bay, where the ≈øaid River falleth into the Sea; and on the North by the Line of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts Plantation; and on the South by the Sea, and in Longitude as the Line of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts Colony, running from Ea≈øt to We≈øt: That is to ≈øay, from the ≈øaid Narragan≈øet Bay on the Ea≈øt, to the South Sea on the We≈øt Part. Thus it appears not
only by the Demon≈øtrations afore≈øaid, but from the expre≈øs Words of the di≈øcriptive Limits of the Charter it≈øelf, which cannot admit of a double Meaning, (curious as our Authors be in the Art of playing with Words, they have not attempted to obviate their literal Meaning,) that it is the unque≈øtionable Right of the Colony of Connecticut to extend it's We≈øtern Boundary to the South Sea on the "We≈øt Part;" and in this that Colony agree, who are now challenging their Right in Fee to tho≈øe Limits, and actually making Plantation, as at Su≈øquebannah, &c.

BY this Time, undoubtedly Queries will ari≈øe in the Mind of the Reader, What will become of the Grant to the Duke of York, if the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øett's and Connecticut Colonies extend "to the South Sea on the We≈øt Part?" The following Intelligence from our Authors will introduce an An≈øwer to this Query; who, after di≈øcribing ≈øaid Grant further inform, in Page 3d of the State, &c. That a Fleet and Land Forces were ≈øent to remove the Dutch, and put the Duke in Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion. Accordingly, on the 27th Day of Augu≈øt 1664, the Dutch Governor Stuyve≈øant, ≈øurrendered by Capitulation, all the Countries the Dutch then po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, to King CHARLES the Second; when among other Terms it was ≈øtipulated, that all the People ≈øhall remain free Denizens, and ≈øhall enjoy their Lands, Hou≈øes, and Goods, where ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ er they are within this Country, and di≈øpo≈øe of them as they plea≈øe. Thus, by Conque≈øt, the King became reve≈øted with his Right to the Lands conquered:
for, as the King had antecedently di≈øpo≈øed of all the E≈øtate the Crown was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of in the≈øe Countries, to the Colonies of Connecticut and the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts Bay; therefore, his Right now could not extend any further than the actual Conque≈øt, which, in legal Con≈øtruction, mu≈øt be ≈øatisfied with, and can extend no further than the actual Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions de≈øcribed in the forementioned Capitulation. A further Information is in Page 4th, To remove any Doubt of the Validity of the Dukes Title, either from the Want of Sei≈øin in the Crown when it originated, or on Account of the intermediate Conque≈øt by the Dutch, it was confirmed to his Royal Highne≈øs by further Letters Patent, dated the 29th Day of June, 1674. That there was Want of Sei≈øin in the Crown at the Time of fir≈øt Granting, is inconte≈øtible; for, as above ≈øaid, the King by antecedent Grants had dive≈øted the Crown of it's Right, and by this Conque≈øt became reve≈øted: So that from this, Occa≈øion will be taken to ≈øay, that in Fact the Province of New-York was originally ≈øounded on Conque≈øt, and the Limits of it, as before mentioned, circum≈øcribed by the Dutch Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions pointed out in the Terms of Capitulation. However ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ourable this Conclu≈øion may be thought, on the Part of New-York, yet, as the Crown had prior to either of the Duke's Grants, di≈øpo≈øed of its Right to the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts and Connecticut Colonies‚Äîif it was not thus founded on Conque≈øt, it hath no Foundation at all; and it's having any Place for Exi≈øtence, is but an "Intru≈øion on the Rights" of tho≈øe other Colonies. Furthermore, it is My≈øterious and Contradictory,
admitting that that Government was thus founded, to ≈øuppo≈øe the Duke could be Lord Proprietor; ina≈ømuch as by the Conditions of Capitulation, the Fee then acquired to the Crown, pa≈ø≈øed to the Dutch Inhabitants, who then became Engli≈øh Subjects.

THE Reader is in the next Place invited to a more particular Con≈øideration of the afore≈øaid di≈øputed Premi≈øes, which are bounded South on the North Line of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts Bay, and We≈øt by a Line about twenty Miles Ea≈øt of Hud≈øon's River, extending North ten Degrees, Ea≈øt till it comes almo≈øt oppo≈øite to Ticondaroga; thence We≈øt till it ≈øtrikes on Lake Champlain, thence on the Ea≈øt Banks of ≈øaid Lake to the Forty fifth Degree of Northern Latitude, and on the North by the ≈øaid Latitude, and Ea≈øt on the We≈øt Banks of Connecticut River. On this Tract of Country 'tis not pretended there ever was any ancient Dutch Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, nor any under Title from New-York, except on the We≈øt Part of the Town≈øhip of Pownal, ≈øituate at the South-We≈øt Corner of this Tract; and ≈øome Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions in the Town≈øhip of New-Haven, on Otter Creek, which Colonel Reed gained and maintained by Force, about three Years, and which by Force he was obliged to ≈øurrender to the fir≈øt Settlers, who were Claimants under New-Hamp≈øhire.

THOUGH this Tract of Land was contained in the original Grant to the Council of Plymouth, yet, as they never made any Conveyance of it, therefore it reverted to the Crown on the Surrender of that
Grant, the 7th Day of June, 1635. From which it may be objected, on the Part of New-York, that the above Conci≈øene≈øs in the Circum≈øcription of the Boundaries of their Colony is too great; for, that the Grant to the Duke mu≈øt hold good where the Crown, at the Time of granting, was ve≈øted with a Right to the Lands granted. In An≈øwer, it has been argued in the preceeding Section, that it is very uncertain whether the Limits of the Duke of York's Grant included this Tract of Land, or if any, how great a Part; and that the Limits of ≈øaid Grant cou'd not be a≈øcertained‚Äîand that governmental Juri≈ødiction, and Property cou'd not be predicated on ≈øuch ob≈øolete and uncertain Bounds. It was al≈øo demon≈øtrated in the fir≈øt Section, and will be further ob≈øerved in this, that the Duke of York's Grant reverted to the Crown, and that the Landholders in the Government of New-York hold under the Crown‚Äîand that, if it did not revert to the Crown, the Fee is ≈øtill in the Duke, his Heirs or A≈ø≈øigns, and no Landholders in the Government are ve≈øted with the Fee of the Lands they po≈ø≈øe≈øs, &cThis Argument and Couclu≈øion is founded on the New-York Hypothe≈øis, exclu≈øive of the herein mention'd Article in the Dutch Capitulation.. It would be too tedious as well as needle≈øs to recite the Arguments that have been offered in the three fir≈øt Sections, which is humbly conceived are abundantly ≈øu≈ø≈øicient to An≈øwer the afore≈øaid Objection, and fairly demon≈øtrate Priority of Title to be in Favour of New-Hamp≈øhire; to which the curteous Reader is referred for a Con≈øideration.

As has been before ob≈øerved, the De≈øign of the Duke of York's Grant was to include the Dutch Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, or in other Words, that it never was valid any further than to ≈øuch Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, which by Conque≈øt, reverted to the Crown, and no farther than the≈øe Limits, to interfere with the Charter Colonies of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts and Connecticut. And as a Twenty Miles Line to the Ea≈øtward from Hud≈øon's River would include the mo≈øt Ea≈øtern Extent of the forementioned Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, the Rea≈øon why ≈øuch a Line was agreed to as the Boundary between the Colonies of Connecticut and New-York: But, as the≈øe Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions to the Northward of Connecticut, fell far ≈øhort of this Twenty Mile Line, or were ≈øo incon≈øiderable and uncertain as not to come within the Capitulation Re≈øerve, therefore, the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts Colony contended with New-York for a further We≈øtern Extent than Twenty Miles Ea≈øt from Hud≈øon's River; but the re≈øtle≈øs Government of New-York, ever unea≈øy within it's own Boundaries, pre≈øumed unrelenting, to intrude on, and conte≈øting for the ju≈øt Rights of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts, by extending their Patents far to the Ea≈øtward of Twenty Miles from Hud≈øon's River; in Con≈øequence of which the greate≈øt Di≈øturbances have ari≈øen between the Inhabitants of the re≈øpective Colonies, and ≈øundry of the Conflicts ≈øo ≈øevere, that human Blood ≈øpilt in the Conte≈øts redened the Hands of the Intruders; but finally a boundary Line was agreed to by the re≈øpective Governments in 1773, at a Twenty Miles Di≈øtance from Hud≈øon's River, which has ≈øince been ratified by his Maje≈øty.

IN the State of the Right, &c. Page 4th, is the mo≈øt extraordinary Account of Alienation of Property that is to be found in the Annals of Hi≈øtory. The Duke continued Proprietor and chief Governor of this Province till he a≈øcended the Throne, when his Right merged in the Royal Authority, on his Abdication it pa≈ø≈øed to King William, his Succe≈ø≈øor, as Lord Proprietor and Royal Sovereign. That upon the Duke's acce≈ø≈øion to the Throne his Right of Government merged in the Royal Authority will not be denied; But, that his Right in Fee, con≈øequently pa≈ø≈øed to King William as his Succe≈ø≈øor, wants greater Proof than a bare A≈ø≈øertion; our Authors ≈øhould have explained this Matter; 'tis taken for granted they will not pretend that King William was Heir at Law to the Duke's E≈øtate, and they mention no Conveyance from the Duke to the King, but ≈øay the "Duke's Right merged in the Royal Authority;" to ≈øuppo≈øe it is po≈ø≈øible that Right ≈øhould pa≈øs to King William, as Lord Proprietor, is ≈øo great an Ab≈øurdity that it wants a Name.

IN the ≈øame Page they further inform, That in the Duke of York's Commi≈ø≈øions to his ≈øeveral Lieutenant Governors, Major Edmond Andro≈øs on the fir≈øt Day of July 1674, and Col. Thomas Dongan on the 30th Day of September 1682, among other Di≈øcriptions of the Boundaries of this Province, are expre≈øly comprehended all the Land from the We≈øt Side of Connecticut River to the Ea≈øt Side of Delaware Bay. Note, tho≈øe Commi≈ø≈øions were from the Duke before he a≈øcended
the Throne; undoubtedly in his Commi≈ø≈øions to his Lieutenant Governors, he had referrence to the Limits of his Grant, to determine their Boundaries: But after his Abdication, and the Acce≈ø≈øion of King Willaim and Queen Mary, we find a Commi≈ø≈øion from their Maje≈øty's to Henry Slaughter, to be materially different. King William and Queen Mary, by their Commi≈ø≈øion, dated the Fourth Day of January, in the Fir≈øt Year of their Reign, appointed Henry Slaughter to be Governor of the Province of New-York, and the Territories depending thereon in America. The ≈øame A≈ø≈øembly (≈øtiled our Authors) further inform, that in all ≈øub≈øequent Acts and Commi≈ø≈øions this Colony is de≈øcribed by the ≈øame Words, the Province of New-York, and the Territories depending thereon in America. "No Arguments need be u≈øed to prove, for it is ≈øelf evident their Maje≈øty's had ≈øome different Idea of the Province of New-York, than what had been before de≈øcribed by the Duke's Commi≈ø≈øions to his Lieutenant Governors, and a little attention to the original State of that Government, will explain that Difference. Our Authors further inform, Page 17, The Ran≈ø≈øelaer Family are not indebted to the Government of New-York for their E≈øtate, they continue to enjoy it by an Act of Ju≈øtice and not of Favour; it was originally a Dutch Colony of it ≈øelf, granted to their Ance≈øtors by the Dutch We≈øt-India Company, who held it as a Part of New Netherlands, under the States General. On the Surrender in 1664, their Rights were ≈øecured to
them in common with the re≈øt of the Inhabitants, by the before mentioned Article of Capitulation granted on the Surrender of the Country, by Col. Nichols, the Commander in Chief under the Crown, and Lieut. Governor under the Duke: the Faith of Government was pledged for their Security, and their E≈øtates were confirmed under the Seal of this Colony in the Year 1685, not by meer Act of the Provincial Governor and Council, but by an expre≈øs Order of King James the Second. They further inform Page 5th, ≈øo long ago as the Year 1685, King James the Second, by Letters Patent under that Seal granted to the Ran≈ø≈øelaer Family the Manor Ren≈øelaerwick, extending from Hud≈øon's River both on the Ea≈øt and We≈øt Sides Twenty-four Miles. This Manor includes the City of Albany, and extends near Twenty Miles to the Southward of it; South of which terminates the Province of New-York, expre≈ø≈øed in their Governor's Commi≈ø≈øions, ≈øo that this Manor is included in their ≈øecond Di≈øcription of Domain, viz. the Territories depending thereon, and exclu≈øive of this Clau≈øe in the Commi≈ø≈øions, antecedent to the forementioned Determination in 1764, the Governors of New-York cou'd not exerci≈øe Juri≈ødiction even in the Manor of Ren≈øelaerwyck, and much le≈øs to the Northward of it, as Settlements which lay Contiguous to tho≈øe Limits ≈øeemed nece≈ø≈øarily to fall under the Juri≈ødiction of that Government. Thus their territorial Sort of Dominion hath been extended without any Pre≈øcription or Limitation, agreeable to the Ob≈øervation of their celebrated Judge Smith, who,
≈øpeaking of that Government, ≈øaid it might well be accounted unlimitted.

IT may be further offered in Objection, on the Part of New-York, That allowing the foregoing Arguments relative to the Territories, and that Ren≈øelaerwyck was, before the AEra of the afore≈øaid Determination, in Fact annex'd to the Government by the territorial Clau≈øe in the Governor's Commi≈ø≈øions; yet, neverthele≈øs the Duke's Grant mu≈øt be valid to the Northward of that Manor, to all the Lands it originally covered. This cannot operate in Favour of New-York, for, in Addition to what has been before argued to this Purpo≈øe, the Reader is de≈øired to ob≈øerve, that King James. the Second, who was this ≈øame Duke of York, abdicated the Throne in 1688, and his E≈øtate reverted to the Crown of England, and this Grant became ve≈øted in the Crown, the ≈øame as though the Duke or his Grant had never had an Exi≈øtance.‚ÄîNor have any of their Governor's Commi≈ø≈øions, from Henry Slaughter, the fir≈øt Governor appointed by King William and Queen Mary, down to this pre≈øent AEra, ever been predicated on, or had the lea≈øt Reference to the Limits of that Grant.

div.head: SECTION VI.
div.p:
THE Government of New-York make the greate≈øt Outcry again≈øt her Si≈øter Colonies, taxing them with Intru≈øion, Violence and Encroachment; and, at the ≈øame Time, are flagrantly more guilty of
the ≈øame avaricious, unju≈øt, and ho≈øtile Wickedne≈øs than all the re≈øt of Engli≈øh America: Their capricious Land-Jobbers have a ≈øurpri≈øing Faculty in carrying their Points; at the ≈øame Time, they are encroaching upon their Neighbours, provided they meet with Oppo≈øition, they will cry out in the mo≈øt exagerating Exclamations, Violence, Riot, Trea≈øon, &c. and at the ≈øame Time, not he≈øitate to trample upon his Maje≈øty's Authority, (the Particulars of which may be ≈øeen in the preceding Narrative) They are great Advocates for Law, Order, and good Government; the≈øe are their Horns of Iron, and with them do they pu≈øh the Poor and Needy, when they get them into their Net. Their Way is as the Way of a Serpent upon a Rock, and it is difficult to trace their Foot≈øteps: They complain of the lawle≈øs, factious, and riotous Conduct of the Settlers under New-Hamp≈øhire; yet know, that they them≈øelves are the moving Cau≈øe of all the Di≈øturbances they complain of: It is incredible to ≈øuppo≈øe a Collection of Farmers expo≈øed to the perpetual Fatigues, and laborious Toils of cultivating a Wilderne≈øs Country, ≈øhould under a ju≈øt Admini≈øtration of Law, become "a Confederacy of In≈øurgents:" Was it only, that natural Pre≈øumption being ≈øo much in Favour of tho≈øe Inhabitants, it is humbly conceived, that all wi≈øe and unprejudiced Per≈øons will, at lea≈øt ≈øu≈øpend their Judgments concerning them, 'till the New-Yorkers can clearly evince, that the≈øe People are in reality, without Cau≈øe, tumultuous, di≈øorderly, &c. And, ina≈ømuch as the Facts of this Controver≈øy is ≈øo fully ≈øet forth in the preceding
Narrative of this Treati≈øe, the Reader is thereto refered for a clearer Exhibition.

OUR Authors, in Order to maintain their Claim to the Lands in Conte≈øt, and if po≈ø≈øible, to include it within One of the de≈øcriptive Limits of the Grant to the Duke of York, tell us many ≈øtrange Things about the Colonies of Connecticut and the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts: That Connecticut. "in legal Con≈øtruction" ≈øhould not have extended to the We≈øtward of Connecticut River, and that their Settlements We≈øt of that River were an Intru≈øion on the Right of the Colony of New-York; yet, neverthele≈øs for Peace ≈øake, and rather than conte≈øt with "a powerful Neighbour," they ≈øettled with that Colony at twenty Miles di≈øtance from Hud≈øon's River.

THEY further inform, that the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts Claim ≈øtands by no Means in ≈øo re≈øpectable a Light as that of Connecticut, and in legal Con≈øtruction, ≈øhould extend no further We≈øtward than 'till it meets the Colony of Connecticut, and not to Connecticut River, and much le≈øs to the We≈øtward of it. Our Authors being Men of great Learning and Sagacity; ≈øoon extended their antient Right of Juri≈ødiction over ≈øuch Part of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts Colony as lay to the We≈øtward from Connecticut River, and this their Scheme in ≈øtopping the We≈øtern Exten≈øion of that Colony where it meets Connecticut, may be reckoned as one among the greate≈øt of their political Atchievements. "And it is worthy a Remark," that had the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts Colony extended We≈øt to the South Sea,
it could not have met Connecticut, but mu≈øt have extended parallel with it, in the ≈øame Direction.

To give this plea≈øing Scheme ≈øome Kind of Colour, they argue the Nullity of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts fir≈øt Charter, and introduce the Duke of York's Grant as the olde≈øt Title, Page 5th, The Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts Charter was vacated, and the Title of that Colony now ≈øolely depends on their Charter of 1691.

YET they allow, that that Colony obtained the Right of Soil from the Council of Plymouth, and that the Charter of King Charles dated the 4th Day of March 1628-9, This is the Charter ≈øpoken of as vacated, which was done as has been before largely treated of, in 1684. ve≈øted them with Powers of Government, (it's needle≈øs to animadvert on the≈øe ≈øtrange Accounts) however, after they have charmed their Imaginations with the fruitle≈øs Idea of extending their antient Right to all that Part of the Bay Province We≈øt of Connecticut River, they complain bitterly of the Encroachments of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts, Page 8th. Under Circum≈øtances ≈øo favourable to the Rights of this Colony, we have great Rea≈øon to complain of the unwarrantable Encroachments under the Authority of the Government of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts-Bay, by which a valuable Tract extending from Connecticut River, within Twenty Miles of Hud≈øon's River, has been wre≈øted from us.

p.q: THEIR Conduct ≈øeems the more inexcu≈øable, as they mu≈øt have known that ≈øuch Encroachments were not only di≈øre≈øpectful to his Maje≈øty's Authority, and big with great Mi≈øchiefs and Di≈øorders, but were highly injurious to private Property, great Part of the≈øe Lands having antiently been granted to his Maje≈øty's Subjects under the great Seal of this Colony.

div.p: THEN they proceed to recite their old Grants, which they tell us cover the Country the whole Breadth of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øett's Claim: The Manor of Ren≈øelaerwyck, granted in 1685, and extending 24 Miles each Side, from Hud≈øon's River; and We≈øtonhook, in 1705, which extends about 30 Miles from Hud≈øon's River; and Hoo≈øick, in 1685, which extends about 30 Miles from the River. It ≈øeems to have been a political, and univer≈øal Principle with the Government of New-York, to begin their Patents within the Twenty Mile Line, and extend them Ea≈øtward of it, that by this Means they might have Opportunity to encroach on, and jockey their neighbouring Colonies, more or le≈øs, out of their Lands, as ≈øub≈øequent Policy, Intrigue and Power, would render practicable.

THAT Government, thus extended their Patent into Connecticut, One in particular, into the Town≈øhip of Sali≈øbury; and it has ever been their Practice to wrangle till they find by Experience, that neither by Sophi≈øtry, Law, or Ho≈øtility, they can maintain their exorbitant Claims, and then capitulate on as good Terms as they can; and conclude
with branding their Competitors with Di≈øhone≈øty, Encroachment and many hard Names, and don't ≈øcruple to impeach their Governmental Authority, (as in the Ca≈øe ju≈øt recited of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts-Bay) with being Di≈øre≈øpectful to his Maje≈øty's Authority, and guilty of great Mi≈øchiefs and Di≈øorders; although the Authority of their own Government, by their unju≈øt, avaricious Encroachments on the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts even to Connecticut River, laid the Foundation of tho≈øe Di≈øorders, and they might have added Blood-≈øhed; yet their A≈ø≈øembly have the Impudence to Palm it all upon the Authority of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts.

THE Claimants under New-Hamp≈øhire are ≈øo happy as to be almo≈øt exempted from any New-York Claims, by Patents from that Government prior to their's; the afore≈øaid Hoo≈øick and Wallum≈øcock Patents being the only ones of this Nature, the former includes about one Qaurter of the Town≈øhip of Pownal, on which Part were about four Settlers, when it was granted by New-Hamp≈øhire. This Town≈øhip is bounded Southerly by the North Line of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts-Bay, and extends We≈øt as far as the Connecticut and Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts Colonies; the latter, i. e. Wallum≈øcock Patent, was granted under the common Seal of the Province of New-York, the 15th Day of June, 1739. This Patent is ≈øaid to interfere with the Town≈øhip of Bennington, and it is Matter of Di≈øpute, whether in it's fir≈øt Location, it included more than about 30 or 40 Acres within that Town, tho' it ≈øeems the Patent by it's di≈øcriptive Limits, extends further into the Town,
and the Patentees produce a Map corre≈øponding with tho≈øe Limits: However, an Indian, aged Fifty-Nine, who was Pilot to the Party that located this Grant, informs of a certain Monument they then erected, where they broke a Bottle, &c. for their Ea≈øtern Bounds. "And it is worthy a Remark," that this Indian happens to be exactly of the ≈øame Age with Ebenezer Cole, one of our Author's principal Deponants. This Monument is well known by the Bennington People, and is on the We≈øtern Edge of the Town; and there has never been a Di≈øcovery of any Lines of the Survey of that Location to the Ea≈øtward of this Monument. The many Circum≈øtances of this Nature, amount to almo≈øt a Certainty, that the Patentees never made any actual Location further interfering with Bennington, than as afore≈øaid; notwith≈øtanding, as they have planned their patent, it includes about one Eighth Part of the Town; which Lands are exceeding good in Nature, and are ≈øettled wholly under the New-Hamp≈øhire Title, by indu≈øtrious Farmers, who form a Wilderne≈øs State, have cultivated and brought the mo≈øt of it under good improvements, with many valuable Hou≈øes, Barns and Orchards; ≈øome of them annually mowing at lea≈øt 80 Tons of Hay, and rai≈øe other Produce of the Country in Proportion. Not the lea≈øt Improvements or Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions were ever made in that Town, except by the≈øe Inhabitants; neither had they the lea≈øt Knowledge of a Pretence of any New-York Patents extending there till ≈øeveral Years after they had ≈øettled the Land. As has been before ob≈øerved, there was about four Settlers on that
Part of Hoo≈øick Patent, included in the Town≈øhip of Pownal, when it was granted; and if the Author has a right Information, there has not been any more Settlements made under the New-York Title ≈øince, though there hath ≈øundry Families ≈øettled on the Premi≈øes, included as afore≈øaid, under the New-Ham≈øhire Title.

As the State and Circum≈øtances of ≈øuch Part of the Town≈øhips afore≈øaid, as are included in the old Patents, are materially different, in many Re≈øpects, from the Circum≈øtances of the New-Hamp≈øhire Grants in general; it will therefore be nece≈ø≈øary that this Matter have a particular Con≈øideration; and that none of the afore≈øaid Arguments be con≈øidered in this Ca≈øe but what are truly applicable: and in this Review of the Ca≈øe, it will be admitted, that the old Wallum≈øcock Patent includes ≈øuch Part of Bennington, as the Plan the Patentees exhibit doth contain.

IT is taken for granted that the Royal Determination of the boundary Line in 1764 cou'd not extend the Government of New-York antecedent to the Date of that Order, which was a Manife≈øtation of Royal Power, and which was the ≈øole Cau≈øe of that Extention; therefore, at the Time the Government of New-York granted the forementioned old Patents, they could have no greater Authority for ≈øo doing than what they were then in Fact po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of: It remains therefore to be con≈øidered, whether the Patents from the Government of New-York are valid or not, ≈øo far as they interfere with the Town≈øhips
of Bennington and Pownal. And Fir≈øtly, it has been proved that the Province of New-York as di≈øcribed in their Governor's Commi≈ø≈øions, doth not extend ≈øo far North as the City of Albany; therefore, the Northern Tracts of Country which the≈øe Patents of Hoo≈øick and Wallum≈øcock cover, mu≈øt be con≈øidered as belonging to their ≈øecond Sort of Domain, (to wit) the Territories. It has al≈øo been ≈øhewn, that the≈øe Territories are not circum≈øcribed to any particular Limits, but that they were originally meant to include ≈øome ancient Grants that were Independent of the Province and adjoining Settlements, on Extra-provincial Lands: probably that Government may have Authority to grant Land to the We≈øt and North-We≈øt, where it is indi≈øputably unappropriated, and where the Claim of none other Government could interfere: But it will be in≈øi≈øted upon, on the Part of the New-Hamp≈øhire Settlers, which are included in the afore≈øaid old Patents, that the Government of New-York had no Right to extend any of their Patents to the Ea≈øtward of a Line equivalent to that which con≈øtitutes the Bounds between New-York and the Colonies of Connecticut and the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts: This Limit was ever thought by the People in general of the Colony of New-York, as well as tho≈øe of the adjacent Colonies, to be the Ea≈øtern Boundary of New-York, until the Aera of the late Determination, which extended it to the River Connecticut: and labouring Men that ≈øupport the World of Mankind, are obliged to form their Judgments of the Juri≈ødiction of Government's by the common received Opinions of Mankind they are conver≈øant with;
and even admitting they make an erroneous Judgment, yet, in the pre≈øent Ca≈øe, as the Lands were of but little Value, exclu≈øive of their Toil and Cultivation; and as the Farmers in Reality uphold the State, it is therefore not only incumbent on the Laws, but on the Policy of the State to defend them in Ca≈øes of this Nature‚Äîit mu≈øt be admitted that where the Limits of Governments are clearly a≈øcertained and notoriou≈øly known, that a Farmer tre≈øpa≈ø≈øing in this Manner on another's Property, mu≈øt bear the Lo≈øs: But, provided a Country of People be generally under a Deception as to Matters of Juri≈ødiction, and purcha≈øe Land and make great Improvements, and all on a mi≈øtaken Footing, Men in ≈øuch Circum≈øtances ≈øhould be con≈øidered in the mo≈øt favourable Light. For, as not only Individuals, but the Country about them were in the ≈øame Manner deceived, and therefore, at the Time of purcha≈øing and Settlement, they were utterly de≈øtitute of the Means of Knowledge; yet, however, it is not conceded to, that tho≈øe Farmers on who≈øe Account the pre≈øent Arguments are exhibited, are under a Deception about this Matter; for of all Sorts of governmental Juri≈ødiction, the New-York Territorial was the weake≈øt, loo≈øe≈øt and mo≈øt vague; it was rather occa≈øional and political, than po≈øitive, and in it's own Nature almo≈øt or quite incapable of being extended fa≈øter than Settlements were actually carried on, or at mo≈øt the Lands expo≈øed to this territorial Juri≈ødiction, ≈øhould not be patented fa≈øter than his Maje≈øty's Subjects are di≈øpo≈øed forthwith to ≈øettle. The Nece≈ø≈øity of granting ≈øo fa≈øt may be pleaded on Account of Order‚Äîthe
Policy of Government may demand it; otherwi≈øe an occa≈øional Juri≈ødiction would be altogether unable to abilitate the Government to make Conveyance of the Right in Fee; although it is indi≈øputable that ≈øuch a Juri≈ødiction in Matters of meer Government, is to all Intents and Purpo≈øes, equal to po≈øitive Juri≈ødiction; but with Re≈øpect to having a Power to convey the Fee of Lands, is Matter of Doubt: But thus much with Propriety may be inferred, that a Title ≈øo weak and impotent ≈øhould not claim Superiority over the lea≈øt Conception of Title whatever; a meer Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion is of it≈øelf abundantly ≈øufficient to maintain the Right in the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øor, and on a judicious Tryal at common Law, (cou'd ≈øuch an One be had) would be judged Paramount to it.

There is another Con≈øideration that mu≈øt totally extingui≈øh and obliterate all po≈ø≈øible remaining Idea of Right, that the Patentees of Wallum≈øcock may be ≈øuppo≈øed to have to the ≈øaid Tract of Land included in the Limits of the Town≈øhip of Bennington. Only advert to the Date of that Patent, which is on the 15th Day of June, 1739, and compare it with the Time of the Commencement of the Settlement of Bennington, which was in the Spring of the Year 1760, and there will be found to be 21 Years, from the Date of this Patent, to the beginning of the Settlement under New-Hamp≈øhire;‚Äîin all this Time there was not the lea≈øt Settlement or Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion made in the Premi≈øes; although the expre≈øs Condition of the Patent was, that it ≈øhould be ≈øettled in three Years from the Time of granting.
Po≈ø≈øibly in all that Time the Patentees might have got ≈øome Dutch Tenants on ≈øome We≈øtern Part of the Patent, which, with the Government of New-York, may be denominated a Fulfilment of the Condition of Settlement; many large Tracts having been patented, ≈øome ≈øince, and others longer ago than that Wallum≈øcock, which are yet mo≈øtly a howling Wilderne≈øs. This Practice of the Government of New-York, in extending their Patents to the Ea≈øtward of a Twenty Mile Line from Hud≈øon's River, hath ever been con≈øidered as a di≈øingenious and de≈øigning Policy in that Government; thereby to lay a Foundation for intruding on the Rights of their neighbouring Colonies; and has been attended with many di≈øagreeable Con≈øequences, as has been before ob≈øerved. And as that Government have given up their exorbitant Claims where they interfered with the Right of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts, it would undoubtedly be their wi≈øe≈øt Way to do the ≈øame with Re≈øpect to ≈øuch Claims as interfere with the Right granted under the great Seal of the Province of New-Hamp≈øhire; and in≈øtead of treating the People that have ≈øettled tho≈øe Lands under that Title, as Rioters and Felons; to exerci≈øe that Ju≈øtice and Humanity towards them, which becometh Governors, to the governed.

IT remains ≈øtill, that there be a ≈øummary View exhibited, relative to the Rule of Right which ≈øhould take Place with Re≈øpect to the Settlers under each Government, that are ≈øettled on ≈øuch Part of the forementioned Patents as are included in the Town≈øhips of Bennington and Pownal. And although
Superiority of Title is in Favour of tho≈øe under New-Hamp≈øhire; neverthele≈øs, as the Line of Juri≈ødiction, in tho≈øe Times of granting and Settlement, was not expre≈øly a≈øcertained or known.‚ÄîUnder the≈øe Circum≈øtances, it would not only be bad State-policy, but great Inhumanity and Inju≈øtice to the Subject; for either the Government of New-York or New-Hamp≈øhire to di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈øs them, let them have ≈øettled under the Title of either; for Titles liable to ≈øo much Di≈øpute and Uncertainty as both mu≈øt be confe≈ø≈øed to be (though One may have much the Preference of the Other) are not ≈øufficient to ou≈øt the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øor, ina≈ømuch as both challenge a legal Right; therefore, either Title, ≈øealed and confirmed with the Sweat and Toil of the Farmer is abundantly paramount to the Other.

OUR Authors, in their Appendix, Page 19th, mi≈ø-repre≈øent the Plea of the Bennington People, in ≈øaying, To rea≈øon on their own Principles, if Equity confirmed the Claims of Others under New-Hamp≈øhire, on Account of Priority of interfering Grants, it would have afforded a fatal Plea again≈øt the People of Bennington; becau≈øe they ought then them≈øelves to have yielded up all the Lands which are covered by more antient Patents. The People of Bennington, or rather the Claimants under New-Hamp≈øhire, have ever in≈øi≈øted, that at the Time the Government of New-Hamp≈øhire, granted tho≈øe Lands, they had good Right ≈øo to do; but that New-York had not. This Matter is illu≈øtrated and proved by many Arguments, and real Facts, in this Treati≈øe, particularly
in the 2d and 3d Sections, to which the Reader is referred. 'Tis true, provided the Bennington People had no further Con≈øiderations in the Matter of Title, but the Priority of interfering Grants‚Äîaccording to this Method of arguing, they ought to yield up ≈øuch Part of that Town as interferes with Wallum≈øcock Patent; but the Con≈øideration of Settlement is undoubtedly, with the many other Matters, material to be con≈øidered, as argued afore≈øaid.

div.head: SECTION VII.
div.p:
HAVING gone through with the Remarks on the New-York Pamphlet, ≈øo far as immediately re≈øpects the Title of tho≈øe Lands which has been the Principal Cau≈øe of the Publication of this Treati≈øe‚Äî≈øhall nextly proceed to detect ≈øome notorious and di≈øhonorable Mi≈ø-repre≈øentations contained in the Pamphlet afore≈øaid, particularly in the Appendix. In this brief Review, it would be too tedious, as well as needle≈øs, to trace the Authors through all their di≈øgui≈øed and fictitious Repre≈øentations, and intricate Windings. Shall therefore pa≈øs on with noteing ≈øuch of their Exhibitions as are the mo≈øt cruelly fallacious; among which the Story of the Extention of the Town≈øhip of Bennington, merely by a Vote of the Inhabitants, at a Town Meeting, to the We≈øtward from where it was intended to be granted, and within Seventeen Miles of Hud≈øon's River, is the mo≈øt flagrantly opprobrious. The Story may be ≈øeen recorded in the 4th Page of their Appendix. The Grantees of the Town≈øhip
of Bennington, di≈øcovered that the Situation of the Tract according to the Intention of the Grant, would be both inconvenient and unprofitable, as it included a large Proportion of Mountain; and they therefore, by no better Authority than a Vote of their Town Meeting, pre≈øumed to extend it to the We≈øtward, within Seventeen Miles of Hud≈øon's River.

As this Repre≈øentation in All and every Part is entirely groundle≈øs, and no Pretence of Proof to ≈øupport it, but is the meer calumnious A≈øper≈øion of tho≈øe who have an implacable Hatred to the Bennington People, a o≈øitive Denial of the Facts alledged, would be a ≈øufficient Refutation of tho≈øe Facts. Neverthele≈øs, as the A≈ø≈øembly of New-York have made a principal Engine of this infamous Story of their own Creation, to de≈øtroy the good Character of the People afore≈øaid, by repre≈øenting them to the Government at Home as the vile≈øt of In≈øurgents and Out-Laws‚Äîand ina≈ømuch as the Facts alledged are capable of Di≈ø-proof by mathematical Certainty, and ≈øundry Demon≈øtrations of this Sort having been actually made, (though not with a View of di≈øproving this Calumny, as it had not then been publi≈øhed,) by Admen≈øurations of the Di≈øtance from Hud≈øon's River, to the We≈øterly Line of Bennington, all of which agree that it is at lea≈øt Twenty Miles. Mr. Samuel Robin≈øon for once made an actual Men≈øuration of that Di≈øtance, and found it to be Twenty Miles and Thirty-five Chains; his Affidavit and Mr. Ebenezer Wood's, together with an atte≈øted Copy of the Survey of that Town
by Mr. Matthew Cle≈ø≈øon, the Surveyor, is thought Expedient to tran≈øcribe in it's following Order, which will abundantly ≈øerve to exculpate the People of Bennington from that Odium wherewith they have been branded. The Author is furthermore e≈øpecially directed by the Inhabitants of that Town, to reque≈øt the Government of New-York to vindicate what their A≈ø≈øembly have before alledged, by another accurate Men≈øuration of the Di≈øtance from Hud≈øon's River, to the We≈øterly Line of Bennington; and further notify that A≈ø≈øembly, that as omnipotent as they may conceive them≈øelves to be, they mu≈øt neverthele≈øs recede from the Calumny wherewith they have abu≈øed the Inhabitants of that Town, and do public Penance for the ≈øame, or continue under the Re≈øentment of tho≈øe Inhabitans: Which take an additional Affront at the ill U≈øage, ina≈ømuch as our Opponents tell us Page 3d, it is to be tran≈ømitted for the Information of the Government at Home; and further inform that it was to guard again≈øt the Impo≈øitions which from the Want of Candor, they were apprehen≈øive the ≈øaid Settlers, who ≈øpared no Art of Act of Violence, would by their Agents deceive the Government at Home, and therefore they had undertaken to tran≈ømit a Narrative of tho≈øe Settler's Proceedings, for the Information of that Government. It ≈øeems the ≈øaid A≈ø≈øembly fully re≈øolved that the Settlers and Agents from the Want of Candor, would endeavour artfully to deceive, &c. and that them≈øelves were as fully re≈øolved to over match them in a Game of that Sort, being greater
Practitioners than Pea≈øants: But artful as they are, they made a fatal Mi≈øtake in advancing for Matter of Fact that which in its own Nature is incapable of Proof, and what has been di≈øprov'd by Evidence of a mathematical Nature, and capable of further Di≈ø-proof by actual Men≈øuration. It is no Ways marvellous that tho≈øe Gentlemen which govern in that A≈ø≈øembly have an Antipathy again≈øt the Inhabitants of Bennington, who have had a great Share in defeating them in obtaining Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Country of the New-Hamp≈øhire Grants: It ≈øeems they are no in≈øen≈øible of their Merit, for, ≈øay they, it is to this Town≈øhip erected by a Charter in it≈øelf void, and ≈øo greatly abu≈øed, that we are to a≈øcribe all the Oppo≈øition which has ≈øince been given to the Juri≈ødiction of New-York. It is evident that the≈øe Gentemen have an evil Eye upon Bennington Inhabitants; for, when they mention the Oppo≈øition to their Juri≈ødiction, they take Care to repeat the afore≈øaid groundle≈øs A≈øper≈øion, by adding the≈øe Words, erected by a Charter in it≈øelf void, and ≈øo greatly abu≈øed. They ≈øtill proceed upon this their favourite Topic, and draw particular Inferrences from it to their advantage, for by changing the Situation of Bennington, it is made to comprehend a large Part of Wallum≈øcock, which was granted under the Seal of this Province ≈øo early as the Year 1739. This their ≈øcandalous A≈ø≈øertion is twice repeated in Page 8th. One of the Pa≈ø≈øages is as follows: Mr. Inger≈øoll, one of the mo≈øt eminent Coun≈øel in Connecticut, and Mr. Selve≈øter of Albany, were concerned for
the Defendants. When the≈øe Gentlemen found Breakenridge's Farm to be within Seventeen Miles of Hud≈øon's River, and greatly to the We≈øtward of what the Government of New-Hamp≈øhire had admitted to be the Juri≈ødiction of New-York‚Äîthey told him that it was impo≈ø≈øible to ≈øet up any Principle for his Defence. Accordingly, when his Ca≈øe was brought to Tryal, he refu≈øed to confe≈øs the Lea≈øe, Entry and Ou≈øture, agreeable to the Rule, and the Plaintiff being Non-≈øuited, obtained Judgment in the ≈øucceeding July Term, again≈øt the ca≈øual Ejector.

THIS is far from being the true State of the Ca≈øe. Sundry Cau≈øes which had been tried, were determined again≈øt the Claimants under New-Hamp≈øhire, and Mr. Breakenridge perceived it was expending Money to no Purpo≈øe, to maintain a Suit at Law again≈øt the New-York Patentees, as they had ≈øuch a Combination of Intere≈øt with the Judges, Part of which were intere≈øted in the New-York ≈øub≈øequent Patents, which interfered with the Grants under New-Hamp≈øhire, though not in tho≈øe on Tryal. This, with many other Things too tedious to particularize, was the Cau≈øe why Mr. Breakenridge would not defend the afore≈øaid Suit in Tryal; but there as not a Word ≈øaid, (as he informs me) between him and his ≈øaid Attornies, about his Farm's being within Seventeen Miles of Hud≈øon's River; nor is it likely never ≈øuch a Thing was mentioned in Albany County; the contrary being ≈øo well known. Undoubtedly, this was wrote "for the Information of Government at Home,"
thinking the Fallacy would not there be detected, it being at ≈øo great a Di≈øtance.

OUR Authors, P. 10th, after giving a Narrative of a riotous and tumultuous Outrage, committed by the Inhabitants of Bennington, for which Proclamation had i≈ø≈øued from the Earl of Dunmore, again≈øt the principal Authors of the Di≈øturbance "which could not be brought to Ju≈øtice," then they introduce a particular Charge again≈øt Mr. Breakenridge, which is entirely de≈øtitute of Foundation, viz. That he was One of the principal Rioters. To this they join the former Calumny of the We≈øtward Extention of Bennington, by a Vote of their Town Meeting; and add to both the≈øe, the groundle≈øs Story of Mr. Breakenridge's Council's Inability to ≈øet up any Principle in his Defence, by Rea≈øon of his being ≈øeated within Seventeen Miles of Hud≈øon's River. All the≈øe Fictions blended together, make con≈øiderable of a Figure, in their own Words, James Breakenridge and I≈øaiab Carpenter, were Two of the mo≈øt inexcu≈øable of all the Offenders: the fir≈øt had ≈øeated him≈øelf within Seventeen Miles of Hud≈øon's River, where he knew it was impo≈ø≈øible, on their own Principles, that he could be protected by the New-Hamp≈øhire Claim, he had declined a fair Tryal, and ≈øuffered Judgment by Default. With Re≈øpect to Mr. Breakenridge's being active in any Expeditions (the New-Yorkers denominate Riots, Mobs, Felony, &c.) it is well known thro' the Country of the New-Hamp≈øhire Grants, he has not. In the 18th and 19th Pages of the Appendix,
they repeat their former A≈øper≈øion again≈øt the Inhabitants of Bennington in the mo≈øt virulent and emphatical Language‚ÄîAnd what is ≈øtill more ≈øhameful, they contend, they arm, they ≈øight, for Lands, as a Part of Bennington, which lies within Seventeen Miles of Hud≈øon's River, and which the Government of New-Hamp≈øhire never claimed, but admitted to be beyond their Juri≈ødiction.

AS THERE can be no Doubt but the≈øe Gentlemen really wi≈øh the≈øe things to be true, and having ≈øo frequently repeated them as being ≈øo, it is conjectured they by this Time begin to believe them, or at lea≈øt think others may; but that the impartial Reader may have the real Truth of the Matter, the following Evidence is exhibited.

"A Plan of a Town≈øhip of Six Miles ≈øquare (i.e. Bennington) lying in his Maje≈øty's Province of New-Hamp≈øhire, laid by Matthew Cle≈ø≈øon, Surveyor, Abraham Ba≈øs, John Hooker, Ezekiel Fo≈øter, and Samuel Calhoon, Chainmen, in Pur≈øuance of an Order from his Excellency, Benning Wentworth, E≈øq Governor of ≈øaid Province, to Col. William Williams, lying Six Miles North of the Province Line that was run by Mr. Richard Hazzen, between ≈øaid Government, and the Province of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts-Bay, and Twenty Miles Ea≈øt of Hud≈øon's River, viz. Beginning at a crooked Hemlock Tree, mark'd W. W. Six Miles due North, or at a right Angle from ≈øaid Province Line, ≈øaid Angle commencing at a White Oak Tree in ≈øaid Line, mark'd M. ‚Ä°‚Ä° O.
I. T. which Tree is Twenty-four Miles Ea≈øt from Hud≈øon's River, allowing one Chain in Thirty for Swag, (which Allowance is made through the whole following Survey) and from ≈øaid Hemlock Tree We≈øt, ten Degrees, North four Miles, to a Stake and Stones; and from ≈øaid Stake and Stones North ten Degrees, Ea≈øt ≈øix Miles, to a Stake and Stones; from thence Ea≈øt ten Degrees, South ≈øix Miles, to a Stake and Stones; and from thence South ten Degrees, We≈øt ≈øix Miles, to a Stake and Stones; from thence We≈øt ten Degrees, North two Miles, to the Hemlock fir≈øt mentioned, which Survey was made November, 1749,

closer.signed: (A Copy.) Per MATTHEW CLESSON, Surveyor."

div.p: Matthew Cle≈ø≈øon, Surveyor, John Taylor, Ezekiel Fo≈øter, and William Williams, Chain-men, on November 3d, 1749, John Hooker, Abraham Ba≈øs and Samuel Calhoon, Chain-men, were all ≈øworn to the faithful Performance of the re≈øpective Services afore≈øaid, and for the above Survey.

closer.signed: Quorum, TIMOTHY DWIGHT, Ju≈øtice Peace. (A Copy.)

div.p:
THE Depo≈øition of Samuel Robin≈øon, who, being of lawful Age, ≈øaith, He being a Surveyor, hath laid out in Lots, a great Part of Bennington, and is confident that the We≈øt Line of ≈øaid Town is the Line that Matthew Cli≈ø≈øon run before the Town was granted (upon which ≈øaid Grant was made,) and as I have run all the Lands Ea≈øt, adjoining ≈øaid Line, and ≈øome on the We≈øt Side, I never knew of any other Line that was called, or known, or ≈øuppo≈øed to be the We≈øt Line of Bennington; but according
to that Line, the Proprietors have ≈øettled, not making any Improvements in the lea≈øt Degree to the We≈øt of ≈øaid Line.

AND the Deponent further ≈øaith, That his Excellency, Benning Wentworth, late Governor of New-Hamp≈øhire, gave a Warrant to Samuel Robin≈øon and George Gardner, E≈øq'rs, and John Davoow, to get the Line run and mea≈øured out, from Hud≈øon's River; which committee employed the Deponent as a Surveyor, with Timothy Abbot and John Drott, as Chainmen, who were under the In≈øpection of ≈øaid Committee, and under Oath, mea≈øured out from ≈øaid River Twenty Miles, according to the afore≈øaid Governor's Warrant; and then turning a right Angle North, ten Degrees Ea≈øt, which they did, and found the We≈øt Line of Bennington to be Ea≈øt of the Line your Deponent run, Thirty-five Chains; and ≈øo the Proprietors of ≈øaid Town concluded the afore≈øaid Cle≈ø≈øon Line to be right, and have conducted accordingly.

And further, your Deponent ≈øaith, John R. Blaker, E≈øq of the City of Albany, got ≈øome Chainmen ≈øoon after your Deponent had run the Line, and mea≈øured out, and told your Deponent that Bennington We≈øt Line, was more than Twenty Miles from Hud≈øon's River: And Archebald Campbell, of Albany, Deputy-Surveyor, told your Deponent, that he had mea≈øured out, and found it to be above Twenty Miles. And further ≈øaith not.

closer.signed: SAMUEL ROBINSON.
Sworn before me, in Hoo≈øick, the 29th March, 17 ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ JOHN MALCOMB, Ju≈øtice.

div.p: THE Depo≈øition of Ebenezer Wood, who being of lawful Age, ≈øaith: He being cho≈øen a Select Man for the Town of Bennington, and ≈øent to Perambulate the We≈øt Line of ≈øaid Town, which accordingly I did, which Line John R Blecker, E≈øq of the City of Albany, told your Deponent was more than Twenty Miles from Hud≈øon's River, which was the Line that Matthew Cle≈ø≈øon run; and your Deponent never ≈øee or heard of any other Line but that, for Bennington We≈øt Line. Further ≈øaith not.

closer.signed: EBENEZER WOOD.
Sworn before me in Hoo≈øick, the 29th Day of March, 1774. JOHN MALCOMB, Ju≈øtice.

div.p: IT may now be requi≈øite to give the Reader to under≈øtand, that although no Part of the Town≈øhip of Bennington interferes with a Twenty Mile Line from Hud≈øon's River; yet, it is probable ≈øome other of the We≈øterly Tear of Town≈øhips may in ≈øome Places, and in Others not approach it by a con≈øiderable Di≈øtance, which may be ea≈øily under≈øtood by the Windings of the River.

THE New-Hamp≈øhire Grants are bounded We≈øt on a Line commencing at the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts North-We≈øt old Corner, extending North ten Degrees, Ea≈øt till it reaches almo≈øt oppo≈øite to Ticondaroga, then extending We≈øt to the Lake. It is beyond Di≈øpute, con≈øidering the Cour≈øe and Windings of Hud≈øon's River, that there is as much or more Land included in the old ≈øuppo≈øed Government of New- „Äà‚óä„Äâ
by this Divi≈øion, as would be by extending a
Twenty Mile Line exactly parrallel with the River; it is al≈øo to be ob≈øerved, that where tho≈øe Grants, as above, extend We≈øt from this Line to meet the Lake, Hud≈øon's River is at lea≈øt Forty Miles to the We≈øtward.‚ÄîTherefore, upon this Hypothe≈øis, it may well be concluded, that, although ≈øome Towns may interfere with a Twenty Mile Line from the River, yet the Proprietors have neverthele≈øs equal Right to tho≈øe Lands with them who≈øe Town≈øhips do not interfere with that Line. Undoubtedly, again≈øt the Colonies of Connecticut and the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts Bay, this was the Ca≈øe; that in ≈øome In≈øtances New-York lo≈øt Land by the Windings of the River, in others it gained it ≈øo as to make it about equivalent to a Breadth Twenty Miles Ea≈øt from the River; had the Line commenced at that Di≈øtance from the River, and extended Equidi≈øtant to it, which would be a Line Difficult to a≈øcertain, and perpetuate.

THE Repre≈øentations our Authors have exhibited in the Thirteenth Page of their Narrative, relative to Cochran, Allen and Baker's di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing ≈øome People ≈øettled on a Tract granted to Mr. Farret, a reduced Lieutenant, which is in the We≈øtern Part of the Town≈øhip of Rupourt, and demoli≈øhing ≈øeveral Buildings, &c. are nearer the Truth, than mo≈øt of their Accounts; yet, as the real State of the Facts are materially different, in many Re≈øpects, and as Evidence of the≈øe Matters is procured, for Brevity's ≈øake ≈øhall pa≈øs over with in≈øerting it.

div.head: THE Depo≈øitions of Je≈ø≈øe Graves, Daniel Scott, and Enoch Ea≈øtman‚Äîis,
div.p:
THAT ≈øome Time in the Month of October 1771, We was in Company together in the We≈øterly Part of Rupourt, a Town≈øhip of the New-Hamp≈øhire Grants, and we perceived there was a Controver≈øy between the New-Hamp≈øhire Settlers of that Town≈øhip, and ≈øundry Per≈øons that had newly come to that Place, with Axes and Saws, and other Farmery In≈øtruments, to begin a new Settlement near the We≈øt Line of ≈øaid Town, and within the Limits of the ≈øame, under ≈øub≈øequent Patents, under the Grant of the Province of New-York, which laped on the Township afore≈øaid: And ≈øundry of the New-Hamp≈øhire Settlers of that Town were gathered together to the Number of about Nine, including Ethan Allen, and Remember Baker, which was not Inhabitants of ≈øaid Town; this Number of Per≈øons went to warn off Two Men, who≈øe Names were Todd, that was then at work on a Lot of Land laid out to Robert Cochran in ≈øaid Rupourt, and on the ≈øame Piece, where ≈øaid Cochran had partly cleared before, and had in his Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion: and we the Deponents went with the Party, having a Curio≈øity to ≈øee the Event, for we were informed that the Two Encroachers, viz. the Todds, had bid a Challenge again≈øt the New-Hamp≈øhire Settlers, and that they were provided with Arms, and had threatened the Life of the ≈øaid Cochran, and claimed the ≈øame Land by a ≈øub≈øequent Patent from the Governor of New-York: So the Party came to where the Two Per≈øons above named were at work, clearing Land, and warned them, to forthwith go off from the Premi≈øes, and they did accordingly.
And we found it true that the Two Encroachers was well furni≈øhed with Fire-Arms, and ≈øo was the Party of Nine Men that went to di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈øs them; expecting there would be near or quite as many to oppo≈øe them, but there was no Pretence of u≈øing Fire-Arms on either Side. After this, the Party of Nine Men went a little further, where another Per≈øon had began to build a Log-Hou≈øe on a Lot of Land belonging to a New-Hamp≈øhire Grantee in ≈øaid Town; the Logs were laid, and the Rafters fixed thereon for the Roof; the Per≈øon's Name that was building the ≈øame, was Hutchin≈øon, the Party afore≈øaid warned him off the Land; accordingly he departed the Town, but tarried to ≈øee the Logs he had collected together, pulled down, and laid in Four Heaps by the Party, and burned with Fire. After this, the Party advanced a little further, where one Reid had began a ≈ømall Improvement on a Piece of Land in the Town of Pollite, his Claim being al≈øo under New-York, on a ≈øub≈øequent Grant, where was a poor Shelter, four Crotches being drove into the Ground, and a Pole laid thereon, and Boughs added to the heap in Lieu of a Roof: This ≈øhiftle≈øs Fabrick was al≈øo con≈øumed by Fire by the ≈øame Party; and we the Deponents, were Eye-witne≈ø≈øes of the Fact before related; and directly after this, the Party di≈øper≈øed: But there was no Family di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed in the whole Affair, nor was there any that had moved on the Premi≈øes under Title from New-York. And further the Deponents ≈øay not. Taken and ≈øworn before me, one of His Maje≈øty's
Ju≈øtices of the Peace in and for the County of Charlotte, and Province of New-York, this 11th of March, 1774.

closer.signed: EBENEZER CLARK.

div.p: HAVING procured with much Difficulty ≈øome Evidence relative to a ≈øpirited Controver≈øy that hath for many Years ≈øub≈øi≈øted between Col Reid, of the City of New-York, and certain Claimants under New-Hamp≈øhire, about a Town≈øhip of Land called New-Haven, adjoining to the fir≈øt Falls on Otter-Croek, a little to the Northward of Crown-Point; a State of the ≈øame Controver≈øy, from the Commencement of it down to the Year 1772, was conveyed to Governor Tryon, a Copy of which has been tran≈øcribed in the Narrative, at the Beginning of this Treati≈øe. The pre≈øent Evidence will ≈øerve to ≈øupport the main Facts there alledged, as well as inform with Re≈øpect to ≈øome later Tran≈øaction of the ≈øame Controver≈øy, which by Turns has ≈øub≈øi≈øted to this Period. More Evidence would have been produced, not only relative to this Affair; but ≈øundry others, had it not been, that the Ju≈øtices at Crown-Point, refu≈øed to take any Affidavits in Behalf of the New-Hamp≈øhire Settler's, except tho≈ø√© hereafter in≈øerted, although they have been often thereto reque≈øted.

div.head: The Depo≈øition of James Hender≈øon and David Bridea, is as follows:
div.p:
THAT, on or about the 19th Day of June, 1773. we arrived from Scotland at New-York‚Äî≈øoon after
our Arrival, we met with Col. Reid, in New-York, who invited us to ≈øettle under him in the County of Charlette, on Lands which he ≈øaid he owned in that County. We being Strangers to the Country, and not knowing there was any Di≈øpute or Controver≈øy about Land in America, thought be≈øt to accept of his Offer; and accordingly agreed to go with him, on the following Terms, viz. That we ≈øhould have a Lea≈øe of our Land forever, with the fir≈øt ≈øeven Years free from Rent, and after that, Six Pence per Acre yearly, and to deliver to him at his Mill or Mills, the Tenth Part of our Grain yearly, and not to cut any Timber, ≈øave what the clearing our Lands required. On the afore≈øaid Agreement we ≈øet out from New-York, with ≈øaid Reid, and when we arrived at Fort Miller, we hear'd tho≈øe Lands that we agreed for, were in Di≈øpute; on which we went to ≈øaid Reid, and acquainted him, that if his Lands were in Di≈øpute, we rather cho≈øe to turn back, than to go any further; but he affirmed to us, that his Land was not in Di≈øpute, and that he would put us in peaceable Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and protect us there. On this Encouragement we went forward as far as Fort George, where we heard the News of the Di≈øpute again confirmed to us; on which ≈øome of our Company would have turned back, but Col. Reid refu≈øed to let them go, a≈ø≈øuring us that the Lands was not in any Conte≈øt, and that he would compel us to go forward. After this we went to Crown-Point, where we under≈øtood that the Land to which we were going, was granted to the Settlers that were on it by the Governor of New-Hamp≈øhire, and that they
would not give up their Title, it being antecedent to New-York Patents. After hearing that we ≈øhould have Trouble, we ab≈øolutely refu≈øed to go any further, telling Col. Reid that we did not come to America to fight for any Man's Title, nor to take away any Man's Property, and de≈øired we might go back to New-York; but he refu≈øed, alledging that we ≈øhould fulfil our Agreement, and, that there was a Parcel of Yankies, or New-England Men, ≈øettled all over America, without any Right or Title to their Lands, and he would put us in Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and defend us there. After this, he brought us to the Mouth of Otter Creek, and then he ordered every Man to load his Gun; but I, viz. James Hender≈øon, refu≈øed to load mine. Next Morning, at the Falls of ≈øaid Creek, he a≈øk'd me where my Firelock was? I replied, it was in the Battoe. Ay! Damn you! ≈øaid he, you dare not load your Firelock‚Äîyou will make a bad Soldier. After this we went to New-Haven, a Town above the Falls, where we found large Improvements made, and the New-Hamp≈øhire's actually in Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion with their Families, which Families ≈øaid Reid turned out, and put us, with the Re≈øt of our Company, in their Place‚Äîthen he ≈øaid, there was no further Danger, and went back and left us to keep Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of tho≈øe Hou≈øes and Improvements. Soon after this, came a large Number of armed Men which ≈øtiled them≈øelves the Green-Mountain-Boys, and they demanded of us if we were Reid's Settlers? We replied that we were. Then they informed us that their Bu≈øine≈øs was to di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈øs us, alledging that tho≈øe Lands were antecedently
granted to them by the Government of New-Hamp≈øhire, and that they would keep Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of them 'till his Maje≈øty's Plea≈øure was further known, Then they ordered our Goods and Effects to be taken out of the Hou≈øes, that none of them ≈øhould be hurt, which was done; and then they demoli≈øhed and burned the Hou≈øes, which were made with large Logs, but nothing of our Hou≈øhold Goods were burned. Next Day they pulled down a Gri≈øt Mill of ≈øaid Reid's, and there was a ≈ømall Stack of Hay burned; which they ≈øaid accidentally took Fire; and that if they could find out that any of their Men put Fire to it, they ≈øhould pay for the Hay; for, they ≈øaid, they did not approve that any of the Effects of the Earth ≈øhould be de≈øtroyed. Their Hor≈øes likewi≈øe de≈øtroyed ≈øome of the Wheat and Corn, but they did not otherways abu≈øe our Per≈øons, Effects or Families; neither did they exclaim again≈øt governmental Authority, but con≈øtantly affirmed that they would maintain their Property, and defend it from the Incur≈øion of Col. Ried, or any other Claims from New-York, until his Maje≈øty's Plea≈øure ≈øhould be further known. And further we the Deponents ≈øay not.

closer.signed: Sworn before me at Crown-Point, 17th March, 1774. THOMAS SPARHAM, Ju≈øtice Peace.

div.p:
THE Deponent, Jo≈øeph Pangbun, jun. ≈øaith, That in the Month of Augu≈øt, 1766 or 7, Col. Reid accompanied by Adolphus Benzel, and ≈øeveral Others, did come to Otter Creek, to the Dwelling Place of him, the ≈øaid Jo≈øeph Pangbun, where the ≈øaid Deponent had lately built a Saw-Mill, and forcibly did
di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈øs the ≈øaid Deponent, and by Force did put the ≈øaid Col. Reid in Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øaid Saw-Mill, together with a large Quantity of Logs and ≈øaw'd Boards, which he the ≈øaid Col. Reid did convert to his own U≈øe, to the utter Undoing of the Deponent, and that he the ≈øaid Deponent, was kept out of his Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion ≈øix Years, or upwards, when he recovered his Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, but was in a ≈øhort Time by the ≈øaid Col. Reid, again di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, and reduced to the la≈øt Extremity. That the ≈øaid Deponent had a legal Right to the Saw-Mill and Land; they were his own Proper E≈øtate, as granted and given, by Charter to a certain Number of Proprietors, by his Maje≈øty's Governor, his Excellency, Benning Wentworth, then Governor of his Maje≈øty's Province of New-Hamp≈øhire.

WHEREAS I the ≈øaid Deponent, have made Application to all his Maje≈øty's Ju≈øtices of the Peace at Crown-Point, and cou'd not obtain an Affidavit of the above Circum≈øtances, I the ≈øaid Deponent do, in Pre≈øents of the ≈øub≈øcribing Witne≈ø≈øes, aver the above to be the Truth, the whole Truth, and nothing but the Truth. So help me God.

closer.signed: JOSEPH PANGBUN, jun.

div.head: SECTION VIII.
div.p:
OUR Authors in the Twenty Seventh and fini≈øhing Page of their Narrative, di≈øcover great Invention and Subtilty, who after giving an Account of the unfortunate Circum≈øtances of the Town of Hin≈ødale which has, ≈øay they, been taken up by a Royal Mandamus. This Town≈øhip had fir≈øt been granted by the Government of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts Bay, and upon the Settlement of the Boundary-Line between the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts and New-Hamp≈øhire in 1739, it fell within the latter, and by them granted, and fully ratified to the Inhabitants and Proprietors, who in Addition to their Title, had al≈øo the Indian Right. This Town≈øhip, by the Determination of the Boundary Line between New-York and New-Hamp≈øhire, fell within the Juri≈ødiction of the former, and was by them granted to Col. Howard, after it had been ≈øettled about Seventy Years. The A≈ø≈øembly of New-York in Order to ≈øcreen their Government from the Imputation of the Blame ju≈øtly due to ≈øo reprehen≈øible a Conduct, endeavour to palm it on the Government at Home, ≈øee Page Sixth, with Re≈øpect to Hin≈ødale, a Town≈øhip in the South Ea≈øt Corner of Cumberland County: Even this is not to be a≈øcribed to our Government, it proceeded from a much greater, and the highe≈øt Authority: A Mandamus was produced from the Crown, on the Report of the Board of Trade, and by the Advice of the Privy Council, which ve≈øted the Grantee with a Right of Election, an Act deci≈øive in it≈øelf, and ≈øuperceding
the Agency of the Governor and Council here, and the u≈øual Forms. A very Extraordinary Repre≈øentation! The Nature of a Royal Mandamus is diametrically oppo≈øite to this Interpretation: The Right of Election in the Grantees, is re≈øtricted entirely to Crown Lands which are unapropriated; in ≈øuch Lands, the Grantee has a Right of Election, and common Sen≈øe may teach, that neither a Mandamus or any other Crown Grant can ≈øubvert the Property which the Subject holds under the Crown by Prior Grants; and, though there be ever ≈øo many Alterations in the Juri≈ødiction, ≈øundry of which have perplexed the Town of Hin≈ødale, yet this ≈øhould have no Effect on the Property of the Subjects.‚ÄîThe≈øe Grantees are likewi≈øe withheld from interfereing on the Right of the Indian Subjects.‚ÄîYet, it ≈øeems Col. Howard had the Vanity to locate his Mandamus on the old Plantation of Hin≈ødale, which was fir≈øtly appropriated by a Purcha≈øe from the Indians, ≈øecondly, by a Grant from the Government of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts Bay, and thirdly, by the Government of New-Hamp≈øhire, and fourthly, by an uninterupted Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion and Occupancy about Seventy Years.

THE Subterfuge the Gentlemen make U≈øe of, to rid their Government from Di≈øhonour, in making this la≈øt Grant of Hin≈ødale, is very extraordinary; it ≈øeems not well calculated to be tran≈ømitted for the Information of the Government at Home! who are undoubtedly competent Judges of their own Mandamus's, and no
Doubt will ea≈øily di≈øcern their La≈øt Error to be wor≈øe than the Fir≈øt. Such prepo≈øterous granting of Lands, is Criminally injurious to the Subject, as it never fails to embarra≈øs the different Claimants with many concomitant Difficulties. Yet, ≈øtill to ca≈øt the Blame due to their Government, on the King's Mandamus, is more daringly injurious to the highe≈øt Authority in the Nation.

LASTLY, the manner of Redre≈øs pre≈øcribed for the Sufferers, viz. the old Proprietors of Hin≈ødale, is the mo≈øt ≈øhocking Piece of Contrivance, Page 27, Hin≈ødale, a ≈ømall Town≈øhip which has lately been taken up by Virtue of a Royal Mandamus, is alone unfortunate‚Äîbut even here the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øors may be relieved, by a ≈øuitable Compen≈øation, equal to the Value of their Improvements in Crown Lands, free from the Expence of Fees. The≈øe Gentlemen in their great Clemency have al≈øo conceded that the New-Hamp≈øhire Settlers in general may be thus con≈øidered, On the ≈øame Terms, may be a≈ø≈øigned to each of tho≈øe who are ≈øeated on the Soil, actually appropriated to others by the Government of New-York, and the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions of which cannot for that Rea≈øon be confirmed; ≈øuch a Proportion of Crown Lands, as the Governor and Council ≈øhall judge to be adequate to their re≈øpective Improvements.

THEN they proceed to de≈øcribe the Tract, A Fertile and exten≈øive Country, in the northern
