Part of the County of Charlotte, and between Connecticut River and Lake Champlain, ≈øtill remains unpatented by either Government; and might be planted and cultivated by the≈øe People:‚ÄîWhat a ≈øurpri≈øing Conde≈øcention this! the Po≈øterity of the Original Proprietors of Hin≈ødale, e≈øpecially, to be allowed the Privilege to pull up Sakes, quit their Farms and Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, Hou≈øes, Orchards, &c. and join Company with the New-Hamp≈øhire Settlers in general, and trudge off to the North-Ea≈øt Part of the Wilderne≈øs of Charlotte, and there commence another Settlement, leaving their plea≈øant Habitations, Fields, Tenements, and Country, in Exchange for a howling Wilderne≈øs; a pretty Exchange!‚Äîand this to gratify a number of New-York Cormorants. But, let's ≈øtop a little and con≈øider‚Äîwhether it would not be more Righteous to change the Scene, and ≈øo the New-York Patentees remove their Patents, that interfere with the New-Hamp≈øhire Grants, and lay them in the Wilderne≈øs of Charlotte, as neither Government have appropriated it.

A ≈øufficient Rea≈øon to be offered in favour of the latter of the≈øe Projects, is, that the Settlers under New-Hamp≈øhire, are in Deed, and in Truth the right and lawful Owners and Proprietors of the Lands they po≈ø≈øe≈øs, as, 'tis apprehended, has been fully demon≈øtrated in the preceding Sections. Although the≈øe Gentlemen have, in the Cour≈øe of their Narration, flung out very extraordinary Hints of rewarding his Maje≈øty's Soldiery,
by the Di≈øtribution of tho≈øe Lands, yet, they may here again be reminded, (which may further ≈øerve as the above Rea≈øon) that his Maje≈øty's Proclamation directed the Soldiery to make their Pitches on unappropriated and vacant Lands; this therefore, they mu≈øt do, at the Hazard of lo≈øing their Grants, or repitching. For tho≈øe Lands which being antecedently granted by the Crown, by the Agency of the Governor and Council of New-Hamp≈øhire, mu≈øt forever exclude the Soldiery from pitching thereon; and put it entirely out of the Power of the Government of New-York, or the Crown, to grant them to a Second Per≈øon. And when it is con≈øidered, that the New-York Land-Jobbers have, long ≈øince purcha≈øed great Part of the Soldiery Rights, and that for a mere Trifle, and laid them out of them≈øelves, at their own Ri≈øque; their Arguments on that Subject, cannot contribute greatly to the Removal of the New-Hamp≈øhire Settlers, to the exterior Part of Charlotte.

OUR Authors have given a tedious Hi≈øtory of the Suits at Law, which have been commenced, by the New-York Patentees, again≈øt the Claimants, and Occupants under New-Hamp≈øhire, and have exhibited many ≈øpecious Appearances of Fairne≈øs, Equity, and Impartiality in their Tryals. However, the Reader mu≈øt ob≈øerve, that in every of tho≈øe, ≈øo boa≈øted of, candid Tryals, the Defendants, by the Re≈øult, were to be di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈øsed of their Farms. They then continue to tell of the entire Satisfaction of the Vanqui≈øhed, (together
with ≈øuch or the New-Hamp≈øhire Claimants at attended the Courts) relative to the Validity of the New-York Title.‚ÄîSoon after this, they give a ≈øurpri≈øing Account of Riots and Outrages, committed by the≈øe Settlers, and mention Allen by Name, (who they ≈øay, but a little before was ≈øo fully per≈øuaded of the Validity of the New-York Title) as one of their Leaders. This Narrative is in it≈øelf incredible, it cannot be ≈øuppo≈øed, that Men who were convinced, they had had an impartial Tryal at Law, and of the In≈øufficiency of their own Title, and the Authenticity of that of their Opponents, would rally to arm, in Defiance of legal Authority, and in Defence of their own invalid Title; e≈øpecially, after they had publickly declared their own Sentiments concerning that Matter.

THIS A≈ø≈øembly ≈øeem profu≈øely lavi≈øh in the Prai≈øe of their own Government, concerning the Genero≈øity, Forbearance and Humanity, &c. they have exerci≈øed towards the New-Hamp≈øhire Settlers; and that nothing of that Sort may here pa≈øs unnoticed, but that every Act, by them done, worthy of ≈øuch Appellations, may be duly acknowledged; it will be freely confe≈ø≈øed that Governor Tryon, and the Majority of his Maje≈øty's Council, conducted with Honour and Humanity toward them; while his Excellency was in the Admini≈øtration, except in pa≈ø≈øing ≈øome very extraordinary Laws on the 9th of March, 1774, which may be ≈øeen in the fore Part of this Treati≈øe, under the Head of the Narrative: But tho≈øe Settlers mu≈øt have that
Charity for his Excellency, as to conclude he, would not have put his Sanction to tho≈øe Laws, had he not known the ≈øaid Settlers called the Green Mountain-Boys to be very expert with Fire-Arms and likewi≈øe very good Wood≈øers; and con≈øequently, that the New-York Land-jobbers cou'd not put the≈øe Laws in Execution. To view this Matter in any other Light, they would be obliged to di≈øtru≈øt the Fidelity of their worthy Friend Governor Tryon. But to return to the Subject of Genero≈øity. The A≈ø≈øembly of New-York are unwi≈øe to make ≈øo great a Bu≈øtle about this Matter, ina≈ømuch as they have ≈øpoiled the Joke them≈øelves, by their ≈øo infamous a Propo≈øal of Accommodation, which as has been before ob≈øerved, is, that the New-Hamp≈øhire Settlers remove to the Wilderne≈øs of Charlotte, in Order to gratify a certain Fraternity with the Country they have with much Toil and Expence ≈øubdued: We have a very beautiful Repre≈øentation of this New-York Beneficence by a wi≈øe Author, the tender Mercies of the Wicked are Cruelty.‚ÄîNow follows another Quotation from our Authors, which is no le≈øs than a barefaced In≈øult on tho≈øe Inhabitants, and one of the bolde≈øt of Mi≈ørepre≈øentations. If the New-Hamp≈øhire Claimants imagined that they were aggrieved by the Deci≈øions of our Judges, the Means of Redre≈øs were in their own Power; and they ought to have ≈øued their Writs of Error, and in the legal and ordinary Mode, to have referred their Cau≈øe to the final Sentence of his Maje≈øty: But to expect a Remedy incompatible with the Admini≈øtration of Ju≈øtice, and the Rights of the
Subject, either be≈øpeak the greate≈øt Ignorance, or Pre≈øumption.

COULD they once get this e≈øtabli≈øhed, that there ≈øhould be no Acce≈øs to his Maje≈øty, or Trial, but in this "ordinary Mode," it would no doubt, be to their entire Satisfaction; Tryals in that Government would then ea≈øily become deci≈øive; for in no Ca≈øe, wherein the Demand of the Plaintiff is below the Sum of Five Hundred Pounds, a Writ of Error in Favour of the Defendant can i≈ø≈øue. And the New-York Attornies who compiled the New-York Statings, and are al≈øo Patentees under that Government, well knew that every Action brought again≈øt the New-Hamp≈øhire Claimants has been de≈øignedly laid below that Sum. Yet they were po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of that extreme Boldne≈øs to aver in expre≈øs Terms, that, if the New-Hamp≈øhire Claimants imagined, that they were aggrieved, by the Deci≈øions of their Judges, their Means of Redre≈øs were in their own Power. i. e. by Way of a Writ of Error.

THERE is nothing exhibited in this New-York Pamphlet which more ≈øen≈øibly de≈øerves Re≈øentment than their Preten≈øions of Indulgencies, Favours, &c. conferred on the≈øe Claimants by that Government‚ÄîTo the Honor of the Government of New-York, it may ju≈øtly be a≈ø≈øerted, that the New-Hamp≈øhire Claimants have received every Mark of Favour and Indulgence which the Circum≈øtances permitted. Such Hypocri≈øy deba≈øes
Human Nature, is the Pe≈øt of Society, partakes of Fal≈øhood and Treachery; and what renders it peculiarly vile, is, that it u≈øurps the Seat of Virtue, and de≈øtroys Faith in Communities, and is the Source of cruel Jealou≈øy. Had the Government of New-York been truly friendly to tho≈øe Settlers, it had been return'd again; and mutual Good Will ≈øupplied the Place of Hatred an Strife. But, alas! ≈øo long as the Fee of the Country of the New Hamp≈øhire Grants is the Object in View, by the Government of New-York, how it is po≈ø≈øible for Peace and good Order to take Place, can't well be conceived. Well would it be for that Government, and infinitely better for the Settlers under New-Hamp≈øhire, were they annexed to ≈øome other Government; but they ≈øay, No. Quere, Why? The An≈øwer is ea≈øy. They would then loo≈øe Sight of the afore≈øaid de≈øirable Object: Otherwi≈øe, ≈øurely they would be glad to part with ≈øuch rebellious Subjects as they repre≈øent them to be. For the Truth no Doubt is, that they are in Hopes ≈øome better Fortune may in future, attend them. And that they can take and execute ≈øome of the leading Men among the≈øe Inhabitants; and ≈øo frighten and impo≈øe on the Re≈øt; and finally, by this Means, avail them≈øelves of their E≈øtates and Property. This is all they can de≈øire in continuing this Country under their Juri≈ødiction. That they have in Reality a View to this, will further appear, by ≈øome memorable Sentences recorded in the 25th Page of their Appendix. "We may," ≈øay they, readily conceive, that Breakenridge, and his Party, have abundant Rea≈øon to wi≈øh
for an Alteration of Juri≈ødiction. The public Crimes, and private Wrongs which they have perpetrated, mu≈øt make them look forward to the Hour of Tranquility, with the mo≈øt anxious Apprehen≈øions. The injured may then demand Satisfaction for all their Sufferings.‚ÄîAn Atonement mu≈øt then be made to the Country, for the Violation of it's Laws. Here the New-Hamp≈øhire Settlers may read their intended Doom, in Con≈øequence of the Ability of the Government of New-York. And one Rea≈øon why this Government have not already de≈øtroyed the Inhabitants of the New-Hamp≈øhire Grants, with Fire and Sword, is their Want of Ability; and this Inability, in great Part, con≈øi≈øts in this, that the common People in the Government, are univer≈øally of Opinion that the Inhabitants have a good Right to tho≈øe Lands, and ≈øhould not be mole≈øted in the peaceable Enjoyment of them; and con≈øequently will not a≈ø≈øi≈øt their Civil Officers, in taking Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of their Tenements, or them as Rioters. That they are no further turbulent than what is nece≈ø≈øary to defend their Per≈øons and Properties, from the Cruelty and Monopoly of their Rulers. This is the Ground of all the Lenity, Forbearance and Indulgence of that Government towards tho≈øe Inhabitants; and it is hoped, if the≈øe exce≈ø≈øive Favours ≈øhould be pa≈ø≈øed over without their Thanks, they may yet be excu≈øed for the Neglect.

FURTHERMORE, tho≈øe Gentlemen, after having thus ≈øoon out their in ≈øulcible Complaints, crown the Whole in Page 25th. That they, i. e. the
New-Hamp≈øhire Settlers, may in Nothing „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ of Character, they have appointed James Breakenridge, (whom we have ≈øo often mentioned) a Fugitive from Ju≈øtice, and who has rendered him≈øelf ≈øo obnoxious as to become the immediate Subject of a Proelamation‚Äîas one of their Agents. What a mon≈øtrous Crime is here!‚ÄîHas Mr. Breakenridge rendered him≈øelf obnoxious to Puni≈øhment in the Government of New-York? O ≈øtrange! Such a pacific Government too!‚ÄîBut what has he done? He has never, (notwith≈øtanding all their In≈øinuations) been active in any Riots (as they term them) occa≈øioned by this Controver≈øy; but is become the Subject of a Proclamation‚Äîyet ≈øtill, what Evil has he done? As tho≈øe Gentlemen have not obliged the Public with an Information, the Author can ≈øupply their Defect. This Gentleman was one of the fir≈øt Settlers on the New-Hamp≈øhire Grants; and has had a great Share in the political Oeconomy of that Country, is a Man of Probity and Stedfa≈øtne≈øs in Principle, and ble≈ø≈øed with ≈øtrong Power of Ponderation, and has gained, as well as merited the E≈øteem of the≈øe Settlers. He was by them cho≈øen as Agent to repre≈øent their di≈øtre≈ø≈øed Cau≈øe to the Right Honourable the Earl of Dartmouth, Pre≈øident of the Board of Trade; and al≈øo, to implore his Maje≈øty to interpo≈øe his Royal Authority, and relieve his oppre≈ø≈øed Subjects.‚ÄîHe approached his Lord≈øhip, with a Repre≈øentation of the Conduct of the Government of New-York, towards his Con≈øtituents, and ≈øollicited his Lord≈øhip's Aid and A≈ø≈øi≈øtance, in Behalf of the Sufferers. He was received with Expre≈ø≈øions of Kindne≈øs,
and when he had laid the Facts of the Cau≈øe before his Lord≈øhip, and ≈øub≈øtituted an Agent at London, and put the Cau≈øe in Readine≈øs for a final Tryal, before his Maje≈øty in Privy Council, returned to America; having done all Things to the great Satisfaction of his Employers.‚ÄîSince his Return from Great-Britain, he has made his Abode at his own Hou≈øe in Bennington, (which is not within Seventeen Miles of Hud≈øon's River,) although "a Fugitive from Ju≈øtice,"‚Äîmaking further Preparations for the deci≈øive Trial depending before his Maje≈øty, and comforting the Inhabitants, with the Hopes of his mo≈øt gracious Deliverance. The≈øe are the Things which have ≈øo exa≈øperated the Government of New-York, again≈øt this good and worthy Man.

AS THE De≈øign of this Section was, in a conci≈øe Manner, to point out ≈øome of the mo≈øt notorious Extravagancies of the Government of New-York, the Subject can't with Propriety be pa≈ø≈øed over, without taking a ≈øhort Review of the forementioned Laws of that Colony, which are the mo≈øt apparent Portraiture of their horrid Malevolence and Caprice. Pa≈ø≈øing the≈øe Laws, which are evidently calculated with a De≈øign of extirpating the Inhabitants, by them Laws alluded to, from their goodly Land, nay, from the Face of the Earth; is no le≈øs than lavi≈øhly foaming out their own Shame; Laws that ought, and are contemned and di≈øregarded by every Lover of Virtue. Laws and Society-Compacts were originally de≈øigned to protect the Subjects in their Property. Loyalty and Subordination to
≈øuch Government, is e≈ø≈øentially nece≈ø≈øary, for the Good of Society, and all good and liege Subjects will ≈øupport ≈øuch Laws and Legi≈ølators. But, as in the pre≈øent In≈øtance, when Laws, in their original De≈øign and Admini≈øtration, are degenerated from the good Ends for which Laws and Government were in≈øtituted, terminating in the Ruin and De≈øtruction of the Society it ≈øhould ≈øecure & protect; from the ≈øame Principles, viz. Self-pre≈øervation, the Subjects are obliged to re≈øi≈øt, and depo≈øe ≈øuch Government. And, ina≈ømuch as tho≈øe Laws, together with ≈øome Remarks on them, are to be ≈øeen in the Narrative Part of this Performance, ≈øhall therefore conclude, with leaving the Reader, from his own Meditations, to pa≈øs ≈øuch Sentence concerning this Matter as may appear rea≈øonable.

div.head: SECTION IX.
div.p: IT may be of ≈øome Moment, towards the Clo≈øe of this Treati≈øe, to exhibit a Number of ≈øpecial Motives which induced tho≈øe Inhabitants to pro≈øecute Settlements on the controverted Premi≈øes. As,
FIRST, On the good Faith of his Maje≈øty's Grants, by the Agency of the Government of New-Hamp≈øhire, the Validity of which has been ≈øufficiently argued. And,
SECONDLY, by Engagement from a Proclamation by his late Excellency Benning Wentworth, which, for the more public Information, is here in≈øerted.

div.byline: By His EXCELLENCY, BENNING WENTWORTH, E≈øq Captain-General, Governor and Commander in Chief of His Maje≈øty's Province of New-Hamp≈øhire, in New-England, &c.
div.head: A PROCLAMATION.
div.p: WHEREAS his Honor, CADWALLADER COLDEN, E≈øq Lieutenant-Governor, and Commander in Chief of his Maje≈øty's Province of New-York, bath lately i≈ø≈øued a Proclamation, of a very extraordinary Nature, ≈øetting forth, that King CHARLES the Second, on the 12th Day of March, 1663-4, and the 29th June, 1674, did, by his ≈øeveral Letters Patent, of tho≈øe Dates, grant in Fee to his Brother, the Duke of York, among other Things, all the Land from the We≈øt Side of Connecticut River to the Ea≈øt Side of Delaware Bay; and therein al≈øo ≈øet forth, and de≈øcribes the Bounds of New-Hamp≈øhire; in which Di≈øcription there is a very material Mi≈øtake; be≈øides, there is omitted the Fact, on which the Di≈øcription of New-Hamp≈øhire depended, viz. His Maje≈øty's Determination of the North and We≈øtern Boundaries of the Province of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts-Bay, in 1739. And nothing can be more evident, than that New-Hamp≈øhire may legally extend her We≈øtern Boundary as far as the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts Claim reaches, and ≈øhe claims no more; but New-York pretend to claim even to the Banks of Connecticut River, although ≈øhe never laid out and ≈øettled one Town in that Part of his Maje≈øty's Lands, ≈øince ≈øhe exi≈øted as a Government.

When New-York Government extends her Ea≈øtern Boundary, to the Banks of Connecticut River, between New-York and the Colony of Connecticut; and
to the Banks of ≈øaid River, between New-York and the Province of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts-Bay, it would have been full early for New-York to declare that the Government of New-Hamp≈øhire was fully appri≈øed of the Right of New-York, under the before recited Letters Patent to the Duke of York. In Virtue of the final Determination of the Boundary Lines ≈øettled by his late Maje≈øty, between this Government and the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts-Bay, all the Lands capable of Settlements, have been erected into Town≈øhips, agreeable to his Maje≈øty's Commands, and a con≈øiderable Revenue is daily ari≈øing to the Crown, unle≈øs interrupted and impaired by his Honor's Proclamation, which New-Hamp≈øhire will not be an≈øwerable for.

At pre≈øent, the Boundaries of New-York, to the Northward, are unknown, and as ≈øoon as it ≈øhall be his Maje≈øty's Plea≈øure to determine them, New-Hamp≈øhire will pay ready and chearful Obedience thereunto, not doubting but that all Grants made by New-Hamp≈øhire, that are fulfilled by the Grantees, will be confirmed to them, if it ≈øhould be his Maje≈øty's Plea≈øure to alter the Juri≈ødiction.

For political Rea≈øons, the Claim to Juri≈ødiction by New-York, might have been deferred, as well as the ≈øtrict Injunction on the Civil Power, to exerci≈øe Juri≈ødiction in their re≈øpective Functions, as far as the Ea≈øtern Banks of Connecticut River.

The ≈øaid Proclamation carrying an Air of Government in it, may po≈ø≈øibly affect and retard the Settlement of his Maje≈øty's Lands, granted by this Government: For preventing an Injury to the Crown, of this Kind, and
to remove all Doubts that may ari≈øe to Per≈øons holding the King's Grants, they may be a≈ø≈øured, that the Patent to the Duke of York is ob≈øolete, and cannot convey any certain Boundary to New-York, that can be claimed as a Boundary, as plainly appears by the ≈øeveral Boundary Lines of the Jer≈øies on the We≈øt, and the Colony of Connecticut on the Ea≈øt, which are ≈øet forth in the Proclamation, as Part only of the Land included in the ≈øaid Patent to the Duke of York.

To the End therefore, that the Grantees now ≈øettled and ≈øettling on tho≈øe Lands, under his late and pre≈øent Maje≈øty's Charters, may not be intimidated, or any Way hindered or ob≈øtructed in the Improvement of the Lands ≈øo granted, as well as to a≈øcertain the Right, and maintain the Juri≈ødiction of His Maje≈øty's Government of New-Hamp≈øhire, as far We≈øtward as to include the Grants made:

I HAVE thought fit, by and with the Advice of of His Maje≈øty's Council, to i≈ø≈øue this Proclamation, hereby encouraging the ≈øeveral Grantees, claiming under this Government, to be indu≈øtrious in clearing and cultivating their Lands, agreeable to their re≈øpective Grants.

AND I do hereby require and command all Civil Officers, within this Province, of what Quality ≈øoever, as well tho≈øe that are not, as tho≈øe that are Inhabitants on the ≈øaid Lands, to continue and be diligent in exerci≈øing Juri≈ødiction in their re≈øpective Offices, as far We≈øtward as Grants of Land have been made by this Government;
and to deal with any Per≈øon or Per≈øons, that may pre≈øume to interrupt the Inhabitants or Settlers on ≈øaid Lands, as to Law and Ju≈øtice doth appertain, the pretended Right of Juri≈ødiction mentioned in the afore≈øaid Proclamation notwith≈øtanding.

By His Excellency's Command, with Advice of Council, T. ATKINSON, jun. Secretary.

div.p: A THIRD and weighty Inducement to the Settlement of tho≈øe Lands, was argued from his Maje≈øty's expre≈øs Order, prohibiting the Government of New-York from Granting any of tho≈øe Lands in Di≈øpute, which is as follows.

div.p: PRESENT,

"His Maje≈øty taking the ≈øaid Report" i. e. a Report of the Board of Trade,‚Äîinto Con≈øideration, was plea≈øed with the Advice of his Privy Council, to approve thereof, and doth hereby ≈øtrictly charge, require and command, that the Governor or Commander in Chief of his Maje≈øty's Province of New-York, for the Time being, do not, upon Pain of his Maje≈øty's highe≈øt Di≈øplea≈øure, pre≈øume to make any Grant what≈øoever, of any Part of the Lands de≈øcribed in the ≈øaid Report, until his Maje≈øty's further Plea≈øure ≈øhall be known concerning the ≈øame.

div.p:
UPON the fulle≈øt Examination into all the Circum≈øtances which at pre≈øent con≈øtitute the State of that Di≈øtrict between the Rivers Hud≈øon, and Connecticut; out of which, the greate≈øt Di≈øorders and Confu≈øion have ari≈øen: It ≈øeemeth to us, that the principal Objects of Attention in the Con≈øideration of any Mea≈øures
that can be ≈øugge≈øted for re≈øtoring public Tranquility, and quieting Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, are,

FIRST, Tho≈øe Town≈øhips, which having been originally ≈øettled and e≈øtabli≈øhed under Grants from the Government of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts Bay, fell within this Di≈øtrict, by the Determination of the Northern Boundary of that Province, in the Year 1740.

SECONDLY, Tho≈øe Grants of Land, made within this Di≈øtrict, by the Government of New-York, previous to the e≈øtabli≈øhment of the Town≈øhips laid out by the Governor of New-Hamp≈øhire, after the Conclu≈øion of the Peace; and which Land now lies within the Limits of ≈øome One or Other of tho≈øe Town≈øhips.

THIRDLY, Tho≈øe Town≈øhips, which having been originally laid out by the Governor of New-Hamp≈øhire, either continue in the ≈øame State, or have been confirmed by Grants from New-York, and al≈øo, tho≈øe which have ≈øince originated under Grants from the Latter of tho≈øe Colonies.

WITH Regard to tho≈øe Town≈øhips which fall under the Fir≈øt of the abovementioned De≈øcriptions; when we con≈øider their Nature and Origin, and the numberle≈øs Difficulties to which the original Proprietors of them mu≈øt have been ≈øubjected in the Settlement of Lands expo≈øed to the Incur≈øions of the Savages, and to every Di≈øtre≈øs
which the Neighbourhood of the French in Time of War cou'd bring upon them; and, when we add to the≈øe Con≈øiderations, the great Rea≈øon there is to believe that the Grants were made upon the Ground of Military Services again≈øt the Enemy; we do not he≈øitate to Submit to your Lord≈øhips our Opinion, that the pre≈øent Proprietors of the≈øe Town≈øhips, ought, both in Ju≈øtice and Equity, to be quieted in their Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions: And, that all Grants what≈øoever, made by the Government of New-York, of any Lands within the Limits of tho≈øe Town≈øhips, whether the Degree of Improvement under the original Grant had been more or le≈øs; are, in every Light which they can be viewed, oppre≈ø≈øive and unju≈øt: But as we are ≈øen≈øible that ≈øuch ≈øub≈øequent Grants made by the Government of New-York, however unwarrantable, cannot be ≈øet a≈øide by any Authority from his Maje≈øty, in Ca≈øe the Grantees ≈øhall in≈øi≈øt on their Title; we ≈øubmit to your Lord≈øhips, whether it might not be expedient, in Order to quiet the the original Proprietors in their Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, to propo≈øe that all ≈øuch Per≈øons who may Claim Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Lands within the Limits of ≈øuch Town≈øhips under New-York Grants, ≈øhould upon Condition of their quiting ≈øuch Claim, receive a Grant under the Seal of New-York upon the like Terms, and free of all Expences, of an equal Number of Acres in ≈øo me other Part of the Di≈øtrict lying between the Rivers Hud≈øon and Connecticut; and in Ca≈øe where any actual Settlement or Improvement has been made
by ≈øuch Claimants, that they ≈øhould in ≈øuch Ca≈øe, receive Fifty Acres of wa≈øte Land for every Three Acres, they may have improved.

WITH Regard to tho≈øe Grants made by the Government of New-York, which fall within the Second De≈øcription, and upon which any actual Improvement has been made; they do appear to us to de≈øerve the ≈øame Con≈øideration; and that the Proprietors thereof ought not to be di≈øturbed in their Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, whether that Improvement be to a greater or le≈ø≈øer Extent: But we beg Leave to ob≈øerve to your Lord≈øhips, that in both the≈øe Ca≈øes no Con≈øideration ought to be had to any Claim, where it ≈øhall appear that no regular Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion has ever been taken, and no actual Settlement ever been made.

WITH Regard to tho≈øe Town≈øhips which fall within the la≈øt mentioned De≈øcription, we ≈øubmit to your Lord≈øhips our Opinion, That provided ≈øuch Town≈øhips do not include Lands within the Limits of ≈øome antecedent Grant, upon which actual Improvement has at any Time been made, it would be advi≈øeable they ≈øhould be confirmed as Town≈øhips, according to the Limits expre≈ø≈øed in the Grants thereof; and that all Per≈øons having Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of any Shares in the ≈øaid Town≈øhips, either as original Grantees, or by Purcha≈øe or Conveyance, and upon which Shares any actual Improvement or Settlement has been made, ought not in Ju≈øtice to have been, or to be in Future, di≈øturbed in
the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of ≈øuch Shares; nor ought they to be bound to any other Conditions, whether of Quit-rent or otherwi≈øe, than what is contained in the Grant.

THESE Inducements are indi≈øputably Authoritative, and need no Commentation: Yet notwith≈øtanding the Priority and Preferance of the New-Hamp≈øhire Title to that of New-York, and the ≈øo many corroberating and concomitant Inducements to the Claimants under the former, to ≈øettle and cultivate tho≈øe Lands; yet the A≈ø≈øembly of New-York, in ≈øundry Parts of their State of the Right, &c. and more particularly through the Appendix, treat tho≈øe Inhabitants, merely on Account of ≈øuch Settlement, with the mo≈øt extreme Injury; who, in≈øtead of arguing, only declaim again≈øt them, and go on in a Gradation of Con≈øequences drawn from fal≈øe Premi≈øes, till they have dragged them from their true Character of hone≈øt Men, to that of U≈øurpers, Rioters, and Felons. Although the Quotations from our Authors have already been lengthy, yet that a Precedent of their Inju≈øtice may not here be wanted, the following, from the third Page of their Appendix is in≈øerted.

p.q:
But though the ≈øame Principles have been explained, and enforced in ≈øeveral Acts and Proclamations of Government, as well as on repeated Trials in our Courts of Judicatory, they have left no ≈øuitable Impre≈ø≈øion on the contentious Claimants under New-Hamp≈øhire. On the Contrary, in Contempt of the Dictates of Ju≈øtice, the Deci≈øions of Law, and the civil Authority,
have their Encroachments, which were few in Number at the Time of the royal Determination, been increa≈øed and extended in a tenfold Proportion; and that in general by Men, who cannot plead that they were deceived or ignorant of the Nature or Merit of their Claim, which it appears, were too notorious to have e≈øcaped their Ob≈øervation, but who in ≈øpite of every Warning and Remon≈øtrance to deter them, which human Prudence could devi≈øe, engaged as Volunteers on the Side of New-Hamp≈øhire, and wilfully plunged them≈øelves into the Controver≈øy. To extenuate their own Indi≈øcretion & Mi≈øconduct, Calumny & Mi≈ørepre≈øentation are their only Re≈øource; and accordingly without the lea≈øt Rea≈øon, they charge the Government of New-York with Partiality, and every Land-holder under it, upon whom they have tre≈øpa≈ø≈øed, with Inju≈øtice & Oppre≈ø≈øion; a≈ø≈øerting, that becau≈øe they have ≈øanctified their Claim by a wrongful Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, they ought peacebly to enjoy the Fruits of their U≈øurpation. To fortify their Pretentions they have ≈øpared no Art or Act of Violence, however Criminal; and after all, as if they were really injured, and the Objects of Regard, they do not he≈øitate to carry their Complaints to the Throne, and by ≈øpecial Agents to ≈øolicit ≈øome extraordinary Act of Favour, by which their Offences may be pa≈ø≈øed over with Impunity, and their Encroachments perpetuated in Prejudice to tho≈øe who enjoy a clear Title from the Crown, under the Great Seal of New-York.

div.p:
As this clamorous Quotation is already mo≈øtly an≈øwered, ≈øhall only remark, as to tho≈øe Settlers extending their Encroachments in a ten-fold Proportion, ≈øince the Royal Determination. It hath been fully evinced that this Determination re≈øpected Juri≈ødiction only, and the before recited Royal Order and Report of the Board of Trade, were accounted ≈øufficient to exclude all manner of Doubts in the Minds of the New-Hamp≈øhire Claimants of the Validity of their Title. They truly cannot plead that they were deceived or ignorant of the Nature or Merit of their Claim. This Matter was elucidated by the highe≈øt Wi≈ødom and Authority in the Nation; they rejoice in the Clemency of their Sovereign, and in the Wi≈ødom and impartial Ju≈øtice of the Honourable Board of Trade, exhibited as afore≈øaid, upon which Encouragement tho≈øe Claimants have greatly extended Settlements on tho≈øe Lands, in a more ≈øpecial Manner on Onion River, and Lake Champlain, between the Town≈øhip of Panton, which a-buts on the Lake oppo≈øite Crown-Point, and the ≈øaid River, and North of it almo≈øt to the Forty-fith Degree of North Latitude, and preparations are vigorou≈øly making to extend the≈øe Settlements to the very Bounds of the Province of Quebec. It is ≈øeldom any new Country Settles with ≈øuch Rapidity, notwith≈øtanding the Oppo≈øitions they meet with from the Government of New-York: The Expence of clearing Roads, building Mills, Moving to and ≈øettling in that Wilderne≈øs Country only for Two Years la≈øt pa≈øt, would amount to no very incon≈øiderable Sum. And tho≈øe Settlers from the foregoing
Rea≈øons, do not in the lea≈øt he≈øitate, but that they in ≈øo fulfilling the Conditions of their Charters, have and are acting agreeable to his Maje≈øty's Will and Plea≈øure; and that tho≈øe Labours will not only be for their own Emolument, but for the Enlargement of the Briti≈øh Empire, and Addition of the Crown Revenue.

THE A≈ø≈øembly of New-York have been very particular in their Hi≈øtory of the Tumults and Riots made by tho≈øe Settlers, in Oppo≈øition to that Government, (many of which Facts mu≈øt be confe≈ø≈øed to be true) though they have carefully omitted their manyfold Provocations, yet, with all their Particularity have given but a very imperfect Idea of tho≈øe Tran≈øactions. I ≈øhall here, therefore, waving particulars, give a general Review of the Oeconomy of tho≈øe Settlers in their Oppo≈øitions to that Government. For defending their Properties, they were indicted Rioters, the next Thing was to defend Rioters; then they had two Objects as the Subjects of their Protection, viz. their Per≈øons, as well as Property: They were at Fir≈øt greatly intimidated at the empty Appearance of Law, that their Opponents were ≈øo conver≈øant with, ≈øometimes de≈øpairing of maintaining their Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions; yet upon Extremity, rather than quit their Sub≈øtance to the in≈øatiable Ravi≈øhers, would rally and fru≈øtrate their De≈øigns: Thus, when the Sheriff of the County of Albany with his Po≈ø≈øe came to di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈øs ≈øome of them, they mo≈øt generally, boldly took up Arms, and appointed Leaders. Matters having come to this, not long
after, the Inhabitants a≈ø≈øembled and appointed Committees of Safety in the ≈øeveral Towns throughout their Settlement; this general Committee have the conducting of the Public Affairs of the Country for its Security, 'till his Maje≈øty ≈øettles the Controver≈øy. They have erected ≈øeveral Companies, which by the Votes of the Soldiers are furni≈øhed with Officers, the≈øe Companies form a Regiment which are known by the ≈øignificant Character of GREEN-MOUNTAIN BOYS, who are generally in the Prime of Life, well ver≈øed in the U≈øe of Fire-Arms, and of robu≈øt Con≈øtitutions; probably no American Regiment in an interior Defence could excel them, or that would willingly contribute more to the Support of the Crown of Great-Britain; for it is ob≈øervable, that ≈øuch Subjects that will not fight for their Property, will never fight for their King: And, the general In≈øtructions from the Committee, ever have been, not to act in any thing again≈øt the Government of New-York, but on the Defen≈øive.

IT is in the Nature of Things impo≈ø≈øible to pa≈øs a right Judgment on the Conduct of the New-Hamp≈øhire Settlers, without taking into View the Treatment of the Government of New-York towards them. All Ca≈øes mu≈øt be determined upon the peculiar Circum≈øtances attending; no Act can ≈øcarcely be conceived of which, under certain attending Circum≈øtances might not be lawful. It will be readily admitted on the Part of tho≈øe Settlers, that, provided the Government of New-York, and its Patentees have a clear and inconte≈øtible Right to
tho≈øe Lands; and that they are Intruders, and by Force and Violence have maintained ≈øuch Encroachments, then, they are truly guilty, in manner as the A≈ø≈øembly of New-York have alledged: But on the Contrary, if tho≈øe Settlers have a legal and inconte≈øtible Right to tho≈øe Lands, that they pro≈øecute Settlement on the good Faith of that Title, and the ≈øundry Approbations of both their Title and Settlement from the Briti≈øh Admini≈øtration, then, they are not guilty in Manner as tho≈øe Gentlemen have declared; and the impartial Public, in≈øtead of viewing them as U≈øurpers, Rioters and Felons, will ju≈øtify them in their Conduct, and e≈øteem them as good Members of Society, leige Subjects to the Crown of Great-Britain, and good Soldiers for defending their Per≈øons and Properties.

THUS, is humbly ≈øubmitted the State of the Controver≈øy, which has for many Years ≈øub≈øi≈øted between the Government of New-York and the Settlers under New-Hamp≈øhire; by impartial Ju≈øtice mu≈øt every Act ≈øtand or fall; if tho≈øe Settlers are in the wrong, they are criminally ≈øo, but if not, then the Allegations of their Opponents will be adjudged as futile and cruel.

div.head: INTRODUCTION, TO THE APPENDIX.
div.p: WHEREAS the French Government of Canada have made ≈øundry Grants of ≈øome of the mo≈øt valuable Part of tho≈øe Lands in Di≈øpute, between the Government of New-York and the Claimants under New-Hamp≈øhire on the Ea≈øterly Side of Lake Champlain, and even to the Southward of Crown-Point. And whereas the General A≈ø≈øembly of the Colony of New-York, in their State of the Rights of that Colony, ≈øo far as concerns the French Grants afore≈øaid, have very ingeniou≈øly confuted the French Claim to tho≈øe Lands; ≈øhall therefore ≈øubjoin it as an Appendix to this Treati≈øe, in a≈ømuch as the ≈øame Arguments equally Support the New-Hamp≈øhire Claim again≈øt that of the French, as they do that of New-York.‚ÄîThere were ≈øeveral Rea≈øons which induced the Author to make U≈øe of this Appendix.
Fir≈øtly, Becau≈øe he is not acqainted with many of the Hi≈øtorical Facts, on which the Arguments therein Contained are founded. And,
Secondly, From the Con≈øideration that he cannot Argue ≈øo well. And a Third and ≈øpecial Rea≈øon is,

Becau≈øe be is credibly informed that the Gentlemen Land-≈øchemers of New-York have altered their Plan of Operation, and have at an incon≈øiderable Price, purcha≈øed the greate≈øt Part of the French Claim to coroborate their own ≈øub≈øequent Patents, and by that Means to avail them≈øelves of an antecedent Claim to that of New-Hamp≈øhire; and that their pre≈øent Scheme is to be ≈øilent at the Court at Great-Britain, with Re≈øpect to their Claim under New-York, and carry on the Di≈øpute in the Name of the French Barons, hopeing by this Stratagem to procure to them≈øelves the Fee of tho≈øe Lands which the French Grants cover; and fru≈øtrate and Di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈øs the Claimants and Settlers under New-Hamp≈øhire, which are ≈øeated on the Lands the French Grants include, to the Number of about Three Hundred Families, and on which there is not a ≈øingle Settler under either the French or New-York Claim. And ina≈ømuch, as the Chain of Arguments predicated on undeniable Facts, and exhibited in the following Appendix, of which this is an Introduction, are abundantly ≈øufficient to invalidate the French Claim, the Author therefore takes a peculiar Plea≈øure in turning the Artillery of the A≈ø≈øembly of New-York again≈øt them≈øelves, in full Confidence that, that A≈ø≈øembly cannot, by Rea≈øon and Argument, gain≈øay what they have thus exhibited with the Help of any French Cunning what≈øoever. And provided the A≈ø≈øembly of New-York had publi≈øhed the following Appendix, with a friendly De≈øign towards the New-Hamp≈øhire Settlers; that A≈ø≈øembly would have merited their grateful Acknowledgements; but though their De≈øign at that Time was to defeat the French Claim to e≈øtabli≈øh their New-York Patents, neverthele≈øs it ≈øeems a good Providence hath made U≈øe of the learned Abilities and evil
Inten≈øions of the Gentlemen of that A≈ø≈øembly, which tho≈øe Settlers dreaded as their greate≈øt temporary Evil to be conducive to their greate≈øt temporary Good.

Altho' the Arguments contained in the Appendix, to be hereafter in≈øerted, are full and compleat again≈øt the French Claim, they are neverehele≈øs ≈øomewhat incumbered with meer imaginary Notions, relative to the prodigious and antient Northern Extention of the Colony of New-York, even to the River St. Lawrence. They indeed a≈øcertain and vindicate the Right of the Crown of England to tho≈øe Lands, and then on ficticious Principles a≈ø≈øume the Right of that Colony to be co-exten≈øive with that of the Crown. Now the Reader will with a little Attention, di≈øcern that Arguments relative to the French claim, do not at all depend on the aforementioned Extention of the Right of the colony of New-York, or of any of his Maje≈øty's colonies: Meerly the Right of the crown to that Extention of Territory is abundantly ≈øufficient to nullify and make void the French claim. Undoubtedly tho≈øe Lands granted by the French Government of Canada, adjoining to Lake Champlain were crown Lands when u≈øurped and granted by the French, and continued ≈øo to be till it was granted by his Maje≈øty's Engli≈øh Government of New-Hamp≈øhire. But of this enough has been already animadverted. The Di≈øpute between New-York and New-Hamp≈øhire is committed to the Publick con≈øideration. What remains in this Introduction to the Appendix is only to point out to the Reader that ≈øuch Part of the Arguments, or rather Repre≈øentations, therein contained as a≈ø≈øume a colony Right to tho≈øe Lands, are foreign to the Point in I≈ø≈øue, in the Di≈øpute of the French claim; the ≈øame may be ≈øaid, provided
the Government of New-Hamp≈øhire a≈ø≈øume a particular colony Right of their's to the ≈øame Premi≈øes. Such Arguments may truly affect the colonies of New-York and New-Hamp≈øhire, but by no Means affect the I≈ø≈øue in Di≈øpute relative to the French claim, ina≈ømuch as the Right of the Crown of England to tho≈øe Lands Precludes the French claim intirely. Therefore ≈øuch colony Arguments as may be found inter≈øper≈øed in the following Appendix are only Digre≈ø≈øions from the Point in I≈ø≈øue, but cannot any Way affect the Arguments which centre in that ≈øingle Point. Tho≈øe Digre≈ø≈øions are al≈øo virtually an≈øwered in the foregoing Di≈øcour≈øe.

div.head: APPENDIX, Tran≈øcribed from the A≈ø≈øembly of New-York's State, &c. Verbatim.

A STATE Of the Rights of the Colony of New-York, ≈øo far as concerns the Grants formerly made by the French Goverment of Canada, of Lands on Lake Champlain, and at and to the Southward of Crown-Point.
div.p: THE Whole intermediate Coa≈øt between Martha's Vineyard and the fir≈øt Settlements in Virginia, remained entirely unknown 'till Hud≈øon's Di≈øcovery in 1609, when it began to be minutely explored, and the Bays, Rivers, I≈ølands, and Creeks, di≈øtingui≈øhed by Name.

Hud≈øon's River was again vi≈øited in 1610, and the following Years, by Dutch Ships, with a Grant under the States General for an exclu≈øive Trade; and the Coloy which they denominated Nieuw Nederlant, advanced with ≈øuch Rapidity, that in 1612 they had a Town and Fort in New-Am≈øterdam, now New-York; and in 1615, another Town and Fort at Aurania, now Albany 160 Miles up Hud≈øon's River.

IN 1623, they erected Fort Good Hope, on Connecticut River, and upwards of Thirty-five Miles from its Mouth. Near to this ancient Fortre≈øs the Town of Hartford has ≈øince been built under Connecticut, but it is indi≈øputable that the Dutch actually enjoyed the exclu≈øive Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, Trade,
and Advantage of the whole River, long before it had been approached by any Engli≈øh Subject; and that they claimed and con≈øidered all the Country to the We≈øtward of Connecticut River, and as far Northward as the River St. Lawrence, as Part of their Colony of Nieuw Nederlandt See Ogilvy's America, publi≈øhed in 1671, and the Map at Page 168, Sect. Nieuw Nederlant; where this Country is called Nova Belgica, and Nieuw Nederlant; and the River it≈øelf is called Rio St. Lawrence, DE GROUTE RIVIER VAN NIEUW NEDERLANT.
See al≈øo Blaev's America, Vol. xi. publi≈øhed at Am≈øterdam in 1662, and his Map in≈øcribed Nova Belgica, et Anglia Nova.
.
IN 1663-4, King Charles the Second, granted to his Brother James, Duke of York, the Di≈øtrict of Country comprehending New York and New-Jer≈øey, which were Territories po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by the Dutch.
IN that Year the Dutch were ≈øubdued by an Armament from England. By the Articles of Capitulation, the Rights and E≈øtates of all the Inhabitants were ≈øecured to them.
IN 1673, the Country was again ≈øurrendered to a Dutch Fleet, but in 1674, by Treaty between the two Nations, the Dutch ceded all their Claim to this Country, to the Crown of England.

IN the ≈øame Year King Charles the Second, to remove all Doubts which might have ari≈øen concerning the Validity of his fir≈øt Grant to the Duke, on Account of the intermediate Conque≈øt by the Dutch, confirmed the ≈øame Territories to his Royal
Highne≈øs by a new Grant. There can be no Di≈øpute but that by the Words of the Duke's Grant, the Province of New-York was to have an Ea≈øtern Extent to Connecticut River. That River takes it's Ri≈øe to the Northward of the 45th Degree of North Latitude, and con≈øequently beyond the Boundary lately e≈øtabli≈øhed between New-York and Quebet, by his Maje≈øty's Royal Proclamation of the 7th Day of October 1763.

ON this Principle we have always claimed, under the Royal Grant, as the ju≈øt and ancient Right of this Province, All the Country which lies to the South of We≈øt Line drawn from the Head of Connecticut River; except ≈øo far as it interferes with the Colony of Connecticut, with which a Settlement was made in 1683, by Commi≈ø≈øaries of both Provinces, under mutual Acts of Legi≈ølature, and which was confirmed by King William.
BUT we have a further Title to the Country as far Northward as the South Side of the River St. Lawrence.

THE Dutch on their fir≈øt E≈øtabli≈øhment here, made a Treaty of Peace and Alliance with the Five Nations, called by the French the Iroquois. The≈øe warlike Tribes were the Conquerors and Ma≈øters of a great Part of North-America, holding all the Natives in Subjection, from the River St. Lawrence down to Georgia.

WHEN the Engli≈øh became po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of New-York, they al≈øo made an Alliance with the Five Nations,
who afterwards, in the mo≈øt expre≈øs Terms, ≈øubjected them≈øelves to the Crown of England, under the Government of New-York; and however wild and untractable, were always treated as Subjects by this Government.

THE Country as far Northward as the River St. Lawrence, and We≈øtward without any known Limits, was their undoubted PropertyThat the Country as far North as the River St. Lawrence, belonged to the Iroquois, or Five Nations, is proved by all the ancient Maps and Hi≈øtories. In the Map in≈øcribed Nova Belgica, et Anglia Nova, publi≈øhed in xi Vol. Geographiae Blavianae, in 1662, Lake Champlain is called Lacus Irocoien≈øis, and the Country on the Ea≈øt Side of the Lake is called Irocoi≈øia.
In Johannes Van Keulen's Atlas, publi≈øhed at Am≈øterdam in 1720, the River St. Lawrence is called Rio des Iroquois ou de St. Lawrence, and the Country on the South of that River and We≈øt of Lake Champlain, Iroquois, and the Lake it≈øelf Lac Champlain on mere de Iroquois.
Ogilvy in his America, ≈øays one of the great Lakes is called the Lake of Iroquois, which together with a River of the ≈øame Name (Sorrel by the French) falls into the River of Canada. He adds, that the French having, in early Times, ≈øided with the Algonquins, again≈øt the Iroquois, have been ≈øo bated by them ever ≈øince, that none of them dur≈øt ever appear again in any Part of the Lake. Ogilby 166.
The Five Nations formerly lived near the Place where Montreal now ≈øtands. In 1672 the French Governor Mon≈øieur De Frontenac, per≈øuaded them to allow him to build a Fort on the North Side of Cadaracqui Lake, under Pretence of a Store for Marthandize. After engaging in two bloody Wars, and particularly the la≈øt in Re≈øentment of ≈øuch flagrant Encroachments, ≈øhould it now be admitted that Canada extended as it's Advocates alledge, what would be the Inference? Mu≈øt it not nece≈ø≈øarily follow, that the Occupancy of the Lakes, Crown Point, Tieonderoga, &c. was no Inva≈øion or Act of Ho≈øtility, but the Exertion of a rightful Sovereignty? And con≈øequently, that we were the Aggre≈ø≈øors in tho≈øe Wars, and not the French; for nothing le≈øs could be implied in the Confirmations ≈øollicited.

4thly. Lake Champlain and Lake George, open a mo≈øt important Communication, and may be ju≈øtly called a Key to the Northern Briti≈øh Colonies
However humbled in the Cour≈øe of a War, which has crowned Great-Britain with unexampled Succe≈øs, it is natural to think the French of Canada will long look with an affectionate Eye towards their former Prince. The Canadian Barons in particular, lo≈øe a flattering Weight and Di≈øtinction; while under the Dominion of the Engli≈øh, they are ≈øunk into mere Commons. Their Language, their Laws, and their Manners, but above all, their Religion, mu≈øt for an Age to come, forbid a cordial Attachment to our Government. They may not be without Hopes that the Fortune of War, between two powerful and rival Nations, may one Day give France ≈øuch an A≈øcendency as to reduce us to the Nece≈ø≈øity of re≈øtoring Canada.

FROM this View, it mu≈øt be very impolitic to ≈øuffer the French, altho' now our Fellow Subjects, to ≈øettle on tho≈øe Lakes, ≈øince it will give them the fulle≈øt Opportunity of a≈ø≈øi≈øting their Countrymen in invading and di≈øtre≈ø≈øing this and the neighbouring Colonies, and e≈øtabli≈øhing a Footing, on the fir≈øt Rupture, in the Heart of our Country. On the other Hand, if the fertile Lands ≈øurrounding the Lakes, were peopled with the King's natural born Subjects, this Danger, which ought not needle≈øsly to be de≈øpi≈øed, would be avoided; it's ill Con≈øequences be prevented, and the Canadians them≈øelves, even if they ≈øhould be inclined to revolt, would be over awed into Subjection.

BUT this is not all.‚ÄîIf ever Canada ≈øhould be the Subject of a Ce≈ø≈øion to France, what were her ancient Bounds mu≈øt become a nece≈ø≈øary Que≈øtion? Her original Grants to the Canadians, ≈øupported
by the Confirmation of the King of Great-Britain, wold be con≈øidered as irre≈øi≈øtible Evidence of ancient Right; and thus not only Lake Champlain but Lake George, which are both inter≈øper≈øed with the≈øe Grants, would fall again into the Hands of France. The Po≈ø≈øibility of an Altercation of this Nature, will be wholly removed by con≈øidering the Claims of the Canadians to the Lands on tho≈øe Lakes, as unworthy of Attention.

UPON the Whole, viewing this Subject in every Light, upon the Principles of original Right,‚ÄîTreaty and Ce≈ø≈øion,‚ÄîLaw and Ju≈øtice,‚ÄîEquity and Policy, it is conceived that the Military and other Grants under the Seal of this Province, ought not to be impeached; and that the Canadian Claims, extravagant in them≈øelves, and de≈øtitute of all Foundation, ought to be rejected.
